answer: A long time ago when I was in third grade, I had a close friend named @PERSON2. His mom was always in a bad mood. She never laughed and she never smiled. Every time I saw her, I would warmly smile at her, but all she would do was frown and keep walking quickly. At first, I didn't know she was a grouch. I just naively thought she didn't like me or something. When @PERSON2 told me his mom was a grouch, I started to laugh out loud and couldn't stop. He asked me what was so funny. I told him that I thought his mom didn't like me because every time I saw his mom, I would smile at her, and all she would do was frown and walk away briskly. That made my friend laugh too. We were cracking up so hard that we got in trouble in class for disturbing the quiet. The next day, @PERSON2 and I were having lunch at school. He suddenly said to me, "<hey your pretty good at making people laugh>". I replied, "<no I am not my jokes are really horrible>". He said, "<@CAPS1 lets put them to the test go up to some one new to this school>". I said @CAPS1. So we went around the whole school, searching everywhere for a new student. Unfortunately, we couldn't find one. Just then, we heard the bell ring and we quickly ran to our class. We sat in the back of the classroom. It was only @PERSON2 and I, with an empty seat between us. We were really excited because our teacher @PERSON1 was going to show us a movie. @PERSON1 walked to the front of the room and said, "class today I have an announcement. We have a new student in our class. Say hello to @LOCATION1." @ORGANIZATION1 walked through the door gracefully. @PERSON1 told @ORGANIZATION1 she could sit in the back in between @PERSON2 and I. She sat down, turned to the both of us, and politely said hello. @PERSON2 gave me a look that clearly said "tell her the joke", and I gave him a thumbs up. I turned to @LOCATION1 and said, "hi I'm @CAPS4. Do you want to hear a joke?" @ORGANIZATION1 said, "yeah sure." I started, "<@CAPS5 knocks". She said, "<who's there". I said, "<boo". She said, "<boo who?" I said, "<oh don't cry I am right here>". At first, she didn't laugh because she didn't get it. But during the middle of the movie, she said, "<ohhhh I get it" and she started to laugh heartily. @PERSON2 turned to me and said, "<I told you so>". @PERSON2 got this crazy idea that if I spent the night at his house, I could make his mom laugh or at least make her smile. I said, "<@CAPS1 sounds like a great plan>". I asked my mom if it was okay if I could spend the night at @PERSON2's house. She said, "<yeah just make sure it's okay with his mom>". @PERSON2 asked his mom, and she said it was okay. When I got to @PERSON2's house, the first thing we did was play exciting video games. When it was dinner time, we all sat down at the table to eat. @PERSON2 and I were on one side, and his parents were on the other. When we started eating, @PERSON2 told me to tell the joke to his parents. I said @CAPS1. So I said to them, "<@CAPS5 @CAPS5>". They replied, "<who's there". I said, "<boo". They said, "<boo who?" I said, "<oh don't cry I am right here>". His parents started to laugh and laugh and they kept laughing for like five minutes straight. @PERSON2 turned to me and yelled, "it worked!" His mom asked what worked. @PERSON2 explained everything to them. His mom told us that her mom had recently died and that's why she was in a bad mood. After dinner, we went to bed and fell asleep peacefully. The next morning, when my mom came to pick me up, she asked me how the sleep over went. I said it was really fun. I made people laugh. She said @CAPS1, but laughter isn't going to help you clean your room. All I could say was, "gosh darn it." FIN.

Softball has to be one of the single most greatest sports in existence. Playing softball in college has always been a long - held goal of mine. I love the feeling of the dirt that sticks stubbornly to your face, the sweat steadily dripping from your forehead, and the gallons and gallons of water you pour all over yourself to keep cool in the blistering @CAPS2 heat. Although I love softball, I feel that the memories you acquire from the times you have with your teammates are the things you remember the most throughout your softball career. I have always had great memories through softball, with many laughs, tears, and frustrations. So when I had the opportunity to play on a top - notch team, I eagerly looked forward to all the many more memories I would create. Hood @CAPS1 @CAPS2 was my team name. I had played almost four years with this local team. Many of these girls were like real sisters to me. They had treated me amazingly throughout my years playing with them. I felt like I had my set team. I was going to play with these girls all through high school, and we would become even closer, sharing more inside jokes and bonding moments. As my fifth year now approached, I was looking forward to it. But when my dad came up with the idea that maybe I play for a team not as local, that idea was also very enticing. I now faced a big dilemma. Either stay with the team I knew so well and continue to play with them until high school ended, enjoying the familiar camaraderie; or play with a team I knew nothing about, play with girls that might not like me, girls that were so much better than me and might look down upon me. As I carefully looked at the pros and cons of both teams, I initially decided no. I would stay with the team that I knew so well and I would stay comfortable at where I was at. At that point, softball season was just around the corner, and I began to reanalyze everything. Did I really want to stay and be comfortable? Or maybe challenge myself to become a better player? Maybe I could work hard enough, and have college scouts take a good look at me and hopefully have me play for them later. I then decided I would take a chance and try for this team. As my dad and I drove to the field where I would try out for this team, my stomach was in tight knots. I desperately wanted this team to like me. I was playing all the possible ways in my head I could greet them so I didn't sound snobby or a grump. The time moved quickly, and I wished it would slow down. My heart felt like it was beating a million times per second. I was so nervous that my mouth began to feel sticky and have an odd, unpleasant taste to it. Soon after, my mouth became bone dry, no taste, no flavor, just a sticky mess. The car then stopped. My dad looked at me and just said, "ready or not here we come". Nervousness began to take over my body. My arms were shaking uncontrollably, and I was second - guessing every move I made. I even had troubles removing my seat belt. As I approached the field, it felt like time was in slow motion. Walking by, I saw all the girls turn their heads to see what new fresh meat had arrived. My first thought was to run. That was it. I didn't want to go. I was done. I wanted to go home and start my year with the @CAPS2 team. I just couldn't take it. Then as I walked onto the field, they all grew a warm smile. Each and everyone of them told me their names, their favorite color, and a small fun fact about themselves. I found myself laughing throughout my whole try - out. There were no awkward moments, and I really enjoyed my time there. I couldn't wait to go back. I now had made new friends, friends I knew I would grow close with over time. My year with this team was amazing. I have friendships with these girls that I never would have discovered if I hadn't gone. Those girls are like family, and the coaches even more so. Laughter played a very big role in the decision I made to play with this team. If I had just gone and tried out, and had I not had fun and laughed, I would have decided to play with the @CAPS2. I have had great memories with the @CAPS2, but also softball is all about going out, discovering new friendships, and therefore, enjoying the sport as well as the people.

Some people like making people laugh, but I absolutely love it. I will do most anything to get a good, hearty laugh. I will make fun of myself in a self - deprecating way, do insanely stupid things that make me look silly, and sometimes even hurt myself (not in any serious way). When I was little, I didn't really understand laughter. For some odd reason, I could never tell the difference if people were laughing at something or laughing with it. I was kind of "special" in some areas as a kid (I still am today). Still, at the tender age of five, I loved making people laugh. And being "special", I would do even crazier things for a laugh. Mind you, I was kind of a spaz, and a really big spaz at that. I was the most hyperactive five - year - old you will ever meet. For example, one time I accidentally hit myself in the head with a hammer while trying to be helpful. Another time, I was dancing around in class with a pencil in my hand, and in my wild movements, I stabbed myself in the head with it and needed stitches. One of the craziest times though was a couple days before I had to take pictures. I really wanted to go play outside. My mom, knowing how "special" I was (I got it from her), wouldn't allow me to. The expert persuasive kid I was back then convinced her to let me go outside. Before I could even reach the street, I tripped and fell head first onto the corner of the sidewalk, leaving a huge mark on my face and completely ruining the pictures. Although that might make some people laugh, this is a story about laughter, not me being a spaz. Now that you know that I love making people laugh, I'm "special", and that I'm a complete spaz, I can get on with the story. Well, I was in kindergarten, and I loved school because I got to hang out with my friends and play with blocks. That might sound stupid, but I was in kindergarten. The only thing I didn't like about kindergarten was bullies. Surprisingly, I have never had a bully except in kindergarten, but this was a really bad bully. He would give me wedgies at story time, which was the best time to do so because the teacher couldn't see. I still know the bully too, but he's no bully anymore. He's a goody two - shoes now, which I think is odd. Anyways, kindergarten was a very good year for me except one day (and every day I got a wedgie). That day is what this whole story is about. It's why I told you I love making people laugh, why I told you I'm "special", and a spaz. Everything in the story circles around this one day, *dramatic pause* in kindergarten. It started out like any other normal day in kindergarten. I woke up, did my daily routine like brushing my teeth and getting dressed, hopped in the car, and headed to school. When I got to school, I grabbed my daily binder and patted the education sign like a mall cop would pat the observe and report sign. I did all my work and colored (which was basically all my work). It came around break, so we ran around the playground and got our little snack. When we finished getting the last few drops out of our juice boxes, we headed over to story time. We were all in the little circle (which was more like a deformed oval) listening to the story. Right when I would get into the story and lose my guard, I would receive an excruciatingly painful (for a five - year - old) wedgie. The story was almost finished, and our five - year - old attention spans were wearing thin. We were getting all excited. The story finally finished, and we were standing up. And this is where my memory starts to fade. I cracked a really funny joke, and the whole kindergarten class erupted into laughter. Me being a "special" spaz that can't tell if people are laughing at me or with me, I burst into tears. I remember balling my eyes out at the drinking fountain, trying hard to hide my tears. One of the teachers tried to help me by telling me that they were laughing at my joke. It took me a couple minutes to stop crying, but a little longer to realize they were not laughing at me. To this day, I still get reminded by classmates about that day. Of course, I can laugh about it now, but that was in kindergarten. I'm in ninth grade now, and for people to remember that is kind of crazy to me. It was a negative experience then, but it turned into a blessing in disguise. It made me grow into a better person. I can tell the difference of laughter and also be okay when people do laugh at me (doing dumb things to make people laugh at me is actually my forte

My best friend, @PERSON1 and I have been close ever since we were @NUM1 years old. We met through @CAPS1 @CAPS2 lessons at our local, friendly dance studio. The studio had a warm and inviting atmosphere, filled with the sounds of music and laughter. We've stayed close throughout the years because we've always engaged in similar activities, like going to movies and trying out new cafes.   We're very different from each other though. I'm more outgoing, always eager to speak my mind and carefree in my approach to life. @CAPS4, on the other hand, is very conservative and can take things too seriously. But either way, we manage to even each other out, like two sides of a well - balanced coin.   Finals week had just gotten over, and @LOCATION1 and I had been excitedly planning a sleepover all week. We just needed time to relax and have some quality time to ourselves, away from the stress of exams. When I had gotten home from school, I gave her a quick call. "@CAPS3?" @CAPS4 answered cheerfully. I carefully grabbed my toothbrush, a soft pillow, comfortable pajamas, and a warm blanket. I put my shoes on and headed back out the door.   My dad dropped me off with all of my gear. I had brought my cozy pajamas, my fluffy pillow, and an extra soft blanket. I walked up her sidewalk to her door, knocked gently, and waited patiently. Only seconds later did @CAPS4 answer it with a big, beaming smile across her face. @CAPS4 led me down to her basement where @CAPS4 had all the junk food set out, neatly arranged and ready for us to attack. @CAPS4 had gone to the store earlier that day and had carefully bought everything we loved. @CAPS4 had set it all up on her old pool table that nobody used. There were all kinds of chips, delicious cookies, fizzy sodas, colorful candy, rich chocolate, and a mouth - watering pizza.   I set my stuff down on the chair in the corner of the room and we feasted. Of course, we couldn't eat all the food. We simply weren't big enough. After eating for almost an hour straight, we were stuffed and laid on her basement floor trying to gain composure. We started laughing at silly little things that came up on commercials on her big screen @CAPS7.   Eventually, we got to talking about how each of our finals went. "I did soo good on all of mine! I'm gonna get ALL A's" @PERSON1 bragged proudly. @CAPS4 has gotten straight A's every year since middle school. "I think I did pretty @CAPS8 too, not so sure about a @NUM3 though." I said as I was laying upside down on the floor, my hair falling towards the ground. "@CAPS8, we'll just see tomorrow!"   We finally decided to move ourselves over to the couch on the opposite side of the pool table, so we could face the @CAPS7 comfortably. It was already @NUM4 in the @TIME1 and we were still on a sugar high, full of energy and excitement. We switched back and forth from watching some old scary movie, which made us jump and scream, and the top @NUM5 music videos of the week, where we sang along to the catchy tunes.   That had passed some time and before we knew it, it was @NUM2 in the @TIME1. @PERSON1 and I were laying on opposite ends of each other. Occasionally, one of us would get some chips or candy from the table. We grew tired to the point where we couldn't keep our eyes open. No one even had enough energy to turn off the overhead light. We fell asleep fast, dreaming of more fun times together.   When I woke - up the next @TIME1, @PERSON1 wasn't laying across from me anymore. @CAPS4 was sitting in the corner chair where I had set my stuff. I looked at the clock, and it was already @NUM4:30 in the afternoon. I looked back at @LOCATION1, @CAPS4 seemed somewhat upset. I shifted around under my blanket so I could face her. "@CAPS5..." I grunted, while I was stretching my tired body. "@TIME1." @CAPS4 said abruptly. @CAPS4 was holding a folded piece of paper in her hand. "@CAPS12's up?" I asked, sitting up on the couch. @CAPS4 crumpled up the piece of paper and threw it at me. I picked it up from my lap and unfolded it. It was her report card. I scanned down the paper looking at all of her grades. @CAPS4 had received all A's... and one @CAPS13. @CAPS4 had gotten a @CAPS13 in her @CAPS15 class. I looked up from the paper to see her hands covering her face. I walked over to her, kinda amused by how upset @CAPS4 was.   "@CAPS16 got a @CAPS13... and @CAPS16're crying?" I asked. @CAPS4 looked up at me quickly. I looked at her with a stupid face, and @CAPS4 busted out laughing. @CAPS4 felt so stupid for crying over @NUM8 @CAPS13. I started laughing too. I knew my grades would be far worse. Heck, I'd be glad to get @CAPS13's. @PERSON1 and I are the perfect best friends. We even each other out. I tell her to lighten up, and @CAPS4 tells me to focus more. @CAPS16 can't take little things like that too seriously, it's just not worth the stress. Sometimes @CAPS16 just gotta relax, and maintain your focus. @CAPS16 have to find your perfect balance of work and play.

Laughter is truly one of life's most precious gifts. It is a really good thing to have in any relationship you are in, whether it's a friendship, a love relationship, or a work relationship. In every type of relationship, laughter acts as a lubricant, making the interactions smoother and more enjoyable. Either way, you need laughter so you don't get so uptight that you become no fun to be around.   Every now and then, somebody around you in your life needs some laughter to cheer them up. People should laugh every day because it has the remarkable ability to make you feel happy even when you are in a really bad mood. When you are feeling suicidal, all you really want is someone to talk to you and make you smile, laugh, and giggle. It really feels good when you laugh with a friend or a significant other. You like to see people smile and laugh, and your friends and family also like to see you laugh here and there once in a while.   So every now and then, take a moment to laugh for once and be happy, even if it is for just a few seconds in your life. Laughter is a major thing to have in your life. It's incredibly nice to laugh and giggle even when life gets you down and is just plain crappy.   Anyone and everyone needs to laugh so they don't become so grouchy and unbearable to be around. So please, for everyone's sake around you and in your life, please laugh. Come on, you know you want to laugh. Ha ha ha. I hope that at least made you smile a little bit.   In any relationship you have or are in, laughter is a major thing you need. Always try to laugh here and there, and you will do just fine in life no matter

I believe that with all people laughter, and having a sense of humor, is something that generally everyone has in common, everyone loves to share with others. Among young teenage girls, laughter is a commodity that is infectious but always wonderful. It's the purest kind of joy we have, it's somethings that brings humans together. It's the beginning and end of friendship and unity. Laughter can ring out and lift the spirits of those that really need it. A simple laugh can make the worst day a little alright. We all know that feeling of dread, and sadness . The kindness, generosity, and good of laughter is one of the few things that are right nowadays. Even in poverty, depression, and oppression the simple joy of laughter can wash away a person's worries for a split second and fill us with utter warmth.  @PERSON1 and I have been the best of friends since we were ten-years-old, and laughter has always been our strongest element. @PERSON1 and I have a knack for making each other burst out in laughter when all we want to do is be angry or just cry. We've decided that apart, we're just a little funny, but with our powers combined we could make anyone laugh. One time when I was skateboarding with my friend, I got really mad because I kept falling off my skateboard and couldn't perform a certain trick. Laughter" A good relationship is built on trust, right? That's what I've heard my whole life. But as I've grown and really started thinking for myself, I came up with my own kind of survival guide, if you will, to good relationships for anyone. Sure, trust is important, but it isn't the only key factor. I've learned laughter is just as important to not only starting a relationship but keeping it full of life. One person in my life helped me really understand that and be able to have that kind of relationship with them. My mom and I have such a great bond and a wonderful way of understanding with each other. Other girls I know don't always have that with their mothers, so I am very fortunate. Sure, we have hard times just like any family, but we are able to laugh those tough moments off with time and start anew. My mom helped me realize, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Having a great bond with my mom is so important to me, but we have not always ran so smoothly though. From about age ten to thirteen, I was a bit troubled in the sense of not wanting to show my emotions. I just wanted to stay quiet. Then, seeing my mom as someone who was strong and beautiful, I have to admit I was a bit worried she would think I was a disappointment. I guess I was afraid to show who I really was to her. Whenever she would joke around with me, I would take those jokes all too seriously, and whenever we would fight about small things, I thought she would hate me forever. I know now I was silly to think that, but I'm actually glad we went through that. I think that's part of what made us stronger, like how there would be no rainbow without the rain or how there would be no happy ending if all was well throughout your whole life. Little did I know the light at the end of the tunnel was just around the corner. One night after dinner, my mom had informed me that it was my night to do dishes. Unlike usual, I completely forgot and went to my room to listen to music and eventually fall asleep. My mother came in my room upset and frustrated. She said, "@PERSON1, why did you ignore me? The dishes need to be done now." I jumped out of bed without a word and began walking to the kitchen. She followed me into the small bright room, "@PERSON1? Are you alright, it's okay that you forgot. I'm not mad." she exclaimed. Again, not a word escaped my lips. I was afraid to say anything. The only sound that came from me was a sigh of relief when I turned back around and noted her absence. When I was finished with the dishes, she pulled me into my room. I tried reading her face; she looked worried. She explained to me the relationship between her and her mom that she so desperately wanted to have with me. She told me about how they would laugh together over silly things and how they promised each other that when they got into fights they would stop themselves, take a deep breath, then laugh. "Laugh? What? Why would you guys do that?" I questioned. She replied, "Because laughter is the best cure for any sad feeling or bad day, as grandma would always say." She helped me experience that by tickling me and joking around. For the first time in my life, I wasn't nervous and I spoke my mind. As we sat there and chucked ourselves to sleep, I knew things would be different from here on out, and they were. We now have made that promise to one other and we are able to have wonderful smiling memories together now. Now at fifteen years old, I can honestly say without question my mom will always be my best and truest friend. Our bond, our way of getting over tough times, and the way we can laugh off all stressful things in life makes me feel as if I can get through anything. I've truly realized the meaning of the saying, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Laughter has indeed become the glue that holds our relationship together.

Why is it that laughter can bring people so close together? Is it because laughing shows trust for one another, or is it simply because you understand each other? There are many different kinds of laughter, like cracking a hilarious joke, or when someone does something extremely embarrassing. The story that I will be telling is about how such a bad day for hunting turned into the funniest moments ever.   It all started on that fateful morning when I woke up, and I had forgotten to transfer my wet clothes from the washer machine to the dryer. Now I had to rummage through all my clothes up in my room and find clean camouflage clothes that weren't dirty, or at least something that I could wear. By this time, anybody would be in a bad mood, and I was trying to rush to get out the door. When my buddy @PERSON1 showed up and was ready to go, but I wasn't. I was in a hurry, and when you rush, you are bound to forget something, and I had left my gun at the house. Five miles down the road, I noticed that I had forgotten my gun, so we turned around and went back to go get it. Not only were we now late, but we were speeding to the cabin for breakfast. @PERSON1 had the eggs so that we could make omelets. As we were racing down the road, we hit a bump, and everything, I mean everything, hit the ceiling in the truck and then slammed to the floor. In doing this, all the eggs broke in the egg carton, so now we had no eggs, and no eggs meant no breakfast.   It's about thirty minutes till shooting hours, and we are late showing up to the blind so that @PERSON1 and I can meet up with our other friends, @PERSON3 and @PERSON2. Finally, we get to the blind right before sunrise, and while we are getting all set up, a group of twenty mallards drop in unexpectedly and take off before we could get a shot off. Now we're all thinking, great, there goes our opportunity to redeem ourselves from a terrible morning. Only to find out that those ducks were the only ducks we saw all day.   At around twelve o'clock, we gave up and went back up to the cabin, but on the way up, we got stuck in two inches of water in the truck. I remember thinking to myself, "Oh no, this is not really happening to us right now". So @PERSON3, @PERSON2, and I got out of the truck to push, and @PERSON1 stayed in the truck to drive. There were many attempts to push the truck out, and finally, on the sixth try, we pushed the truck hard enough to get it out of the muddy water. Now the funny part, when we had freed the truck, @PERSON1 laid on the gas, causing the truck tires to spin and spray mud everywhere. When I saw the amount of mud being hurled everywhere, I jumped behind @PERSON2 and used him as a shield from the mud. By this point, @PERSON3 and @PERSON2 are covered in an inch-thick layer of mud from head to toe. You couldn't help but laugh; it was the funniest thing ever. @PERSON1 had watched it all through his rearview mirror, and as soon as he was safe from getting the truck stuck again, he fell out of the truck because he was laughing so hard. Even @PERSON3 and @PERSON2 were laughing a bit too.   So when it's a day when nothing goes your way or you're having bad luck, you never know what the day has in store for you. In this case, it was one of the most memorable things I remember that happened that duck season. It just goes to show that even in the midst of a bad day, a little laughter can turn things around and create memories that will last a lifetime.

@CAPS1 figure something out to do! I am really freaking bored!" @CAPS2 explained as all of us relaxed next to his dark blue @CAPS3, which was gracefully parked right outside of my house. All four of us quickly jogged over to the driveway of a house that was for sale right near the exit of my neighborhood where @CAPS2 was parked. "@CAPS17 you've waited long enough," @CAPS2 explained. "Well, we are all here! So @CAPS1, go to the intersection and set this up!" @PERSON1 explained as he started to lead us toward the intersection, which was about fifty yards away. I was guessing this was where all my friends were hiding. "Haha, this is perfect! I made sure everything feels right!" I explained as we all gazed upon the delicately hung wrap that ran from both sides of the two-way street. "@CAPS21 we must wait," @PERSON2 said as anticipation fell over us. Four heads bobbed up and down as we checked to see if cars were driving down the road. Since it was about @NUM2 pm, most of the good folk of @LOCATION1 were sleeping or inside. But suddenly, a car came out of nowhere, speeding and only @NUM3 yards from the great prank. "@CAPS22," I yelled as the car continued driving closer and closer. Boom! The car sped through the saran wrap and then came to a screeching stop. Laughter burst out as we inspected the target, which was completely in disarray. But the angry male driver, hearing our laughing, decided to leave his car and chase us! "@CAPS23 up," I screamed! We all ran right as the man reached the fence where we were hiding. Although it was too late for @CAPS6! The angry man caught him as the rest of us all high-tailed it for my house. As soon as we reached my house, we all began to ask ourselves what happened to @CAPS6! Suddenly, out of nowhere, @CAPS6 came running. As he finally reached us, we started to burst into laughter once again! As the exciting and long night wrapped up, we all called it quits and went to sleep at my house. Interesting flight. It was the @DATE1 of this @DATE2. After a long day filled with some crying, lots of goodbyes, I was finally in the airport, waiting for my plane to @LOCATION1. After a long conversation, she started reading a magazine, and I put on my music. When we were about to reach @LOCATION1, she all of a sudden screamed so hard that it made me jump. He was now working at a bank and making good money, really good money... She was going crazy talking to herself and asking why in the world she stopped talking with him.  That good time with her, even if I haven't seen her again, made me really happy. And by the time we got off the plane, I was more confident and almost forgot about all the nervousness that I felt before. After @NUM2 months here, everything is going perfectly. I'm sure that even if it was just a few laughs and not a really long time on that plane, when I go back to @LOCATION2 and think about this experience, I will think about her. I'll count that moment as my first good memory of this new adventure. It just goes to show that a little connection and laughter can make a big difference when stepping into the unknown.

Friends aren't always what we want them to be. They aren't always easy to find, but with a simple smile and a hearty laugh, a friendship can blossom. The next time I went to class, she was absent, so I was all alone that period. I had to be partners with this other girl named Savannah, who was a total girly - girl. She didn't want to ride the @CAPS2 at all; all she wanted to do was talk. I was fed up with her by the end of the day, and I hadn't practiced my unicycle riding. I was really hoping @CAPS3 would show up to class the next day, and thankfully, she did. This time, we had to team up with our partner and create a routine to a song of our choice, so we were pretty stoked. We started practicing and brainstorming when suddenly, we both tumbled. It was a normal, bright, and warm @DATE1 day as I was about to enter my fifth - grade year. My older sister and I had spent the whole day playing with our other neighbors who were around our age. One of those neighbors was a boy. We were at a loss for what to do. It was swelteringly hot outside, so going for a walk in the sun was out of the question. We decided it would be fun to play in the shade with the new slingshot my @CAPS1 had made. He crafted it out of an old swing - set seat, and I thought our neighbor would really enjoy it. We all made our way into our garage to get it. My sister offered to retrieve it for me since she was taller and it was hanging up pretty high, but I declined. It was my idea to show it to our neighbor, so I wanted to be the one to get it. As I focused intently, stretching and reaching to grab the slingshot, I noticed everyone around me snickering. My concentration started to waver as I wondered what they were all laughing at. I stood there, bewildered, for a moment before I discovered what had happened. My sister had pulled down my pants... right in front of our boy neighbor. I quickly picked my pants up off the ground, glared straight at my sister, and started weakly pounding her with my flimsy fists. I fled to my room, sobbing all the way. A few moments later, my sister came into my room. She tried to coax me out from under the covers with the last two fruit roll - ups. She sat on my bed, waiting patiently for half an hour, but I refused to budge. She didn't say a word, but I could feel her intense gaze through the sheets. Later that night, I finally emerged. My sister kept apologizing, but it didn't matter to me because I was still furious with her. The entire next day passed, and nothing had changed. She continued to apologize, and I remained in the ignoring mode. My @CAPS1 approached me and told me that my sister was terribly sorry and also upset because I wasn't talking to her. I thought to myself, "How could she be upset...?" but I realized that I hadn't treated her right, even though I was unhappy with her. After hearing what my @CAPS1 had said, I decided that it wasn't worth holding a grudge. I went to talk to my sister for the first time in days. She explained that she hadn't meant to hurt my feelings; she was just joking around. After discussing it for a while, I concluded that I'd gotten so upset because she'd done it in front of our friend. We often play around like that, but it's always just among family. I was worried that it might have scared our neighbor away, but he came back to play a few days later, so I had no reason to be mad. Even though I'd been embarrassed, I admitted that it was actually quite funny. We had a good laugh about it, and we were no longer at odds. I learned that dwelling on the past gets you nowhere, and you have to learn to laugh things off. Ever since then, every time the incident is brought up, we laugh so hard that tears stream down our faces. I wouldn't have considered it a good thing when it happened, but I do now. It's another memory that my sister and I share and can look back on fondly. The more laughable memories you share, the closer it brings you to someone.

There are numerous joys in life. Some are more significant than others, and some are so obvious that it would be foolish not to notice them. Have you ever sat on your porch or stared out of the window, watching the sun rise while reflecting on your life and its unique aspects? As you sit there, you think about all the wonderful memories, all the shared laughter, all the sorrows, all the pain, and all the love and hate. It's no surprise that almost everyone has done this at some point and wondered if they could change things, how they would do it, or if they would leave their life as it started, feeling that their life is complete and they are content without any regrets. For all the tears I've shed and all the pain I've endured, there has always been a laugh to overshadow the sadness. Sometimes, I too sit and ponder my life. Although I'm still young and many of my real experiences are yet to come, I've been through a fair amount in my short life. However, it doesn't trouble me because I've learned a great deal from what has happened. I've realized that no matter how hard you plan your life, there will always be unexpected events or people. All you can do is hope for the best and prepare for the worst. It's not difficult to be happy; just keep an open mind and a light heart. Soon, you'll find yourself laughing along with the world and relishing your time on this amazing planet we call @LOCATION1. So, listen to your parents or the person you admire most in life. There are many things that keep me going, like my boyfriend or my love for animals. But the most important thing isn't just one thing; it's a combination of things such as love, laughter, new beginnings, old endings, a bright and new path (all you have to do is take it), the unceasing nature of the universe, and the possibility that there @MONTH1 be other planets with life, perhaps even intelligent life. It's easy to find reasons to live and even easier to find reasons to sacrifice for. Hopefully, you'll focus on finding things to live for. I recall a time when things were tough, and I thought I'd never be happy again. I felt like I didn't belong in this world with all its confusing aspects. I was at a crossroads, or so I thought, but then something happened as I sat on the side of an old road. I looked up at the stars and wondered what I'd miss out on if I ended my journey then. What names would I give my children if I ever had the chance? Who would I marry, and would our love last? So, I finally decided that there was too much I'd miss if I ended my life so soon. After that fateful evening, I started to transform into a better person, longing for a bright future with a passionate love story to share with my children. With devotion, trust, and respect, I hope our love will endure. But that's not all I want my life to be about. I want to find inner peace in a noisy world. I want to help ensure that animals can coexist with us on this @LOCATION1, rather than being pushed aside or mistreated. I want to contribute to solving the pollution problem that we humans have largely caused. I know I'm just one person in this vast world, but even the smallest actions can make a difference. So, if I want to look back and laugh at my life, I'd better do my part in making this planet a shared and healthy home.

I never thought that laughing can help you start a conversation with someone you don't even know. But @CAPS4 truly can. Just by sharing a laugh with someone can get you to meet a new person. One of the things I do first when meeting someone who is trying to be funny is laugh. Once you understand what the other person is talking about, you forget that you are just getting to know that person. This happened to me once. It happened in @LOCATION1, a place where my family and I usually go every year in @DATE1. I made a great friend and the first thing we did was share a hearty laugh. As you know, @LOCATION1 is a sweltering place and the sun is usually out brightly every day. I remember it was a lovely day that my cousins, sister and I went to a small, cozy store that's right down the street from where we stay at. I couldn't help overhearing so I started to laugh heartily. One of his friends saw me laughing and he thought I was laughing at him. He asked me if I was laughing at him and of course I said no. I told him I had accidentally overheard his conversation so then he started to laugh. "That was funny wasn't it?" he told me laughing. "Yes it was. I didn't know you made jokes like that" I replied. He kept on talking to me and then he said, "I always talk like that so don't be afraid. I don't say things to hurt anyone." I thought it was nice for him to clear that out but I already knew people in @LOCATION1 talk like that. We kept on talking and then I started to laugh again. "What did I say now?" he asked. "Nothing. I was just remembering what you said in the beginning. That was really funny" I replied. For some reason I couldn't forget what he said and I don't think I will ever forget. I think it was probably because the way we met was really surprising to me. I had never met a person, especially a guy, by laughing first. I guess I thought it was a great way to start a conversation. Laughing with the person will let them know that we are interested in their subject and we understand them. That's at least what I thought. I had a good conversation with my new friend. We talked about how I was spending my vacations. I told him that every year I go and I always enjoy them. My family and I have a great time spending time with my grandparents and cousins from @LOCATION1. He agreed with me on one part of what I had told him because he knows what it's like to live in @LOCATION1, but he doesn't know how it's like to live in any other place. After he told me that, he stayed quiet for a couple of seconds. I noticed something instantly. I had noticed that our conversation wasn't like in the beginning. In the beginning, we wouldn't stop laughing and we had interesting stuff to say. Then, it got calmer and a little unusual. I didn't want to just stop our conversation there so I asked him where was he going to go because when I started talking to him, he was with one of my cousins and I was with my other cousins. Now we started laughing again. This time it was because we just had noticed that the people we were with had left us. "Where did they leave?" he asked me. "I don't know, but they can't be that far because we haven't been talking for a long time," I told him. We walked together to go and look for them and I was right. They weren't that far. They were still looking for things to buy and I don't think they noticed we were missing. We just got together with them and acted as if nothing had happened. It was strange for me because whenever I looked at him, I would remember our conversation. The first thing that would come to my mind was that we started our conversation by laughing at a funny thing he said. I actually liked making a new friend this way. Now, whenever I go to @LOCATION1, I know I have a new friend over there and if I decide to, I can make other friends by simply laughing with them in their conversations.

As I waited in the car, anxiously fidgeting, eager to meet my best friend and the man I'm in love with, I started to laugh nervously. Not because something my mother or brother said was funny, or because I saw something comical, but because I was extremely nervous. I'd talked to him countless times on the phone, exchanged many many text messages, and had numerous emails with him. But I was still a bundle of nerves. I knew him better than I knew most people, yet my anxiety seemed to be making me lose my composure. As our sleek black rental sedan pulled up to where he was waiting outside of where his family lived, I got even more nervous. What if he wasn't actually the way I thought he was? What if he didn't like me? What if I didn't like him? As soon as he stepped into the car, smiling brightly at me with his warm, friendly eyes, my nervous laughter and my anxiety all melted away like snow in the sun. I smiled back, my heart pounding. "Hello, @PERSON1," he said, his voice soft and gentle. "Hello @PERSON2," I said, butterflies fluttering wildly in my stomach. I was still smiling broadly. He reached out and cautiously took my hand, his touch sending a tingle up my arm. "How was the drive?" he asked, lightly squeezing my hand. "Long, and nerve - wracking," I replied, nervous laughter bubbling up again. "But you're here now, and I'm very happy you are," he said, smiling warmly. And for the rest of the car ride to the restaurant our conversation flowed so smoothly I thought I was in a dream. Here he and I were, two guys in love with one another, a new and exciting thing for both of us, and we were as happy as could be. The whole car ride we held hands and talked, I felt like I'd known him my whole life. Not just the year and a half I'd known him. We arrived at @ORGANIZATION1 all too soon and all of us got out of the car. I was famished and so was he. But we had to wait for a table for a half - hour before we sat down. Once at the dinner table, my mother, who was overjoyed that I found someone I loved so much and knew of our love, started regaling us with funny tales of my childhood. It was one of the most embarrassing moments of my life. I was bright red for almost the entire time she told these stories. Some of which I remembered vividly, others I did not. @PERSON2 laughed and joked with me about all of them. Which made my nervous laughter turn into genuine, hearty laughter. It also helped that he was holding my hand under the table, giving it a reassuring squeeze. After we ate a delicious dinner and scrumptious dessert we went to the nearby mall for some shopping and to just hang out. My mom and brother went one way, and @PERSON2 and I went another. We bought some trendy clothes together and finally ended up in a cozy book store. My favorite book store, @ORGANIZATION3's. Back in my favorite section, young adult fiction, I noticed @PERSON2 staring at me intently. "What?" I asked stupidly. He smiled deviously. "You just look very... In your element," he smirked. "Really?" I said, in mock confusion. He just smiled and took my hand in his again. "No problem," he said, squeezing my hand gently. He pulled me closer to him. We were the only people in this quiet area of the store. "Is it okay if I'm a little forward?" he asked. I shook my head yes. He leaned in and kissed me very gently on the lips. I blushed a bright red and started to giggle after our lips parted. He quirked an eyebrow, I knew what he was thinking just by the look on his face. "That felt fantastic," I said, putting my fingers on my lips. I had a silly grin on my face. "Good," he simply said, kissing me again. "I love your laugh, love," he told me. I was on cloud nine. I was truly in love with somebody and I felt great! I'd never been this happy before. Except maybe the first time I went to @ORGANIZATION2. But this was definitely better, because it could last much longer. Which it has, since we've been together ever since. Both our gazes were fixed on our future together. Now whenever I remember that moment, I start to giggle happily to myself. Yes, I get a strange stare every once in a while, but I don't care. Laughter is the thing that helped bridge the gap between him and I. Making us the closest we've ever been.

The name looked and sounded familiar because I used to go to school with a boy with the same last name. That's when I asked her to verify if it was the same family. Sure enough, it was. I had had a crush on this boy since I could remember. We lost contact after I had found out he liked my cousin though. We did our rounds and everything went very smoothly. We were having tons of fun, making jokes and laughing at absolutely everything. Then it came time to go to "his" house. We all choked up. The girls had heard many things about how cute and dream like this boy was so they were all nervous too. We were sitting there in the truck telling ourselves he wont be home, and even if he was it would be fine and we would be fine. I think that was the longest walk to a house with that short of a walk way ever. My grandma rang the door bell and we positioned ourselves to be ready to sing when the door opened. To our dismay, he answered it. We froze! We were like gargoyles gawking at him. He gave us a weird look and said " @CAPS3 you going to sing or just stand there?" with an evil little smile. I did attempt to sing, but nothing came out. That's when the youngest cousin starts singing happy birthday. That was not the song we had planned for this house, and it was not his birthday. In the middle of the second "happy birthday to you" we all start cracking up laughing, and I don't mean giggling or a small laugh. We @CAPS3 all laughing hysterically to the point where we could not breath, and he shut the door.  I know if we would have just stood there it would have made that memory a lot more dreadful, but because we all were laughing, we can look back and laugh at ourselves for it. Laughing is a good way to release inner emotional pressure I realized that night. It's a memory i'm sure we will never forget. I have done something like that on multiple occasions but that was defiantly number one on my list of "what were you thinking" moments. I wouldn't change anything about it.

Laughter is always the key to complete happiness. All you really have to do is laugh to be happy. I remember back in the third grade, I was the new student. I can clearly tell you that I didn't know where anything really was. It was a brand - new school: a new bus route, new classrooms, new everything. Being the new student is something no one wants to be. You get made fun of a lot, and sometimes you just don't fit in. Well, that's my story. I never fit in right away.   One day, I was walking up the stairs to my class. It was a bright sunny day, and I don't believe there really were any clouds in the sky that day. Anyways, as I was walking up the stairs, I tripped and fell backwards. My skirt, which I was wearing, flipped up over my head. And of course, in that era of time, you had to have character underpants. Well, I remember everyone pointing and laughing at me. A. because I had just fell down, and B. because I was wearing Dora underpants. Therefore, I went the whole day with everyone laughing at me. But to tell you the truth, I laughed right along with them. I honestly thought it was pretty funny. Falling down and your underpants showing? Who doesn't think that's funny?   After the fact, this girl named Sarah came up to me and told me I'm not the only one who wears character underpants. We both laughed as hard as we could that whole day, just remembering the fact that me of all people, I fell down the stairs! Next, being the new kid could actually be embarrassing, but for me, I've done it a million times, so it really didn't bug me as much as people thought it would. Sarah and I became such great friends. We laughed all the time. Like when we went to the park and she fell in the ice - cold water, or back to the time where I fell down the stairs. Up to this day, we still talk about that. It's just something you really don't get over. Not to mention it was pretty funny when my character underpants showed.   In conclusion, I think when the quote says "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people" really is true. You have to have a good laugh before you can go on with your day. It's just a known fact. If you don't laugh throughout your day, then something is really wrong with you. Just because you're getting older doesn't mean you have to throw away your laugh. Laughing is the part of the day where you can do whatever you want. So you tell me what is your funny story?

However, we all had two important things in common; our sick sense of humor and our intelligence.  We each felt that the work we were teaching ourselves was much too easy. We breezed right through the book and never really had any questions. That doesn't necessarily mean that that's the order things played out in. "@PERSON4, I don't feel like doing math @DATE2. I'm beat," I complained as we walked into @PERSON1's room for math right after lunch. "@CAPS6 neither," she replied. "I say we just sit there and make it look like we're doing work." "@CAPS8 uh, I was talking to @LOCATION1 @TIME1 and he said that we don't have to do any work @DATE2. We can just sit here and hang out," I lied, not even bothering to hide my smirk. Catching on, @CAPS3 and @PERSON3 grinned. @PERSON3 turned around and pulled a brown paper bag out of her backpack. She began to pull food out of the bag and offered it all up to us. I immediately grabbed the miniature chocolate pie. Midway through eating it, I dipped my finger in the gooey chocolate and wiped a big blob of it on the window behind @CAPS6. @PERSON4 noticed and immediately started to chuckle. "@CAPS10, what's that?!" she exclaimed, loud enough for everyone in the class to hear. @PERSON1 and a few classmates glanced over briefly, but got back to the lesson instantly. It really wasn't funny at all, but the four of us dissolved into giggles. "@CAPS11 guys, I had @TIME1 crazy dream @TIME2," @PERSON3 said as the laughter died down. "I went to @TIME1 @DATE1 camp thing, and @PERSON2 was one of the camp counselors. He was wearing khaki pants and a white shirt with blue pinstripes. Oh, and he also had a clipboard!" We stared at her blankly and then burst out laughing once more. The funny thing about @TIME1, was that @PERSON2 often substituted for our teachers, and he wore that exact outfit each time. But the even funnier thing was that it really wasn't funny at all. We were @CAPS8 desperate for a good time, we found chocolate blobs on windows and khaki pants to be hilarious. Our laughter died down and we sat there in silence. Suddenly, @CAPS3 leaned back in his squeaky swivel chair and it immediately broke, dropping him right to the ground. To anyone else, @TIME1 would have been funny. However, we each sat in silence, staring at one another. It wasn't that we were embarrassed for him or felt sympathy, but simply ironic that obsolete things sent us into fits of giggles, while a substantial, laughable event made us simply sit there. I don't think I'll ever forget the @ORGANIZATION2. Though it was a waste of time, we had many good laughs. We @MONTH1 not have learned a lot about math, but we learned a lot about each other.

Many of my friends burst out to laughter. People always say that laughing can have many benefits. The truth, I believe, is that laughter is not always the best thing. Laughing can have many different meanings. When I think of laughter, I think of smiles, true happiness, and precious memories. Although, there is one memory of laughter that does not prove that to be true. "Mom, I really don't wanna be here. I don't know that I can stay here and tell him this," I pleaded to my friend's mother to let me go back home. "You need to do this honey. It's for the best." At that point I had always thought my friend's mother knew best. Now, I wasn't so sure. I sat patiently, trying hard to hold back tears, waiting for my friend's father to get back to his house. I knew he was at the bar, and silently thanked him that I had time to think. I was supposed to go tell him how I felt about him always drinking alcohol. Every time I went over there I saw him either drunk, or on his way to being drunk. The truth is, I was scared. I was scared for his health and scared that I was the reason for his drinking. I was getting older and needed to tell him what I thought and how I felt. While distracted by this realization, he came storming through the door. I looked up at my friend's drunk father and my heart dropped. I burst out in tears while my friend's mother held me in her arms. "It's... it's alright," she soothed. My friend's father looked at me without any recognition and went into the other room. I walked in the room where he was and watched cautiously at him through the open doorway. He wasn't the man my friend's mother had once married anymore. He had become a monster. I couldn't stand it anymore. I walked into the room where my friend's mother waited with worry in her eyes. "Let's go home," I said. On the way home I sobbed until my shirt was streaked with tears. The car ride home was silent and the thoughts and sadness hung thick in the air. I could barely sleep that night. The sun shone down on my face as I awoke to a new day. I felt confident and ready to go back and confess to my friend's father how I've felt all along. We drove back to his house and when we pulled into the drive way, nervousness rushed through me. I wobbled up to the door and knocked. "Hi. Hey." It made me upset that my friend's father was acting as if nothing was wrong. I walked in, with confidence, and asked him to sit down. I was content with the fact that I had caught him in one of this rare moments of not being drunk. "Sir, we really need to talk. I feel as though you are making a huge mistake by drinking. I know you're addicted and there are risks with stopping but you're also endangering your health!" I basically screamed at him. I poured out my heart as a whole new wave of tears rushed over me. By the time I was done my friend's father sat there with a blank look pasted on his face. He laughed. "Your mother told you to tell me this stuff. Don't worry about it. Your mom doesn't know what she's talking about." My jaw dropped as he acted as though this wasn't serious. Anger boiled in me. "You don't even know me! You don't even care about me!" I screamed then stormed out. I went into the living room and looked straight at my friend's mother and somehow she knew exactly that I wanted to leave. This time the car ride, again, seemed to be filled with silence. Thinking about how laughter is almost always a great thing, I started to cry because, just once, laughing didn't mean happiness. It meant tears. Laughter, in this instance, was a cruel mask hiding the pain and reality.

Laughter, often a sign of joy and mirth, can sometimes carry a deeper, more complex meaning. "Honey, we've got something to tell you." I knew exactly what they were about to tell me. I saw the signs. I knew that when they went into the other room, it wasn't for some quality time together. They were getting a divorce and the time to tell me had come. As each of my parents gathered around me, I knew that they were about to say something I wasn't ready to hear. The words "We are getting a divorce," rang in my head like church bells when a couple is getting married. The happiest sound one could ever hear. But that was the exact opposite of what was going on right now. As I looked up into the face of my mother, I could tell she had been crying. Where the blue, gray mixture used to meet and become one, her eyes had turned red and irritated. It killed me inside to see her crying, and while this was happening my dad just sat on the couch near me with his head buried in his hands. I could tell that he was thinking that he was so in love and that it all just went downhill, leaving him with an intense feeling of resentment and anger towards my mother. The love of his life, was now his enemy. At seven I couldn't fully wrap my mind around what was happening to our family. I got that one parent would move away, that I wouldn't always get tucked into bed at night by a duo of love, I just didn't understand why this had to happen. My poor little brother. Only four, how could they possibly explain this to him. If I was confused, he had to be off on another planet. At the thought of my family crumbling before my eyes, I wanted to cry. I wanted to go far, far away from the troubles occurring at home. If a genie had been there to grant my three wishes, I would have used all three of them if I thought there would be a possibility to save my parents' relationship. Crying just seemed so much easier than sitting in the living room listening to my parents say, "It's not your fault, don't blame yourself, this is between your father and I." Why did they think those statements made it better? Because it really didn't help. My parents had fallen out of love with each other, and the hope I had that they would get back together was diminishing faster than the amount of rain forest left in Brazil. Plus, there was still the underlying factor that my home was broken. And more importantly than my home, my heart. It was broken and I didn't think there was enough super glue in the whole world to pull the pieces back together. Just when it felt like the whole world was going to crash down upon me, my mother said something to me that I will never forget. "When you feel like crying, laugh. Remember all the good times that we spent together as a family." One by one, each memory began to flood back into my mind. The time dad jumped into the pile of leaves we had collectively raked. The time mom and I made sugar cookies in the winter that ended up burnt, but still made the whole house feel warm and familiar. And especially the wedding that brought the two of them together in matrimony. That sacred bond that only ministers can ensue on people. The one that forever changed their lives and mine. I began to laugh, and then to cry. My parents weren't sure what to think about my sudden change of emotion. They asked, "What's wrong, sweetie?" And I, still thinking that none of these memories would be had again, I then realized something. I realized that even though my family wouldn't be together all the time, that we would still laugh. That when someone slipped on a piece of paper, it would be funny. My tears had stopped spewing out of my eyes like a dam in desperate need of repair, and the realization had finally set in that we would be okay. That with laughter in our lives, and memories in our hearts, we would survive this. From then on, I solely believed in that one statement spoken to me by my mother. "When you feel like crying, laugh." The statement that said to me, it's okay to be sad, but that as long as you have laughter in your life, everything will be alright. In my heart, I applauded my mom for handling that situation so well. If it had not been for her, I would have kept on with the water works and never stopped for just a second to think about all the hilarious times we had had together. So, as far as laughter goes, don't forget to just take a moment out of every day to remember each punch line to every corny joke, because laughter truly is a healing force.

Laughter, the sense of pure happiness. You are in the moment and nothing else matters, all your worries and stress fall away leaving you with your true happy self. Have you ever had those moments when everything seems too much? Then a friend says something that makes you laugh, once you're done laughing you start to cry because it felt so good to laugh. Or when you laugh so hard you fall to the floor and can't get up for what seems hours? Yet looking back you forget what was so funny. Laughter is magical, second only behind love. Those two seem to go hand in hand. When you love someone, not just your boyfriend/girlfriend but your friends and family too, you know how to make them laugh or cheer them up, how to have fun with them, and that brings you even closer together. When I'm with my close friends the one thing we seem to do most is laugh. We laugh about anything and everything that is even slightly funny. It brings us closer together, sharing a moment of pure joy. The six of us are very close and will be friends after high school is over, even if we go to colleges a thousands of miles away. It is because we have shared so many happy memories. Laughter is important in a relationship. We trust each other and can share anything with them even our most important secrets. This story is how we came to be so close. Brightly colored fancy dresses and killer high heels were splayed out across the room. Open soda cans and chip bags were scattered about. The faint smell of nail polish, flowery perfume, and deodorant lingering in the air. Laughter and giggles bubbling throughout the room with the occasional squeal. Pitch black outside but light and warm inside. Six of us lounging around the room. Smeared makeup and deflating hair. Sweat pants and baggy t-shirts. We all went from looking our very best to... not, within a few minutes. Yet not one of us cared. When looking at each other we were able to look past appearances and have fun with each other, not their looks. We had just gotten back from the prom. None of us had had dates but we still managed to have the time of our lives. "Did you see him! He was dancing with her!" "I wouldn't really call that dancing...." she made a pelvic thrust, we all burst into a new round of giggles and shouted stuff like, "Get a room!" We gossiped about what we saw, who was with who, pretty dresses, hot guys, creeper guys, slow dances, the music, even how we hid our cups so we would know which one was ours when we wanted to use it again. We had all been friends, but recently we had been becoming closer. Starting to move from friends to best friends. It was at least two in the morning. Everyone was exhausted but was forcing themselves to stay up with caffeine and sugar. You might ask why, but I'm not really sure. Maybe because we always seem to have so much to talk about, because we enjoy each other's company, or just because we can, so why not? "I think we need a picture, a picture of the six of us." I said. "Yes!" "Great idea!" "Now? I'm a mess!" "I've got just the thing!" Sarah takes off running upstairs to grab something. "Where should we sit?" "On the bed?" "Come on, move over fatties!" "Hey! I'm not fat, I'm festively plump!" We all cracked up at the reference of Thanksgiving as we started to squeeze into a corner of the squishy full size bed. Sarah and Sarah's mom arrive back into the room. Sarah was carrying an old Polaroid camera that prints out the picture immediately after you took it. She gave the camera to her mom and jumped onto the bed. We all squished together, barely enough room to breathe. "One...Two...Three!" Click! the picture came out. "Let's take one more while the first is developing. Again, one... two... three!" Click! Click! "Oh no!!!" We all screamed in unison. The bed broke! we had broken the bed! We all sat there clinging to each other in total shock. "Our bed! You girls are faaaaat..." Sarah said while trying to contain a giggle. Suddenly we were in hysterics. Even Sarah's mom was laughing. We were one big throbbing pile of laughter. Only the corner of the bed had broken so we were all pulled down into that corner. Then someone started tickling, it was war. Every girl for themselves. It was a mass of bedsheets, wiggling fingers, bare feet, and a whole lot of laughing. "Look, the pictures have developed." The first one showed us sitting together smiling, but the second one was taken just as the bed broke. It showed the shock on our faces as we held onto each other for support. Not only did it bring us literally closer together but it solidified our amazing friendship. Laughter truly is the glue that binds us.

A @CAPS1 @CAPS2. I once heard "laughter is the best medicine." I whole - heartedly believe that is true.
