A day with the family One sunny day, my cousin, her husband, my mom, my dad, and I decided to go out to eat at @ORGANIZATION2 for a delicious breakfast. They had all grown up together in the same neighborhood, and as they sat around the table, telling stories about the old days, it made them all eager to hang out more often. They always had so much fun together, reminiscing about their childhood escapades. I grew up with my cousins around a great deal of the time. We would always hang out at each other's houses, playing games and having a blast. As we sat there, we started talking about all the crazy times we had shared, and it was truly nice to hear about those long - gone days. We were just laughing up a storm, enjoying each other's company.  All of a sudden, out of nowhere, my cousin @PERSON1 let out a loud fart. All of us immediately started busting up laughing. @PERSON1 continued to fart while she was uncontrollably laughing, her face turning red from the effort. So many people were looking at us in the restaurant, probably wondering what on earth was so funny. Here was a group of people all laughing hysterically, and one of them couldn't stop farting. The laughing got louder as well as the farting, creating quite a ruckus. My mother could not take it anymore. She took one of the salt shakers and started pounding it on the table, hoping to drown out the sound of @LOCATION1's farts. @PERSON1 was beat red with embarrassment. We were all laughing so hard that we started crying. We were almost to the point where we were going to pee ourselves.  @PERSON1 could not hold it any longer. She finally stopped farting, but now she had to pee so bad that she could not even walk properly. When she got up to go to the bathroom, she had to walk there cross - legged and very slowly. All the way there, she was still laughing, and we were also laughing at her funny gait. We had fun watching her have to stop every so often so that she would not pee on herself. One time that she had to stop, it was right on these two guys' chairs. She just stood there laughing cross - legged over these two guys, trying her best not to pee. The guys did not really do anything; they just sat there waiting for her to go away. We could tell they were very uncomfortable though. I told my mom, "I would be uncomfortable too if I had some random girl bent over me laughing and trying not to pee. I'm surprised they did not move. I would have."  Finally, @PERSON1 got to the bathroom. Those two guys had left, and when she came out, she was glad to see them gone. When we saw her, we could not help but laugh. She laughed with us, so we did not feel bad about laughing. People were still looking at us, and @PERSON1 was still blushing. She wanted to go, so we left and talked about it the whole way home. They were coming over to our house to play board games.  When we got home, my brother joined us in a game of gestures. This game is kinda like charades. We got into teams. I was on @ORGANIZATION1 and my brother's team. My brother went first. He started melting to the ground in a very exaggerated way. I shout out, "Wicked witch of the west!" He frowns at me and says, "Hey, watch before you shout things out." So I sat there and watched. He did his whole melting thing again, but when he got to the floor, he started rolling and jerking around. I was so confused. My cousin shouts out, "Poop!" My brother yells, "No, why would anyone want to be poop!" We all start laughing, and he just tells us what he is. He was a waterfall.  It was my turn to go, and I got horse. I did not want to be a horse. I did not even know how to be a horse without making a sound. I went up there and started hopping around like an idiot. I felt so dumb. My team - mates made me feel even worse because they could not guess what I was for the life of them. The buzzer rang, and we lost the game by two points. My brother hates to lose. He got really mad and ran up the stairs. On his way up there, he trips on his face and falls down the stairs. We all started laughing, and that made my brother even more mad. He went up the stairs again without falling this time and stayed in his room the rest of the day.  The rest of us stayed downstairs and played more games. It was a really fun day. I got to hang out with the family and get a great laugh. Hanging out with the family is something everyone should love. It is one of those things that just make you feel good.

Laughter is important, we all know that. It makes life easier, happier, and even helps you live longer. It's also very important in relationships. When talking about preferences in significant others, it's often that people mention that they want someone who can make them laugh, and this is the reason. This story, however, is not about dating. It is about how laughter can cause you to go from hating someone one moment to being their best friend the next.  I had known @PERSON1 for a few months at this point. I had met him on the bus during my daily commute. He was pale, skinny, and very loud. He always had something funny and offensive to say, and he was a bit of a shut - in, spending most of his free time indoors. Before I met @PERSON1, I could dish out jokes but couldn't take it when others made fun of me.  I remember one day, the day I went from hating him to befriending him. We were having a heated argument about something so insignificant that I can't for the life of me remember what it was. Although I do remember what he said. He said that I was a "hypocritical, arrogant asshole who would go around making fun jokes at other people's expense but would get up in someone's face if they tried one at me." This made me laugh. Not because everything he said was right, but because it made me realize that @PERSON1 was actually a pretty good guy whose only real problem was that he didn't know when to shut up.  Throughout the whole time I have known @PERSON1, he has never stopped smiling. He laughs off everything, from stepping in dog crap to dealing with his father's drug addiction. He can dull the pain of any blow with laughter. @PERSON1 is my constant reminder to never stop laughing, as laughter can truly change perspectives and bring people closer.

Laughter is good for everyone. It helps the body be more awake. In fact, believe it or not, laughter is an exercise for the body. When you laugh, your facial muscles move, your diaphragm contracts, and your heart rate increases, all of which are signs of a mini - workout. Laughter clears the body when people are really stressed out. It's like a natural release valve, allowing pent - up tension to escape. It is not just good for you but also, when others see you laughing, it also gives another person courage to do the same. A shared laugh can create a positive atmosphere and make a difficult situation seem more bearable. Laughter truly has the power to uplift spirits and bring people together, making it an essential part of a healthy and happy life.

Laughter is a powerful medicine. We have all been there, I know we have. We all have. We have all been that kid that just did not feel like helping your nagging parent out. Especially when your dad had been in a huge motorcycle wreck and you had been waiting on him hand and foot the entire visit at the hospital. Your dad had gone through a couple of surgeries and was put on a lot of medications for his injuries. I had noticed that your dad was not really himself on all these pills. His abnormality was taking a toll on the family. Through all these stressful times, we were also worried about your step - mother. She was pregnant with her second child. There was also the stress of having your father's business being the main income, and him not being able to work. Your father felt helpless; his leg was too weak for him to be doing anything. He would micromanage everything and tell you that you were doing things all wrong. This was starting to cause a lot of tension within the house.  Today was the day. Isabelle (your little sister) and I were left alone with your dad for the first time. I was going to the kitchen to get scissors for an art project we were doing in your room. Father asked if I could make him some oatmeal. Of course, with full hands, I said, "Sure, but I will when I'm done." Your father took that as disrespect and hobbled over to me with his crutches. He was yelling at me, which was upsetting, so instead of fighting back, I headed to your room. The anger in his voice was excruciating. I turned around, told him to stop yelling, and headed back to your room.  That's when it happened. Your father hooked the end of a little kids' chair and flung it down the hallway. It bounced off the walls, breaking an outlet shell, putting a hole in the wall, and hitting your knee. I didn't say anything, being afraid of what would happen next. Slamming the door, luckily I had the phone, and I called your grandmother. I told her on a voice mail that I wanted her to pick me up and take me to her house. She showed up an hour or so later not knowing I left a voice mail. I explained what happened, and she comforted your sister and me, telling us it would be okay.  Your grandmother sat us all in the living room to try and resolve the situation. By then, your dad had come to his senses and apologized to both of us. He used popcorn and candy to make us forgive him, then he started making fun and telling jokes. Every time there is a fight or disagreement, your dad always cracks a few jokes to get us in a better mood. The one thing different this time is after he told some jokes, he apologized again. This time, explaining why he was sorry. I liked that, which made the rest of the day quite a joy.  "Doctors say that laughter is a powerful medicine. Ten minutes of laughter is equal to two hours of relaxation." A health expert on a radio service talked about this. Laughter can truly mend a broken heart. The stress that you and your sister went through that day was all over after the laughter your father gave us. "Laughter can save us," he also stated. After this day, I believe with a little humor, your father and my relationship can get through anything. I would never let one mistake control a lifetime bond. Laughter will always be in our hearts, helping us overcome difficult times.

Laughter plays an important role in relationships. It also supports enjoyment and can be a pursuit of happiness. Or who knows, if you laugh hard enough, you might even pull a "whotammy" (whatever that is!), and trust me, that does not look pretty, and then you will be embarrassed in front of everybody.  My favorite comedian is Adam Sandler because he is very funny and has a good sense of humor. He knows how to keep a person laughing and interested in his comedy shows and movies. When he made the "Big Daddy" movie, it was pretty good. It wasn't extremely funny but still had its moments. So we all pretty much understand what laughing is, but most people don't really seem to laugh at things that are funny. I can't quite understand it, but my guess is that they don't have a good sense of humor. But some people seem to laugh at things that don't even make sense. I quite don't understand that either, but I guess it's better to laugh than to not laugh at all.  Some really good comedy movies that I can mention right off the bat that will keep you tuned and laughing through more than half of the movies are "Grandma's Boy," "Happy Gilmore," "Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Sipping My Juice," and "Zombieland." "Zombieland" is a heck of a good movie. It's not just about making a funny movie just to make the audience laugh. It's the way they make it, how they act, and how good the background story to the comedy movies is gonna be. That's what I pay attention to whenever I sit down and inspect what makes the movie funny. Also, if I can't understand a funny movie, I watch it again and again till I understand what is so hilarious about it.  That pretty much covers the basics on laughter. There is your basic information about what it is and how to enjoy it and use it wisely. Remember, don't laugh too hard because you don't want to end up pulling a "whotammy" in front of everyone around. Thank you for reading my text.

Laughter" - I firmly believe that laughter is the shortest distance between two people. When things between you and a loved one get a bit fuzzy, making them laugh will always help break the ice. Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship." Many other people firmly believe that laughter is an essential and significant part of any relationship. I also whole - heartedly agree with those thoughts.  I came to New York about two years ago. At that time, I did not speak English at all. I started going to school. I carefully practiced saying my name, age, and where I came from before I went to school. The next day I walked into school and I could clearly see that everyone was looking at me. It was pretty scary to me. I looked back at one girl and she walked towards me.  "Hi, my name is Lily," the girl said with a warm smile. "Hi, my name is Mia. I'm from Japan. I don't really speak English," I said to Lily, then Lily started laughing so hard, her eyes crinkling with amusement. "Oh - oh you have an accent," Lily said, "it's really cute." I laughed back, feeling a bit more at ease. Lily looked really nice with her smiles on and we became friends so quickly. She was my first American friend ever.  I always thought that making new friends was hard, but the laughter made it much easier than it used to be. Laughter truly has the power to break down barriers and build new connections, making relationships more fulfilling and enjoyable.

Laughter is the best way to show someone that they are funny. It is also the most effective way to relax. Everyone often says that hearing a baby laugh is an absolute delight. Watching comedians performing their acts can cheer people up and have them start laughing heartily. Laughter is the best way to relax and here are three reasons for that. First, no one can stay angry at the person making them laugh. When someone is laughing, the negative emotions just seem to melt away. Second, when someone laughs, everyone around that person starts laughing too. It's like a contagious wave of joy. Third and last reason, no one can stay sad when something funny is happening. The power of humor can quickly turn a gloomy mood around. What do you think when you hear a baby's laughter? I think that the baby is truly loved by its family. He or she is having a blast playing with someone in the family or even by themselves. They think that whatever you are doing is funny. A comedian's job is to make a crowd of people laugh at or with them. One way a comedian does an act is stand - up comedy. That is when a comedian is on stage and does his or her act, using their wit and charm to entertain the audience. Another way is a comedy. A comedy can be a TV show, a play, or a movie. Comedies usually do not have a complex plot, but the point is to make you and anyone else start laughing. That is what I think about laughter. It helps anyone relax. Hearing a baby's laugh is great. Comedians love to hear people laugh at or with them. Laughter truly is a universal language that brings people together and lightens up our lives.

The incident only happened a few weeks ago on a day when all the students were supposed to be out having fun or sleeping because there was plenty of snow outside. A guy was crying on his chair with his hands firmly over his eyes, a french horn in his lap and his gaze fixed on the ground below him. Sobs choked the sound in the band room but luckily for this guy's pride there weren't too many people in the room to start off with. The guy's head slowly rose up, the tears seemed to eat away at the self - sturdiness of his normal self, and he spoke to the person who always sat to his left. " They just don't understand, Mark" the broken, voice cracked on words "I don't care that they play in cascade winds or that they get private lessons or that they've gone to state honor band! This might sound like a terrible reason, but I just want to play first because I want to play first, and they never let us play first." He was right about one thing, Mark really never let us play first. I somehow understood where he was coming from; back in my freshman year I had always sat under him, and him under someone else and so forth. I had never seen him be first chair on anything. And now on his senior year, a prodigy child had come into band and she only knew how to fight for her position as first chair. In short, his four hard years of working for the first chair spot in band were summed up to being second best the moment she stepped in the room. The feeling of all his hard work turning into mediocrity in his face, with time, had broken him to tears.  The prodigy, Lisa, was much better than us and she has the accolades to prove it. She had attended cascade winds solo ensemble festival, band camp, and would be going to Paris as an ambassador of music. Still something about her having first part still didn't feel quite right. Maybe it was my sense of wanting superiority as well. Lisa took in the words, leaned closer to say. " I understand that you want first" with confident tones she said "but right now we need specific players in specific spots. I've played harder music and my skills are what's needed on first part. I understand what you're feeling, I've been there before."  It struck me weird that a sophomore was telling this to a senior. How could she have felt what he was feeling? She'd been a prodigy child in band from the start. I sided with him but then I realized that letting him play a more demanding part would be worse for the band. So I tried siding with Lisa but then all I could think about was that this was his last year to shine as a high - school french horn player. They kept going at each other. Every comment scraping at the already fragile surface of the argument. Minutes made the quarrel more and more volatile.  I had to think faster. If the argument continued like this the horn section would be torn apart and co - operation would be useless. More importantly I would lose two partners that together had uprooted a great deal of musical talent. I slid my chair next to them to tell them my thoughts. "If a man has no socks," I liked starting out my thoughtful speeches with mysterious beginnings, " then so will..." And that's as far as I got. I thought it was brilliant, their faces said otherwise. So they called me crazy and giggled as they made fun of me and laughed. Thankfully I was oblivious of the stuff they called me because I really wanted to remember what I wanted to say. He stopped crying, finally, and Lisa got my message that he was a senior and didn't really have many more chances at playing first chair in high - school band. They settled the fight with a simple deal; he would get first chair as soon as we stopped competing. After that, I've been the center of being made fun of. But as annoying as it gets sometimes it's usually funny for everyone, including myself.  I can't even begin to imagine what band would be like if their enmity had risen to the no - forgiveness zone. There had been times before when heated discussions left the stress levels in our section so high that it made it hard to breathe right. Having laughter come in even right before they were about to rip each other's faces off gave them time to understand that they had mutual understanding of each other. Or opened their eyes to how long they're going to have to sit next to each other if they were to continue fighting. Either way, this incident has definitely changed the way they feel about each other; I haven't heard them complain about one another for a while. He is eagerly awaiting his turn to shine and Lisa for better or worse can't wait to see him play.

We're happy together, Tom told me as we lay on his bed. I just smiled and I knew this was going to be a really good relationship. He always made me feel so great. He made me feel beautiful. Now don't say you're too young to know what love is, I've heard it from my mom every time I talked about him. But I know that no one has ever made me feel this wonderful about myself, made me feel perfect. When we are together it's a lot of fun. Most guys I have been with have not been this much fun, especially in our dates together, like walking to the park to sit and talk, or eating out and then kissing in public. Before we were ever dating, we were best friends. We still are best friends. Everyone asked us if we were dating, The answer was always no, we're best friends, but I always wanted more. We wouldn't have made such a strong couple if we didn't make each other laugh. Just thinking about the moment I first knew I loved him makes me laugh. I was walking to my math class, and out of nowhere Tom grabs my arm and pulls me into a huge bear hug, and buried his head in my neck and laughed and said "Hey, you have some toilet paper sticking out of your pants" I felt my face turn twenty different shades of red. I smiled and quietly asked him to hide me so I could grab it. When I got to my math class I was thinking to myself why could he just say that to me, he must of wanted to embarrass me. But the more I thought about what he did and why he did it made me feel, well it made me feel like he really and truly cared about me. Wanting to help me out rather than embarrass me. I bet every other guy was laughing. Not Tom... well after that happened we had a good laugh. After we laughed and joked about what happened to me, he looked up and kissed me. I didn't know if that was a best - friend kiss, or a real love kiss. So I simply laughed. then he kissed me again. This time I knew it was a real love kiss. We weren't like most couples either. Which made us stand out, and the more we stood out the more people started to hate the fact that we were together. They would say some horrible things to me in the hallway about Tom. Who knows what they were telling him. Even some of my closest friends started to make rude comments toward me and Tom. I know he didn't believe anything they were saying because he would laugh at everything people would toss our way. When he laughed I would always ask him what's so funny, he would say "If the rumors aren't true then laugh about them, that way people will know you're not bothered by them" I would have never thought about that. I'm the kind of girl who wears her emotions on her sleeve, so of course I would get a little peeved with all the stuff they were saying about us. After I started laughing at all the rude and nasty things people were saying, they stopped talking about us, it was like magic. I never thought about being in college, let alone finding a guy that would understand what I'm going through. Let alone someone who is going through something almost as difficult. My brother went to prison last year, and I don't think I could have been able to make it through as much as I did without Tom. I cried almost every day at college with him. It's been about a year now. Every time I go see my brother I remember what Tom said

I wholeheartedly agree when people say laughter is what mostly brings people together. In my opinion, most of the time when you're talking to someone, laughter is essential. It is what dispels the dullness from a person and makes the conversation truly engaging. Only when you are talking about something truly serious do you not need to include laughter, but I'll explain that later. So I can easily share a true story about laughter from my life. Right now, I have a wonderful group of friends. Sure, there are times when they mess up and act like kids, but I feel like I need to forgive them and remember that they are there for me when I really need them. Anyways, I can vividly remember the first time I met each one of them, and the one thing that kick - started our friendship was a joke. I can't exactly recall which joke we shared, but I do remember that we all had the exact same taste in comedy. And once we realized that neither of us were serious and dull individuals, it made us eager to spend more time with each other. That is why laughter builds a strong bond between different people and brings them closer together day by day. So as time went by, my friends and I were really drawn to each other. What I mean is that, from time to time, we were happy to express our friendship through jokes. Sometimes the jokes are really silly. Many of them have caused physical pain and have led us to seek revenge on each other. But that is just how we stay close to each other. Day by day, when we come across something funny on the television, internet, or in real life, we always show it to each other, knowing that after showing this prank or whatever it is, the other person will find it extremely funny. It makes us feel more connected and assures us that we all share a common interest in at least one area. I can give one clear example of this: I was watching a comedy show once, and the comedian was talking about his childhood and a prank he once played on a stranger's house. Right when I saw this video, I knew right away that my friends had to see it because I knew from past experiences that they enjoy these types of laughs. And I was right. As soon as they saw the show, they were amazed at how funny it was, and they were grateful that I shared it with them. We grew closer than ever. I want to share one more example from my life about laughter bringing two people closer. So after telling you that laughter helps me get closer to my friends, I also want to point out that laughter brings out a sense of connection when you talk to girls - or boys, if you're a female. So I met this one girl, and every time I talked to her, I had to throw in a joke or a story that was relevant to our subject. After a while, she started joking around and making up stories too. She told me that she saw me as a different kind of guy compared to others. She said that I wasn't a boring person, and it made her want to keep talking to me. Now, me and this girl are extremely close, and it all started with laughter. So as you can see, laughter makes any relationship happier and more open. Of course, I'm talking about relationships that are light - hearted. There are people out there who take everything seriously and can't take a joke. But I would really encourage you to embrace laughter in your life if you haven't already. Look at my life; I used laughter, and I gained a lot of great friends, of all sorts - just by joking around about silly things. You don't have to say the most brilliant things, but I say it would really make your life more interesting if you use laughter.

Trust is a huge deal between friends. True friends not only agree on the same things but also openly share an honest opinion about them, thereby maintaining the trust within a great friendship. You never know who can whole - heartedly stay by you with unwavering trust. When you trust a friend, you rely on them to keep things confidential between the two of you. Just like my friends and I, we firmly agreed on telling each other every single thing that has happened and promised never to lie about anything. Our friendship has always thrived because we don't lie to one another. We freely share how we feel about certain things. Then we gather all our opinions and come up with a solution that we all whole - heartedly agree on. That's why friends should depend on each other like a well - coordinated team. When you break the trust with a friend, you probably won't regain the same level of trust as before. You won't be told as many things as you used to. It's as if you should have never let that trust slip away. You seem different because you're no longer fully trusted. You'll be blamed for lying or for any reason that led to the loss of trust. Like one time, one of my friends didn't tell me the whole truth of what she was doing behind my back. When I finally found out, I lost most of my trust in her. She's not as trusted as she was before, but we are still friends. That's why having trust is a big deal in a friendship or any kind of relationship. You learn to trust each other in various ways, and get to know each other more deeply through that trust. You gain more attention when you have that trust with others. You don't feel left out of anything. You'll find that you can trust more people as you get to know them. Who knows, you might even develop trust for someone who isn't your best friend. So we all know that trust is a huge deal between two people or maybe even more. You need to work together to build and maintain that trust. As long as there is trust between you and others, you can have a good friendship or relationship. My friends and I have learned a great deal from trusting each other in different ways, and this trust has truly enriched our lives.

One day, when I was having trouble trying to cope with some very big changes in my life, I sought the help of a friend. Usually, when I'm having a bad day, I tend to keep to myself. But this was an occasion when I really needed someone else there to help me. So, I went and met with my friend. She tried all she could to cheer me up, but nothing seemed to be working. Then she said, "Hey, want to hear a story?" Wanting to hear anything that would take me out of the slump I was currently in, I said, "Sure, I think it will help." Then she began. "The other day, my family and I went grocery shopping. We were gone for probably four hours." I stopped her right there and asked her how this was relevant to making me feel better, and she said, "The more details the funnier it is." I told her to continue. She continued, "When we got home, the parents started unloading the groceries. While they were doing that, my sister and I were in the living room teaching our dog how to sit, lay, shake, speak, and roll over. Every time she did a trick, we would give her half a dog treat. When the parents were done putting the groceries away, they walked in the living room and we showed them the tricks we had taught our dog, which they had yet to see. After we showed them all, my father had to say was, 'Please put the dog treats up so she doesn't get into them.' I replied with a simple 'Okay.' Then the parents said they would be back and that they were going to get pizza because they didn't want to cook after a long day of shopping, and then they left. While they were gone, my sister and I straightened up the living room and continued to train the dog. When the parents got back, we all sat down and began to watch TV and eat our pizza. After a while, when everyone was done eating, we were still in the living room. My sister and I heard my dad in the kitchen complaining about not being able to find the cookies they had bought. I looked at my sister and said, 'You know what would be funny? If dad thought the dog treats were cookies and ate one.' My sister giggled. Our dad came stomping into the living room and threw himself on the couch, acting like a four - year - old boy who had his game taken away. We began to laugh, and our dad looked over and scolded us, then looked back at the TV. Then out of nowhere, he said, 'I found them.' Or what he thought was them. He reached for the dog treats on the coffee table. My sister and I didn't dare speak a word. We watched him. He looked at the bag and reached his hand into the bag of dog treats and pulled one out. He looked at us and we looked away momentarily. Then our eyes fixed right back on him, beyond our control. We had to watch. He looked away to the TV again and put a whole dog treat in his mouth. He began to chew. Then he slowed down his chewing and tilted his head to the side, just like a dog would. What a coincidence. Then it sounded like he choked on a piece of it and he began to cough. He spit dog treats all over the back of my mom's head who was sitting on the floor. My sister and I began to laugh hysterically beyond our control. My dad was sitting on the couch with a straight face. I swear we could see the smoke coming out of his ears. He began to yell about how we should have put the dog treats up so this wouldn't happen, but in mid - sentence, he couldn't help it anymore. He began to laugh. Then we were all laughing, and then we looked at my mom who was still sitting on the floor, still in shock because she got sprayed with chewed dog treats. We couldn't stop laughing, and then she began to laugh." When she told me this story and laughed so hard that I even cried. Then I realized, "All you need is a little laughter in your day to brighten your life." And that laughter really did lift my spirits that day.

Have you ever had a fear of falling off of a cliff when up in the mountain? I have, and I actually had that terrifying experience. It was a winter day, and right after we had just gotten off of the bus, I quickly grabbed all of my gear from the storage under the bus and then headed for the slopes with my friends. We strapped in our boots firmly and then went to the lift to catch a chair up. The air was so crisp and cold, and the snow was like a fresh, soft blanket of powder. It was a perfect day for snowboarding. We were all so excited to go ride in that wonderful winter setting. As we went down the run, it was the same old usual every winter day. So I talked to my friends and suggested that it was time we went through some new trails. They readily agreed, so we went down through a new area. It was a really good trail with many exciting jumps and a lot of soft powder. It seemed like an absolutely perfect area to board in. We all enjoyed it very much, whooping and hollering as we made our way down. But we realized that it was coming to the end when the trail was getting a little narrow. Then suddenly, there was a steep drop right in front of us. I quickly shifted my board sideways so I could stop, but it didn't help at all. It was a patch of ice that I hit, and it was completely useless. I couldn't stop my momentum. I fell off the edge, and I braced myself for the impact, my heart pounding in my chest. I was thinking that I was about to be seriously injured because of the sharp rocks below. But luckily, my board was the first to hit the rock, showering the cool winter air with sparks that lit up the area. I slid down the snow a couple more feet, desperately trying to stop myself. As I finally came to a stop, I looked back in disbelief, wondering how I had survived that. I was really worried that my friends would do the same, but they had stopped just in time. We all couldn't believe what had just happened. I learned a valuable lesson from that incident: to always scope out the area first before you go through it. I was extremely lucky that I wasn't hurt; I could have been seriously injured. This experience will always stay in my mind as a reminder of the importance of caution in the mountains.

Laughter, everyone from cute babies to wise old people does it. Laughter is an essential element that helps in life. They say that "laughter is the best medicine," and it truly is. Laughing lets people know that you have a good sense of humor and that you like to have fun and let loose. In any friendship, relationship, job, or sport, you need to laugh every once in a while. You can't always be serious all the time. Being overly serious, as they say, is not good. It makes people seem like they don't know how to enjoy life or they have no sense of humor. In a particular season, I had a rough volleyball season. A lot of my teammates had problems with me because I was chosen as captain along with my friend [Name]. We weren't the most well - liked captains, but we were liked by some of the team members. It was really hard for [Name] and me to prove that we were right for the position of captains and that we could lead the team effectively. A few of my teammates at the time quit because they did not want to deal with [Name] and me being captains. But as they quit, we moved people from junior varsity up to varsity. The new varsity members had a tough time; they struggled a bit trying to get the hang of varsity play. But they were determined and managed to get the hang of how varsity plays and practices. Soon after our mishap of having to replace seven out of fourteen players, we had our first game. The game was one of the toughest we had the whole season. In our first set of what would become a five - set game, we didn't exactly have our minds fully in it at the beginning. We battled back and forth a few points in the first set, but unfortunately, we ended up losing that first set. We went into the second set not knowing what we were going to do, whether to give up or just half - heartedly play. It was tough, but as one of the captains, I said, "Come on, we won't get anywhere unless we give it our all." Then [Name] said, "I agree, let's try our best and not let them get an easy win." We did exactly that. We tried hard and we won that second set. It was the third set, and we had started to get tired and feel aggravated. But we pushed forward with all our might and won the third set. One more set and we would win it. We went on the court, and the ball was served. We let the ball hit the ground, giving point one to the other team. After that first point, it went downhill. We let them get the best of us and they won the set. It had come down to the fifth and final set, where we would either win or lose. We got on the court knowing that we might lose, but we started with determination. The first point went to us, and we went back and forth a ton in the final set. It was a really tough battle, but we had done it; we won. Later in the season, we met the team again, and it was a hands - down battle. We lost the second time we met them. It was not easy at all; they didn't allow any room for errors on their behalf, but we let our performance slip. It was time for the state playoffs, and we had made it to the state finals. The team we were playing was the team we had faced twice before, and we were one and one against them. The line - up was called, the national anthem was sang, and the coin was flipped. We would receive the serve. The game was in full swing, and we were doing great. We won the first set by four points; it was a tough first game. We went into set two, but we lost control. We didn't do what we were supposed to do. We lost the second set, and it was a real confidence - hitter. We were down and didn't know what to expect in set three. As captains, the team was looking at [Name] and me, and we shouldn't have let ourselves be down. We looked at each other with that knowing look, and then we just busted out laughing. We couldn't stop. The team wondered what was wrong. So we explained that in order to win, we had to laugh. We couldn't let ourselves feel down. The team joined in the laughter, and we went into the third set confident as ever. We won that set, and we didn't stop there. We went into the fourth set and won it too. We had done what we set out to do: win! In the end, laughing was what we needed to do. We had come this far, and we could either give up or push and succeed. We looked back at the two previous games that we had against that team and laughed. We made "laugh until you cry, and cry until you laugh" our team motto. The season was great looking back on it; we were state champs. Now in the new season, we are hoping to repeat our success and become state champs again, with laughter still by our side.

The Element of @CAPS1 and Laughter Laughter is an extremely important element that a person could ever have when they are in a joyful or happy mood. Some accidents people can decide whether to take it one way or the other. For example, a person might think that another person that is about to jump off of a diving board, but then slips and hits his back on the board is really funny and another person could disagree with that and take it in the opposite way and think that it was not funny at all. It is like when someone says that they have a really funny joke or something hilarious to say, and you end up thinking that it was something that was bothersome or a tragedy or it could also be the other way around. Enjoy having good times with friends to share a couple of laughs, don't just be in a grumpy mood all the time, be happy. Laughter is a good thing; people love it so don't always be serious and at least share some laughs with your friends or loved ones. Laughter truly enriches our lives.

Our packed bags and ski gear filled the vehicle to the brim, along with six other kids, occupying all of the other empty spaces. Our uncomfortable seating arrangements didn't seem to ruin our fun, within five minutes of our road trip, the van exploded with laughter, as @PERSON1, most likely a future comedian, started off cracking really funny jokes, just being his usual hilarious self. Within those first five minutes of our drive, I could already tell that this was going to be a ski trip I would always remember.  The van rolled up to the hotel parking lot. My ski team would be lodging here for the long weekend. The sky had turned black with the @TIME1, and me along with everyone else trudged along with weary eyes, exhausted from the long drive. We quickly unloaded our bags, all eager to hop into our beds, knowing that five a.m. would be coming quickly. The sun began rising over the mountains, signaling time to wake up. This was not the case for me. I had been up for nearly an hour, and sat in our van while we sped around each sharp corner up to the mountain. It was race day, and me, along with all of my teammates were all excited for the day ahead. The morning flew by quickly, collecting our bibs at registration, getting our lift tickets, and inspection of the course. I now stood at the top of the hill peering down at the course ahead of me. I had to focus. While I have had a lot of fun, it was time to concentrate, to perform my absolute best. The pressure was on. I now stood in the start gate, my coach stood by my side, and my friends were watching as well, cheering me on. I was hoping not to disappoint. "@CAPS2 ready," the official began in a tense voice, "@CAPS3!" I threw myself out of the start gate. I flew by each gate, staying in control and most important, going fast. The wind slid past my aerodynamic body, my ankles and knees rolled smoothly with each turn. Everything was going well until I broke over the knoll. My body compressed bringing my knees to my chest, as I skied over the roller, throwing me off balance. I fought hard to get back up, to regain myself, but I couldn't do it. My skis spun out from under me, causing me to be spit out from the course, landing on my back, sliding down the mountain, hopeless and done for. It was over. I sat in the snow frustrated with my performance. I wanted a second chance that I wasn't going to get. @PERSON1, one of my teammates, came up to me and sat in the snow by my side. My first thought was he was going to say something of a cliche "nice job," or a "you'll do better next time". To my surprise he tells me one of his ridiculous jokes. My mouth turns up, trying to contain a laugh, unsuccessful, I burst into laughter. @PERSON1 sits there and smiles at me. Almost immediately I found myself in a better mood. I give him a quick "thanks," with a smile before we both @CAPS3 to watch and cheer on our teammates. Although I didn't do my best, I didn't let my results ruin my weekend. The next day, I skied two solid runs with top finishes, if I had stayed upset with myself, I would have never been able to achieve those results. I came to realize that some days, just a small laugh can be all you need to turn any day around. Laughter, I have found is essential in any situation. It's a connection that can bring anyone closer. For me, laughter changed my personality that day on the mountain. Laughter can mean many different things for many different people, laughter could be a special bond between two people. Laughter can remove the seriousness or competitiveness in a situation, but also it unites us. Languages are different among people, but everyone understands what a laugh can do, a laugh is truly universal and should be embraced in all aspects of life.

The Gift of Laughter As of this date, I don't remember exactly why I was laughing. All I can remember, vividly, in my mind is the look on my grandfather's face. He had on the same warm smile he always wore during times of joy. It was a wide, inviting grin that he would shine your way every so often. As I laughed uncontrollably that day, so many years ago, he shined his happiness and love down on me for so long that I will never forget a single wrinkle in his grin. My grandfather, who we all called Pop, had a way of keeping the peace and happiness in everything. No matter how bad things were within our family, he would always make things right. No one could get angry with Pop, and no one could stay sad when he smiled. That's just the kind of guy he was.  Pop was a big part of our family gatherings, just like the one we had on that special day with Pop. That day was our family's annual reunion with Pop, and soon after, he passed away. When I look back and realize how important that day was, I can see that it was a perfect occasion for everyone. It was a happy day, and my most vivid memories of my grandfather were of his great big happy grin shining down on me while I giggled away during a card game.  When that reunion kicked off, in the early morning, the weather was already proving to be spectacular. Everyone in my family was in high spirits and was ready to enjoy the day with family. My favorite activity during each and every family event is to play my favorite games with everyone. Our family has a few specific games that are a tradition during family gatherings. One of our favorites is called Hearts - Spades. Now Hearts - Spades was one of the many games that my grandfather was very good at playing. He rarely ever lost a game, and would not finish playing until he had won at least once. So when everyone was assembled at our house, I convinced Pop and my cousin Tom to play Hearts - Spades with me. We went into the spare room and started dealing out the cards. About a half an hour later we were still playing, and to no one's surprise, Pop was winning. It was just before the food was ready and we were about halfway through the game when either my cousin Tom, or Pop said something to me that I thought was the funniest thing my tiny eight - year - old ears had ever heard, and I began to laugh.  My family was so thoroughly entertained by my laughter that they could not keep their smiles and laughter tucked away without bursting into giggles as bad as mine. It seemed that my senseless laughing created instant joy for my family, including my grandfather. Pop's smile was one of the greatest things my little eyes looked up at during my childhood. It was something so magical, yet so colorful and vivid in front of me, that I would worship his smile like I was seeing my first solar eclipse. I never quite understood, at such a young age what was so fascinating about his smile, but now I do understand. Pop's smile showed true, wholesome, unbreakable joy. His smile didn't come out all too often so when it did, you knew something good was happening.  No one knew that was our last reunion with Pop. I most certainly could not imagine it to be the last day I would spend with my grandfather. Everything was so perfect and so increasingly happy, it seemed to be a crime to end his life during such a time of joy. Although if I were him, and if I had to choose my last reunion, that day would be perfect. My single memory of that day was laughing, and being happy. I can't think of any better way to spend my last bit of time with Pop than a day where we were both completely satisfied in our card game, laughter, and smiles.  Laughter is a funny thing. It is unique in every person, and can range from any kind of humor to pure happiness. Laughter brings hope in times of doubt and never fails to make someone smile. Someone, somewhere started a quote that says, "Live. Laugh. Love." I believe those three words can combine together, and act separately to sum up a perfect life for anyone willing to live out the true, meaningful definition of each of those words. Laughter brings smiles of happiness, humor, and love. Love brings us all together, and when we strive to be happy and to love, that is when we can truly live. My grandfather loved each and every one of his family and friends and made a priority of keeping them happy. He lived his life the best way that I believe anyone could ever live it. He died after a life full of love, happiness, and, most importantly, the very special gift of laughter. In the end, the memories of that laughter - filled day with Pop will always be a precious part of my life, a reminder of the power of love and laughter in bringing joy and connection to our lives.

Some people say that laughter is good for the soul, and that could be true, but the soul is definitely not the only thing. Laughing is great for your heart and mind too. It can improve relationships, make friendships grow stronger, and even start and make two people who don't know anything about each other, extremely close. You can meet someone new or be with someone you barely know, and just because they make you laugh you feel like you want to get to know them better. I love that feeling. Honestly, you can laugh with any age or gender. You don't both have to be 20 and female, you could be with a little boy, an elderly lady, or anywhere in between and still have a lot of fun.  Last summer I never had anything to do, so I decided I should start volunteering places. The two places I could volunteer at were: a daycare next to my house, or an old folks home about 5 miles away. I thought really hard about it, trying to make the best decision for me. I couldn't make up my mind, and even though I didn't admit it, I felt like they would be just as boring as sitting at home. I finally decided I should do both of them, so I could meet some new people, and have new experiences.  I started with the daycare. I woke up at 7 am, and walked to the daycare center. I wasn't sure what it was going to be like at all. I didn't even know if I was good with kids. I walked in, and stood there awkwardly. The daycare manager came up to me and asked me if I could help out with the 3 - year - old's coloring room. I nodded my head nervously. Was I supposed to color for them? There's no way they could color a picture by themselves. They're only three! I thought. Oh well, if I follow directions then this day will get over faster.  When I went in, all the kids ran up to me with a smile on their face. "Sit by me!" one said. "Come here!" said another. "There's a spot right here!" "Look at my picture!" "I drew a rainbow!" "I drew a car!" "I drew you!" To that, I looked down. There I was, on the piece of paper. A bunch of blue and green scribbles. That day was a lot of fun. I was laughing and having a great time with the kids. I learned that I absolutely adore kids, and I'm actually pretty good with them.  The next week I went to the nursing home. I was even more nervous there. I felt so out of place. I hadn't found out what I was going to be helping with yet, so I sat on a chair in the lobby. When the receptionist asked who I was there to see, I said nobody. She then asked me why I was here, and I replied, "Oh, I was going to volunteer." She led me down the hall and told me that it was almost time for lunch so I needed to get ready to serve lunch. I did, and then I heard, what I assumed was, the lunch bell. I gave everyone their lunch with a big smile and it was honestly great. If one of them looked a little down, or upset I could flash them a smile and they would grin back, obviously in higher spirits than before.  After lunch, I played a few games of chess. Most people who were there took naps after lunch, so there were only three people out there. I played first with a lady who used to be a nurse. I got to know her pretty well in the half hour we played the game; which I won. Next was a guy who was a veteran. He fought in the Vietnam war. He seemed really nice, but serious. I won that game too. The last man used to be a comedian. He was so funny. He told jokes the whole game! Maybe he said a few too many, because he beat me at chess. Well, that was my excuse.  When I got done, I was in a great mood and I couldn't wait to come back again. I learned a lot that summer. I found out everyone is alike in some ways, even though each person is unique. I realized you don't have to be the same as the person you're with to laugh and have a good time. It doesn't matter what age, race, gender, size, mentality, maturity, etc. The only thing that matters is that you are in the same place at the same time, trying to make the best of your day. I am so glad I decided to volunteer, otherwise I would have never known so much about people, love, life, and laughter. Through these volunteer experiences, I've come to understand that laughter truly is a universal language that can bridge the gaps between different generations and backgrounds, bringing joy and connection to all.

A couple of months ago I was hanging out with my friend Jess. It was a sunny Saturday and I came to her place to spend the afternoon. At first, we were extremely bored, so we decided to go on a walk to find something interesting to do. We strolled around the neighborhood and eventually found our friend Dylan at the skatepark. We stopped to talk to him for a while, watching him do some cool tricks on his skateboard. After we had hung out there for about two hours, we headed back up to her house.  When we opened the door, her sister started freaking out because we had left and she got stuck with their younger brother Jake. Jess didn't yell back; she didn't want to start any drama. Her sister got even more mad because Jess was not showing a reaction to what she was doing. By ten minutes, she exploded and started throwing herself around and acting like a crazy person. She was stomping her feet and flailing her arms, looking so ridiculous.  Jess and I looked at each other and started laughing really, really hard because of how funny her sister looked. It was like watching a comedy show right in front of us. After a while, her mom had calmed the situation down. Jess and I then made a cozy bed on her bedroom floor using some blankets and pillows. As we were lying there, getting ready to fall asleep, we both burst out in laughter again. We were probably still thinking about her sister's crazy outburst. It was the funnest afternoon I have had in a long time. Those moments of shared laughter not only lightened the mood but also strengthened the bond between me and Jess, making that day a truly memorable one.

Laughter is a daily part of my life. I'm always laughing in school, whether it's during a funny class discussion or when my friends crack a joke. At home, too, laughter fills the air when my family gets together for a meal or plays a game. With laughter, you can show many emotions that can't be told with words. It can express joy, amusement, and even relief. To me, it's also a way of showing how fortunate your life is, as it indicates that there are moments of happiness and light - heartedness in it.  I've had numerous occasions where laughter was the solution to my problem. For instance, when I was stressed about an exam, a funny video my friend sent me made me laugh and helped me relax. I also agree that laughter is an important part of a relationship. It can break the ice, ease tension, and create a warm and positive atmosphere. In the next paragraphs, I am going to talk about how laughter affects my relationship and the benefits it brings to it as well.  Approximately three months ago, my family and I decided to take a trip to Hawaii. We planned to stay there for a month or so. When I told my boyfriend that I'd be gone for a month, right away I saw the sadness in his eyes. This truly killed me. However, our decision was made and there was no turning back. Our relationship was tense during that month. We talked a few times on the phone, but his voice was different. There was a sadness to it and I knew something was wrong. Although he said everything was good, I knew his sadness was due to my absence.  After the month had finally ended, it was time to come back to New York! I was truly excited. We arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York at 3 pm on a sunny Friday afternoon. I immediately called him but there was no chance of seeing him that same day. Although, just knowing that I was closer to him made me happy and anxious. We conversed for endless hours on the phone, telling each other that we would never be that far apart again. We laughed and laughed during our whole conversation. We talked about funny things that had happened to us during that month, and his laughter on the other end of the line was like music to my ears. To me, the sound of his laughter was a sign of his happiness and that was just priceless. The laughter was as if it had been a blessing to our relationship. It melted away the tension and brought back the warmth and closeness we had before.  From that day on forward, I realized how much laughter really affects me in numerous ways. It's as if it brings happiness

Looking back on my early childhood, one thing that stands out bright and shiny in my vivid memory is the warm and infectious laughter. Since the moment I was born, I have always had an innate love to smile and laugh heartily. I've discovered a kind of deep - seated comfort, serene peace, and unwavering confidence through laughter alone, which I sincerely doubt I would have been able to find elsewhere naturally. This could, in part, be because of my dear Grandfather. We rarely get to see each other because he lives in a small, cozy town in the countryside and I live in the bustling city. But when we do have the precious luxury of spending time together, it is always filled to the brim with laughter and pure, unadulterated joy. I credit him whole - heartedly for giving me my love for laughter. I've been told by my parents that as a baby, all my Grandfather had to do was let out his booming laugh, and my eyes would brighten up like twinkling stars and a wide smile, as wide as the expansive ocean on my face, would become apparent. It's been that way ever since. One of my earliest and most cherished memories is laying on my parent's soft bed, listening intently to my Grandfather tell me hilarious jokes. Every time he finished, I would erupt in uncontrollable laughter, and at the sight of me laughing so merrily, he would burst out too. The important detail to note is, when my Grandfather laughs, his big belly shakes violently like a jiggling jelly. I found this the most delightful part of the jokes. Once his belly started bouncing up and down, my laughter became completely out of control. Our laughter escalated until tears of happiness were streaming down our faces. Besides having a belly that bounces when he laughs, my Grandfather has one of the most distinctive and contagious laughs one has ever been fortunate enough to hear. It's one of those fabulous and enriching laughs which words simply do not do justice, but once you hear it, you won't ever forget it. His laughter can light up the darkest room in a house. For me, his laugh almost has a medicinal, healing quality. Whenever I hear my Grandfather laugh, for just a moment, the world stops, and everything within is okay. I am not the only one who has a great appreciation for my Grandfather's laugh. My father and him both have a love for telling jokes, which I have observed over the years, is one of the few things they hold a common agreement on. Everything from politics, to religion, to who should pay for dinner, usually ends in an argument between them. Because of that, they tend to stay clear of those topics for fear of confrontation. They have never mentioned this, but from my observation over the years, I've come to the conclusion that the laughter they share so often, acts as the glue which keeps their relationship strong. Were it not for laughter, I sometimes wonder if they would still have a working, loving relationship. I will forever be thankful for the great gift my Grandfather unknowingly gave me at such a young age. He created a deep and passionate love for laughter inside me, which has gotten me through the roughest times. I truly believe that laughter heals the soul and that when two people share a laugh, they are bonded for a moment in a precious, fragile, and sacred way. My day can be going horribly, and in the instant that a joke is cracked, and laughter overwhelms my body, everything brightens and the worries and stresses of my day seem so insignificant. Finding humor in every situation is another lesson that my Grandfather taught me. If you can find humor, you can find serenity in the most disastrous moments. Laughter, to me, is somewhat like a drug. It's a harmless, enriching, and life - saving drug which I can proudly say I hope to be addicted to for the rest of my life, thanks to my wonderful Grandfather.

Laughter is such a truly marvelous element to have in any relationship. For instance, if you can't find any form of humor in a relationship, then I'm pretty certain there is no strong connection between the two of you. For example, I was in a relationship once where we didn't have that essential element of humor, and I truthfully did not enjoy that relationship that she and I had. Any type of relationship needs laughter, whether it's friendships, between boyfriends and girlfriends, or even within a family. All different types of relationships need some form of humor to thrive and survive. Sometimes families don't have that humor for each other, but they'll still have that special type of a deep - rooted friendship. The reason for that, I believe, is because your family will always be there for you, unlike most friends would. One way I know this is because one of my friends really liked a guy. I could have sworn she, in that summer month, might have even loved him. When he told her that he started dating some girl, she had cried for weeks. Then, when she was at her mom's house, one of her brothers, whom she believed hated her, said he wanted to hurt the guy that had made his younger sister cry. They, in that same month, did not have a humorous friendship, or even a friendship at all. But I believe laughter isn't necessarily always needed, especially within family. All types of relationships are like plants. The flower is the relationship and laughter is the water that will help the relationship grow big and strong. But without that water, the plant won't grow, just like in a relationship without laughter. I know that if I knew someone who I did not find to be humorous, I know our friendship would not be very strong, unlike someone who I felt was hilarious. Laughter is always an important element in everyday life. For instance, if you are going for a job interview, you really need to connect with the person interviewing you and make a good impression for yourself. One way of doing that is through laughter. I have heard of many stories about job interviews. An example of one is my mom had an interview not too long ago for a high - profile job. She told me about her interview and she said they had really connected. There was also some seriousness and some laughter in that interview. Then three days later, they emailed her and told her that she got the job and that they would love to hire her. And I have heard of interviews where they didn't get the job. My sister had an interview once for a pet kennel type of place where people drop their pets off while they go on vacation. She said that her and the person interviewing her had no connection, which led to no humor or laughter. So I believe humor is such a marvelous element to have within a relationship because with laughter comes greatness and happiness.

Laughter is key. You never really think about the importance of laughter, but the truth is, laughing brings the most opposite people together. Last year, I met one of my brother's friends in school. We never really talked, but she seemed like a nice person. We had a class together and we started talking more and more every day. She was best friends with my best friend. Sarah was her name and she drove a bright orange Volkswagen Beetle. We hung out after school one day. I leaned the passenger seat all the way back and was sitting on it like a lazy dog. She suddenly slammed on the brakes and I flew into the front of the vehicle. I couldn't stop laughing. At that moment, I knew we were going to be great friends. I was a freshman, so I didn't really know anyone, and she was always nice to everyone. So we started hanging out more. I lived about 10 miles out of town, and her brothers went to school about 5 miles past my house. So we had to go pick them up. We bought a game called 'BeanBoozled'. There are tons of little jelly - beans that were flavored like vomit, centipede, dirt, rotten egg, etc. So we were playing while we were driving out there, and Sarah had to stop the car nearly 3 times in our 15 - mile drive! Those were the nastiest beans ever! Then, we would drive out to my house and we'd listen to our favorite country songs and blast them in her car. She was my ultimate best friend and no one could replace her. Whenever we would get in fights, we wouldn't start drama. We'd always have an actual physical fight because by the time one of us was pinned, the other was laughing too hard to do anything about it. Her dad and my dad became friends later on too, and we would always have barbecues and family get - togethers. We also talked in a southern accent all the time because one of our friends was from Texas. Whenever we went to the mall to go shopping, we'd use our accent, and everywhere we went, people would ask us where we were from. Before we knew it, our dads started talking like us. We also created a bunch of slang words, and then the whole school started using them. She is a great friend and she keeps me laughing every day. Whenever Sarah was having problems with her family, she knew she could always talk to me, and I would always be there for her. She always called me sister instead of friend because we were so close. She used to take cooking and sewing classes at my old high school. When she got the fake baby doll, it would keep us up late into the night. That baby was crazy. Sarah would be driving, and the baby would start screaming in its car seat, and we'd have to pull over and find out what was wrong with it. She'd be a good mom. She always cared for things, even the smallest little thing she would cherish. One time, we painted her little brother's room because we were bored. Sarah was rolling her paintbrush in paint and texting. She took her eye off of her phone and dropped it in the paint. She couldn't find it for like 10 minutes, and by the time she did find it, it was totally covered in green paint! I laughed at her for so long, and those are the moments I wish I could bring back. Every time we hung out, I would laugh, and I realize now how important that laughter is to me. About six months ago, I moved to a whole different state, and I don't see her very often. There is no one like Sarah. She could make me laugh and was always just 10 minutes away when I needed something. Now I have to drive about 2 hours to even see her. I haven't laughed like she made me ever since I went back to visit. Laughter is key, as I stated before, and if you frown, you'll never know who is falling in love with your smile.

A few years ago, when I was 15, I decided to do an experiment on laughing and the color of the clothes people wear. I realized that I laughed a lot and I was almost always happy because of my great friends, I did really well in school, and I also had a very 'up' attitude. My clothes were all very bright and 'happy' colors. I had a theory that the less someone laughed, and the darker colored clothes they wore, would make their mood and attitude dip. The experiment would last one week, and in that time, I would try hard not to laugh and gradually start wearing darker and darker clothes until I got to black, to see how I would be affected, if affected at all. To get started, I had to first tell everyone what I was doing and ask them to try not to make me laugh on purpose. Then I had to go to the store and get new clothes that had no bright colors on them. That was the hardest part because I saw a lot of cute clothes, but they were too colorful. After that, I only had to wait for the weekend to end and Monday to begin. On Monday morning, I woke up and did my usual daily routine, then tried on my new clothes. When I got to school, I noticed the surprised looks from my classmates as they took in my outfit. It was pretty tough trying not to laugh at some of their expressions, but I couldn't, because that would ruin what I was trying to accomplish. Throughout the day, I got comments on my clothing, and some of my teachers were worried because I wasn't laughing as usual. But when I told them of my experiment, they understood and said, "Good luck." As the day came to an end, I was satisfied with my success and quickly fell asleep. The next two days went pretty much the same, and I was wondering if my theory would be proven wrong. But on Wednesday morning, my mom pointed out that I seemed different. "Are you okay?" she asked. "You don't seem as energetic in the morning, and you're not smiling at all. Are you sick or something?" I told her that I was fine. At school, I was asked the same thing, and after a while, it got really annoying. I got mad and yelled at them, which I never do, and they apologized. But I felt bad and told them I was sorry, and they forgave me, telling me it was probably just the experiment. I got a little happier at the thought that my theory might just be correct. Laughing, laughter.It's every where. Lots of people are laughing right now.Why not laugh though? It's good for you right? It feels good to laugh here an their. Well laughter can make your day great. She was very depressed too. Ill tell you a little about it.   My day started off as a normal school day, I got up got ready, got on thus to school then be for I new it I was on the bus on my way home. I get off a block or two away from my house and then I walk home. I walk and walk, an about ten minutes later I get up to my house. We started walking down the road after we got to the end of are drive way. We walked straight for about five minutes, then take a right.We walk that way for about ten minutes an turn left. When I looked back at my mom she look like she was having a really bad day. Like anyone i asked her what was wrong. She talked to me about everything and she seemed really sad, and depressed. From that I knew i need to talk to her an make her laugh. We never had the best relationship because she was always gone hanging out with friends. I knew if i could make her laugh, an help her get better, it would help us get along better an help each other out in the long run. I love my mom an I hate seeing people down. We went on a couple more walks for the next month or two and we got a good mother an son relationship. We were both happy this had happened. About two months from the first walk w had she came up to me and hugged me and told me thank you for helping her out with what she was going though. I think laughter is a great thing in life. For me it helped me out a lot in life an it helped me save a relationship with my mom. I love laughing, and I love making people laugh it is fun to laugh an fun to make people laugh. Laughter makes great friendships. It can have a lot to do with your life. I hope this helps you laugh more and makes you try to be funny an have people laugh with you.

Laughter is just one of those things that doesn't go away very easily. Even the simplest things can make you laugh or smile. The point is, happiness is going to be around for a while. My dad laughs, my mom laughs, I laugh, and everybody laughs. It's truly a good thing to have. If there was nothing to be happy about, then people would be in fights, and countries would be in wars. Anger is not something someone wants to deal with all the time; you have to relax every now and then. My parents and I know that happiness is what drives us to good things. That's why we embrace it in our house, and we like to acknowledge it to my younger siblings. My dad and I have a good relationship, as well as with my mom. We get along well and laugh together. Me and my girlfriend at @LOCATION1; we started out in a good relationship, but as time went on, it was starting to fade. We weren't communicating as well, and that's what was driving us apart. We were just ending up in fights all the time, and for no reason, fighting just seemed to find us all the time. We talked, we hung out, and we started getting along better, laughing at our jokes or our constant teasing to one another. We had a good time. She said that she liked us laughing and having a good time. I told her that laughing and enjoying ourselves is what brought us together. Laughing is the key to our happiness; it's what made me and her closer. It's a main key point to any relationship. If there is no happiness, then there is no laughter, and if there is no laughter, then how are you supposed to get happiness? They work together, and it's a good thing to have in life. Where would we be if we didn't have it? We would all have a grudge for no reason and just live in black and white all the time. Laughter truly enriches our lives and makes every moment more meaningful.

A @ORGANIZATION1 is a wondrous gift. It allows your mind and your body to conjoin with others. It is the root of happiness and brings a sense of sanity to those who have lost hope. It was my voice that he was laughing at. Everything I did caused him to become hysterical. I found out later that he was from @LOCATION1 and didn't speak a word of @CAPS2. My mom and I eventually moved out of our house and lost contact with the neighbors. I am always reminded of him when I hear a laugh. Though he's not near me in a physical sense, I am guided by his laughter every day, and it continues to inspire me to find joy in life.
