Human beings are...unusual...Okay, we're weird. There are so many people in the world, including ourselves, and the only way we can like ourselves is if we can get others to like us. If that isn't strange enough, we still don't like ourselves no matter who likes us. Just what are we thinking? We are always using relationships to assist our understanding of who we are; it's a gamble to even have those relationships. Face the facts, we risk so much on relying on others; we give them the ability to build us...or break us. Our major goals as youngsters is to find people to like us. I think it might even span to later times in life than that! From my experiences, I know there are two key points in knowing a person can build us: trust and kindness. Finding builders with these traits is as easy as understanding if they bring you joy or not. A person can give you joy by simply being kind to you...but if you want a whole swarm of friends, then this isn't exactly the best way. It's not that kindness is a bad way to make friends...it's just that it's not the fastest method. If a builder is kind, then of course you would become their friend...in time. In order to immediately know a friend when you see one, they will make you laugh. Laughter makes us enjoy our time with our friends; it's a golden rule in the book of @CAPS1, if there is such a book. And it was through laughter that I made my experience in @CAPS2 class better. @CAPS2 class, to me, was extremely stressful. Every day we had either a speaking assignment or we had paperwork; and the class was really slow. Why was it slow? It was slow because we could hardly get through one set of instructions without some group speaking or finding some other way to disturb the class. A good example would be this one class project we had to do. As usual, the instructions were slow; I was at my boiling point. Today seemed different though. Despite the usual annoyance, not a single student asked for a repeat on instructions. In fact, they all seemed to understand and immediately started working. I too followed in with this action. The assignment was that each group of about three to four people had to create a script using the vocabulary learned from the supplied booklet. It took a whole class period, and then everyone went home to do their other work. The next day we returned to @CAPS2 class, and it was definitely an interesting one. The teacher had all kinds of strange props lined up for us. Apparently, we were going to have the audience act out our script, and our job was to read it out loud. My group was first to entertain, and we had finally selected our volunteers and actors. Tiffany, @PERSON1, and I sat down in the back of the classroom, ready to read the script, not sure what the actors would deliver. Our play was... a success?! By the end of the first sentence, everyone was giggling. As we moved further on to the next play, the laughter had grown louder. Students were really enjoying themselves, and more people volunteered to perform until it was difficult to choose actors. Even I, the classroom - snob, was enjoying myself. The plays were fun and random; some plays would send everyone into hysterics. I can easily remember one of the groups making me laugh so hard that my sides were aching, and tears lined my lids, and it was almost impossible to breathe. This project was definitely the best one I had ever participated in. It's moments like these when we build strong unity in the classroom. We enjoyed all of the people around us, and we enjoyed ourselves. I was so used to being angry at my classmates that I was taken by surprise on that one day. Enjoying their plays so much, I now look at them as an entertaining group of students, rather than the annoyance I had seen them as before. No longer are these people strangers in the hallway; now they are family. It really is amazing how something as simple as laughter can change one's outlook on others and themselves.

The Power of Laughter. What would we be without laughter? Would we still have relationships/friendships like we do now? Laughter brings out a sense of connection closer to someone, a sense of humor, a friendship, and a positive environment. Personally, I feel as if the world would be a miserable place to be without laughter. I can assure you life would not be the same as it is now. Without laughter, my winter vacation would not have been anything like it was. Over winter vacation, my friends and I made it our mission to embarrass @PERSON1 (@PERSON5). This however, was not as easy as it may sound, seeing as how nothing could ever bring her down. We tried our hardest to embarrass her. We tried throwing her into a pool while her crush was around, dumping our drinks all over her just as a group of cute boys walked by, calling her names that only a grandmother would call a child. You name it, we did it. She was like a brick of marble, extremely hard to break. One day, my closet friend @PERSON2 came up with the idea of grabbing a pair of shorts, removing the seam on the butt, and gluing it back together in hopes of it ripping when @PERSON5 bent over. Hey @PERSON5, I began, @PERSON2 and I found these shorts yesterday, and thought that you might like them. They're super cute, and would go perfect with your new yellow tank top. Wow! Thanks guys, they fit great! @PERSON5 screamed as she filled with excitement. Let's go to the mall! After about an hour or so of walking around the mall, I threw my phone down and acted as if I hadn't noticed. However, @PERSON5 freaked out and ran after it as it slid down the walkway. Just as she was about to bend over and grab it, her crush, @PERSON4 walked right behind her. Next thing we know, her shorts were split right down the middle, and her cheeks were bright red. @PERSON2 and I couldn't help but laugh. The look on her face was priceless. I wish I had had my camera. We had never seen @PERSON5 so mad. She was absolutely fuming, yet @PERSON2 and I were still laughing at her. I mean, who wouldn't laugh at someone's pants splitting in front of a huge crowd of people at the mall? You guys are so mean, she screamed. @PERSON4 saw me, and you're laughing? He's never going to talk to me again. I hate you guys! You don't hate us. That was hysterical and you know it, chimed @PERSON2. We embarrassed you pretty good, huh? We did it! We did it! We did it! We broke the rock. We actually broke the rock, I giggled as @PERSON2 and I gave each other a high - five. A few minutes later @PERSON5 began to crack up too, and apologized for freaking out after realizing that it was all in good fun. Little did we know, she was planning to get us back. By the end of winter break, we had been to nearly every party, but there was still one at @ORGANIZATION1. We all had a gut feeling that this was going to be the best one yet. Everyone was having a blast at @ORGANIZATION1's party. The strobe lights were going, there was crazy, loud music, the hot tub was at the perfect temperature, and there was a bunch of people in the pool. Who could complain? Just as the party was about to come to a halt, @PERSON5 decided to undo my bikini top, and pull down my bikini bottoms! Humiliated, both of us ran into @LOCATION2's room, and locked the door. How could she take it this far? Was our practical joke this embarrassing to her? Tired of all the nagging coming from @LOCATION1 and @PERSON3 about us running away, we decided to leave the room and forget what happened. Let's just say that we know what we did to @PERSON5 was wrong, we won't do it again, and we now know not to mess with her to the extent that we had during our mall trip. Honestly, I feel as if this whole experience brought us closer together. If that didn't ruin our friendship, nothing would. Consequently, you can now see why I feel that laughter is an important part of a friendship and/or relationship. It makes the world go round. Do you have any experiences where laughter brought you and a friend, significant other, or family member closer together?

During the winter break, my family went to @LOCATION4 except for my older brother. We were headed to @LOCATION1, @LOCATION4. The ride there was long, but we made it. When I woke up at my grandparents' house, there was already snow! I was very excited. They got about six to eight inches of snow. We rested before we went out to enjoy the snow. Later, while I was outside, I got a visit from old friends of mine. I hadn't seen them since @DATE1. We talked and hung out. They told me that I was lucky to get out of school early for winter break. They still had to go to school. I told them that if they were lucky, then they would have to go to school for only half of the week. And they did get lucky. Do you think that being part of something is fun? Well, sometimes it's not always breezy fun because you might be in a difficult situation. Everyone laughs in different ways. Some people laugh so hard that tears stream down their faces, while others just have a soft chuckle. But one thing that they all share is the power of laughter. People use laughter as a wonderful way to express their feelings of pure joy, or intense happiness, or even when something is just really, really funny to them. Laughing is an amazing way to feel better about things. For instance, maybe you're having a truly bad day, and then one of your close friends comes up to you and tells you a hilarious joke. It instantly makes you feel better, doesn't it? Having a good sense of humor is a valuable trait that can help you get through tough situations, embarrassing moments, or even just a plain bad day. Being able to laugh at yourself and at something embarrassing you might have done is a great thing. It can help you quickly get over it and not be overly embarrassed about it. Whenever I laugh, I always feel a wave of positivity. Laughing reminds me of all the wonderful things in life. It reminds me of the amazing good times I have spent with my friends and family. It brings back memories of all the inside jokes my friends and I have come up with over the years, and we can still laugh at them just as hard as we did when we first thought of them. I firmly believe that laughing is enjoyable for everyone. It can make you feel better no matter what the situation is, and some people even say that laughing makes you look and feel younger. When you laugh at things, it creates long - lasting memories that you'll never forget. And when you talk about them again in the future, you'll still find them just as funny as before. Some of my best friends have a contagious laugh. They laugh at everything. They think that every little joke is the funniest thing ever. Their laughs are so distinct and unforgettable that you can always hear them laughing from afar. This shows in another way how laughter can make anyone happy. If you think you're not a funny person, just say something to one of them, and I can guarantee that they'll laugh at it. You'll then feel funny and most likely start laughing as well. I enjoy spending quality time with some of my closest friends. Probably the best time I had with them was when we went to @ORGANIZATION1 for the beginning of @DATE1 before going into high school. It was two days after our promotion (graduation) from middle school. We excitedly packed up my family's car and headed out for @ORGANIZATION1. Not even half - an - hour into the car ride, and we were already cracking up laughing at every little thing that happened. We always create great memories, and this one was already shaping up to be one of the best. I'm sure that the car ride for my mom and aunt was just as fun. So we decided to jump out of the car and do a @CAPS1 fire drill around it. All the other cars watched, and even the construction workers thought it was hilarious. We turned a boring moment into a fun one. Once we finally got there, we didn't hesitate to drop off our bags, grab our bikes, and take off to explore. The weather was perfect, with not a single cloud in the sky. During our exploration bike ride, we laughed, told jokes, and just talked about how excited we were to be out of middle school and moving on to high school. The next day, we decided that we wanted to float down the river on a raft. It sounded like a really fun idea. Well, it would have been if we actually knew where we were going. I used to do it all the time with my family, so I had a rough idea of where to go. But still, five girls, two rafts, and a river - maybe not such a great plan. During the whole river raft trip, we jumped back and forth between the two rafts and occasionally splashed each other with the oars. Knowing us, we laughed the whole way down the river. Whenever we passed people, I'm sure they thought something was wrong with us because of how much we were laughing and enjoying each other's company. By the time we finished the rafting trip, we were starving. Good thing my mom had prepared us some delicious lunch for when we got home. When we sat down at the table, we could never keep a straight face. What made it even funnier was that my aunt and my mom didn't know what we were laughing at because we could just look at each other and burst into laughter. You know you've built a great friendship when you can just look at each other and laugh, already knowing what your friend is thinking because of all the inside jokes you have with each other. All because of one little thing called laughter, these memories will stay with us forever.

Laughter can be used for many important things. One of which is being an important part of a relationship. There are many key elements in a relationship. But, the most crucial one is definitely the idea that "laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Sometimes, laughter can cure the emotion of being sad. But sometimes, it doesn't completely cure it. If laughter is the shortest distance between two people, then when a guy or girl meets someone they like. For instance, I once went up to a girl and was so nervous that I couldn't figure out what to do or say. So, I just tried my absolute best to make her laugh. It @MONTH1 took me a few days of really trying hard to do so. But, in the end, I felt more comfortable asking her out and felt at ease around her and her friends. Whenever I can make her laugh, I always feel a boost of confidence because it's never a good sight to see her in a bad mood. Now, on some occasions, I have made people laugh, and it didn't really mean much. But, when I make my girl laugh, then it's totally worth all the effort. Because I can cheer her up from being sad or angry and turn her into a happy and laughter - filled person. It also helps with dealing with depression. Her being depressed is like a train derailing off its tracks. It never has a good outcome. But when she is happy, she can be full of joy, all giddy, and very spontaneous. I know that laughing alone can be good for your mood. But you can also get strange looks and be called crazy if you're laughing at nothing at all. The best way to know if someone is feeling better is through their laughter. If they laugh, then they can't be mad, sad, or in any negative emotion besides maybe sarcasm. But sarcasm can be easily ignored. If I ever try sarcasm to make people laugh, I always end up offending them. So I always just be my genuine self around everyone I meet. So if you ever hear that laughter is the shortest distance between two people, you should know that it's absolutely true. Because not only do you get to connect with someone on a deeper level and get to know them better. But, you can also learn valuable things about life through being closer to more people. When you hear that phrase, ask yourself, "Am I capable of making someone laugh? Am I able to use laughter to actually be close to someone?" If you do that self - reflection, you'll truly understand that laughter is indeed the shortest distance between two people.

People say laughter is the shortest distance between two people. A moment that made me realize this to be true was when I met a girl named @PERSON1. Three years ago I was at a city playground swinging, my mind filled with gloomy thoughts, wondering if it would hurt if I jumped. I took a wild chance and let go of the swing chains, flying through the air. I could feel the unbalanced feeling of falling in my chest, everything around me seemed to slow down. The temptation of what would happen when I hit the ground was vast. Sticking the landing was a fail and getting up from it wasn't much of a success either, until I felt gentle hands upon my shoulder and arm. I looked up at my helper and saw a girl. Not just any girl but a gorgeous girl. A girl with green, dazzling eyes that could stop an angry rhino charging toward her. Her hair flowed gracefully with the wind, and her soft, gentle skin was so delicate that it made you think she could be easily hurt. "Thanks," was all I could squeeze out. "Thanks, are you okay?" she asked with a very concerned tone. "Yeah, I'm fine, I just forgot to stick the landing. Thanks for helping me, um, what's your name?" I returned with a shy smile. "And your welcome. What's your name?" She giggled before she said her name. "Hey, do you want to walk around with me?" I struggled to vocalize. "Sure, but I have to wait at the playground because my mom will be here soon." @PERSON1 stated. During the walk around the playground, we stopped at a monkey dome and started asking each other random questions that the other person had to answer. I figured out that she was @NUM2 years old, her favorite color was baby blue, and she always wanted to be a doctor. We walked around the playground some more while talking about past memories or something that happened to each other in the past. I asked her if she had a brother and sister. Her response was that she does have a brother and two sisters. While I was listening to her, I noticed she was very deep into thought and asked what she was thinking about. She quickly replied. "Well, I'm wondering why I'm so happy with you." "Well, it could be that I'm making you feel good by laughter. Or it could be my charms working on you." I replied with a silly accent. "Oh yeah, it's definitely that." She barely got out the words because of laughter. Suddenly there was a car horn honking and we said our goodbyes and she left. I sat there watching the car go down the road and was hoping that we would see each other again, but in a way, I knew we wouldn't because my mom and I were moving from the city to a small town halfway across the country. Turning around and walking back toward my house for the last night in the city, all I could think about was her and how a little bit of laughter became the key to friendship.

Aloha park sounded like some school that would have great funding and spoiled rich kids in it, but it was actually the exact opposite. It was an older school with kids that mostly lived in lower - income housing at the time. In some ways, it was rather comforting knowing that I lived the same way temporarily. The first day of school was frightening. It was my first major transition into a new, unfamiliar place. My teacher was old and grouchy. She seemed to have a major chip on her shoulder. Suddenly, out of the blue, she held my hand in the hallway, which was humiliating and definitely not comforting. I heard my new classmates giggle and laugh when they saw me. I thought I would never make any friends. The humiliation was withstandable, but the thought of being in this class for the next nine months was a fear beyond belief. My teacher told me to take a seat on the far side of the room next to three boys. They all had the same expression, which was an amalgamation of both alienated confusion and territorial pride. The feeling of being unwelcome would be an understatement of the new nervous sensation that had surrounded me. I sat down, unaware of the actions that the three boys might deal onto me. Surprisingly, the only occurrence was a series of temporary stares and an awkward silence. As the day continued, life had again become somewhat casual, until the boys had started to talk about the opposite gender, and my attention was directly turned towards them. I sat there and quietly listened and smirked at the inappropriate conversation that I was clearly not supposed to be a part of. They laughed and snickered and covered their mouths embarrassingly. As I looked at them, I considered them amateurs of the comical arts. I wanted to say something that I held onto for the whole conversation, and then I took my chances to add a most important joke. Quickly, I muttered my overly inappropriate sentence. They confusingly looked at me and asked me what I had said. I wasn't sure how they would take the joke, but I risked another chance and repeated it. The group of boys grew silent, and the only noises were those of the other students talking to each other. Suddenly, they burst out laughing. I was overjoyed that they had a sense of humor, and after that, I had friends and a new start in this unfamiliar place.

Laughter is an important part of any relationship, whether the person is a relative, a dear friend, or someone you are dating. Laughter has the amazing ability to make you forget your worries and problems, if only for a little while. But with a friendship based primarily on laughter, when do you trade in the giggles for seriousness? I firmly believe laughter is vital in a friendship. But to have a strong, healthy relationship, you also need a level of seriousness. This is the story of how I learned to balance laughter and seriousness in one of my most important relationships.    Olivia has been my best friend as long as I can clearly remember. Whenever we hung out, we laughed constantly. Laughter has always been a huge, integral part of our friendship and always will be. But going into middle school, we faced drama, boys, and petty arguments, which we had never experienced with one another before. All of these small but important things to us then added up and began to make us drift apart. Our lack of sharing our real feelings and instead covering it up with laughs caused us to bottle up anger towards each other. I always thought we were perfect matches for best friends because of our countless inside jokes and the constant fun we would have. But our anger grew until we were ready to handle it, which we did not understand then.   We started to hang out less and less, and our daily calls became weekly. Both of us noticed a change in our friendship, but didn't know how to fix it. We apologized for fighting with each other and sympathized for our boy troubles, but it just wasn't the same. I missed her, but the longer it went on, the easier it was to not talk or hang out. Summer came around, and our moms planned for me to stay a week at her house while my parents were on vacation. To put it nicely, I was less than thrilled. How was I supposed to stay a week there when we barely talked anymore? I knew everything would be okay, but I still worried that the week would be filled with constant fighting instead of the usual laughs.    Finally, the day came, and my parents were driving me to her house. As I got there, things were fine. We pretended nothing was going on and had fun. It was that way for a few days. But on the third day, she broke the ice, asking what was wrong and why we don't talk anymore. That day, something amazing happened. We talked about all our feelings and what was upsetting us. It was a little awkward at first, but we got through it together. The fights got less and less because we knew the things that bugged each other, and everything slowly became better than it was before. That talk changed our relationship forever, and I'm so glad she had spoken up when I didn't, or else we wouldn't be as close as we are today.    That day was @DATE1, and it had a huge impact on our friendship. Ever since we got that milestone in our friendship, I knew better how to be more open with other people too. Olivia has taught me so much, but this was among the more important lessons. Laughter is a huge part of any strong relationship, but you also need to be able to share your feelings and be serious when the situation calls for it. Everyone needs a best friend to laugh with, and I am incredibly grateful to have mine stick with me no matter what.

Laughter can change a lot in people. It has the remarkable ability to bring people together, creating a warm and convivial atmosphere. It can also play a crucial role in relationships. Making the other person laugh is always a good thing as it can lighten the mood and strengthen the bond. When you're with your friends, laughter can and will always be there. Well, I know it is with my friends and me. Whether you're in a relationship or a friendship, being able to laugh with that other person is important because it can make you feel more connected to them. If you have a big group of friends that you just met, and you all laugh together, that's even better because then you know you're getting somewhere.   My best friend and I laugh all the time. She can just look at me in a way I only understand, and I'll know what she means, and then we both start laughing. Sometimes, when we stand in a big group of friends and start laughing, they all look at us funny. Then normally we tell them what we're laughing about, but most of the time they don't get it. We only have to bring up one time of hanging out, and if something funny happened, we will start laughing about it again.  In a relationship, as in having a "boyfriend" or "girlfriend", one of the plus sides of things is to make them happy, and laugh, and love to be around you. My boyfriend does it to me. No matter if I'm not in a good mood, he always tries to put a smile on my face, and most of the time it works. If you have a boyfriend or girlfriend, you always wanna try and make them happy. That means girls don't get over the stupid little things. Boys don't get mad when they want to hang out with their friends.   The best way to have a relationship with your boyfriend and your best friend is to make sure they don't hate one another. And if they do, work it out in a way that you could hang out with your boyfriend one day and your best friend the other. My relationship works out amazing because my best friend is dating my boyfriend's best friend. So we can all hang out if we really wanted to and not fight. It's nice to have all of us as friends. That way we can go to the coast together and we can go out to dinner as a group. At this time, we are thinking about planning a trip to the coast and going there for a day, but we're not totally sure though.   I think the best way to have a good relationship full of laughter is to make it your all. Just don't give your whole life to your boyfriend or girlfriend because if you ever break up, you won't have any friends because they won't want to hang out with you anymore because you left them for your boyfriend at the time. So I always try and tell my boyfriend that without making it sound the wrong way. Normally, the guys understand that you have a life too and it doesn't revolve around them. My friend did that once, and she was not happy at all in the relationship. She told me they never laughed together or anything. She was afraid to break up with him though because she would not have any friends because she made him her life.   Laughter can always make you feel better. It's kinda like a healing process. It will always be there. It's just a matter of if someone can make you laugh. There are people that can make you laugh, like comedians and videos and family. When you're with someone that makes you happy, it is like you're full of joy and enjoyment to be around them. You care for them and you feel comfortable around them. If you have struggles and get through them, and they still make you laugh and happy, you will know that they are the one you're happy and can laugh around. Family always makes you laugh whether you don't want to or not. I love my dad. He always knows how to make me laugh. Laughter truly is a precious gift that enriches our lives and relationships.

One Christmas, I was sitting in the living room with my family talking about how every Christmas we always end up laughing. One Christmas, we were out at my great grandpa's house, and we just got done opening our presents. In the middle of the floor was a large, old chest. My cousin, Tommy, thought my dad was inside the chest.   At first, we tried to convince Tommy that my dad was outside talking to my uncle. Tommy didn't believe us, even though my dad was clearly outside talking. Tommy circled the chest, and observed it closely and was convinced my dad was in it. Then Tommy started poking the chest. We were laughing because it was so cute that Tommy thought my dad was in the chest. He kept saying "I know he is in there." Tommy opened the chest, and my dad was not in there. My dad walked into the house and asked why we were laughing. We told him the story, and he started laughing too.  Later on in the evening, Tommy was playing in the other room and wanted to show my dad the toy he was playing with. So my dad climbed in the chest, and we told Tommy that my dad was outside. Tommy went outside to look for him, but my dad wasn't there. When Tommy came inside, he looked in every room and could not find my dad. After a while, Tommy was standing by the chest, and my dad jumped out and scared Tommy. Tommy screamed like a little girl, and we all laughed really hard. Tommy was mad at first, then he started laughing too. At the time, Tommy was only five, so when my dad jumped out at him, he got really scared.  Tommy thought it would be funny to scare my dad, so he hid in the chest. My dad came inside, and we told my dad to look for Tommy. My dad called his name, looked in every room, and pretended like he couldn't find Tommy. Tommy started laughing because my dad acted like he was going to sit on him, and it made him laugh super hard. When Tommy got out of the chest, he was like "how did you know I was in the chest?" My dad said "well, you started laughing, silly goose."   Out of all the Christmases I have had, that Christmas was the best Christmas ever. That was the time laughter brought two people together, and it created memories that will last a lifetime.

While you begin to make any kind of relationship with anyone, you are usually going to start off making jokes and being silly. Whether you're trying to be flirty with them or just be the funny one and make a good, first impression. Usually, all of these things lead to someone laughing; even if they really didn't have a reason to. Anyone who is shy around new people will most likely laugh about anything they say. If it's someone you already knew, you could always be giggling about something. There are different types of relationships you build with different people, and laughter is almost always the number one way to keep it together.  When you have been in a strong friendship with someone, you are already very close with each other. The laughing, crying, and fighting you do with that person will make the relationship stronger. There are times that you spend with another individual that will make steps towards sticking together. From my experiences, I will become someone's close friend for quite some time; then we will get into an argument and no longer be friends. Although we fought and wished to not talk, we became good friends again because of all the time we had spent laughing together. Being sad all the time, with no one else to laugh with, made us realize how much we missed each other. Even though meeting someone new was simple, it didn't last as long as the friendship I had with the other person.  Truly, when you meet someone for the first time, whether it's a boy or a girl, you will laugh and make jokes almost the whole time. That might even be how it will stay. Once you have known a person for so long, you can tell what type of relationship you will have with them. The connection you make with them is simple; you could get along, or you could always argue. No matter what relationship you make with an acquaintance, it will most likely be the same all the time. When you are not as close with another person, you tend to not care about the friendship as often. You won't be as emotional, although your experiences you have with them could always lead to laughing. The time you spend with anyone should always be full of fun and laughter.  Another form of laughter could be spent with a boyfriend or girlfriend. In my opinion, you will make a special connection with your other half. When two people have chosen to be together, they're choosing to spend their time getting to know each other on a different level. The fun and laughter they will create can put them on a higher level of love than you would have with a best friend. Couples should be enjoying their time together, laughing, and making each other happy. Making each other laugh will allow them to be closer in friendship, becoming comfortable with one another. They will gain more confidence and ability just by sharing the times laughing together.  In conclusion, laughter is the glue that holds all types of relationships together. Whether it's a friendship or a romantic relationship, laughter brings people closer and makes the bond stronger. So, always make sure to fill your time with others with lots of laughter and fun.

What's Laughter if not a smile, a small chunk of happiness like a chocolate chip cookie fresh out of the oven, with chocolate oozing out of the sides like waterfalls. Laughter can come from a joke, an awkward situation, or just about anything. Laughter can be the thing that bonds a friendship. I'm going to tell you a true story surrounding the matter of laughter and how it has been involved in a relationship of my own.  It was my first day of high school. I walked into the school, looking down at my shoes. I could feel the people around me staring at me, but I wasn't sure if I should look back at them and smile or if I should just keep to myself, so I said nothing. I went to the office and asked them how to find drama class. They gave me a map that I had no idea how to read and sent me off. By this time, I was scared. A tall, lanky guy with brown shaggy hair and a flannel jacket bumped into me. Instead of an "I'm sorry" or even a polite "Excuse me", he looked at me disgusted and continued down the hallway.  It took me some time, but I finally found my drama class. The teacher wasn't nice to me. It seemed like she hated everyone. She was kind of rounder and had short blond hair. Her name was Mrs. Jenkins, and she was not in a good mood that day. There was a girl sitting next to me, and she looked just as scared as I felt. During the first few minutes of class, we glanced at each other a few times but said nothing. About half - way through the class, the girl next to me asked my name. I replied "Lily" extremely quietly. As I went to turn away, she grabbed my attention by whispering to me. She chuckled "Hey, look at what she's wearing. What are teachers thinking when they get dressed in the morning?" I started laughing hysterically. The large teacher lurking in front of me said "You two, hallway, now!" I didn't know if laughing was an option, but as soon as I stepped out of that door, a grin crossed my face, and I fell on the floor laughing. I couldn't control myself. Don't get me wrong; I didn't think us getting into trouble was funny, but this bitter teacher was such a disappointment. Drama teachers are supposed to be fun and nice, or so I thought.  The next class period, I walked through the auditorium doors and found myself a seat close to the back, next to Sarah. Mrs. Jenkins was wearing a green top that looked like it had been spattered with baby throw - up, a pair of light blue skinny jeans that did not flatter her body, and a pair of hot pink three - inch high heels. Today she was in a great mood. You could tell by the big fat smile on her face. When anyone talked, she would burn a hole in their foreheads with her eyes. It was like getting stung by a bee on a hot summer day. We would all laugh behind her back, but that's the way we got through her class alive.  After a few minutes of talking, she sent us off to rehearse our first scene. The people in my group were Sarah, my friend Mia who I had met in algebra the day before, and a girl I didn't know named Jasmontae. We all got to know each other quite quickly because we all loved the joys of laughing. Jasmontae was friendly and outgoing, as was Mia. Jasmontae was taller than me by about four inches. She had blond highlights in her hair that were only in her bangs. She was stunningly pretty. Mia was a quiet, keep - to - it - alone type of person. She was about two inches shorter than me and had short black hair. It was straight, as I would quickly learn it always was. She was stylish. She had on the cutest brown belt and shoes that matched it with skinny jeans and a denim jacket. Her whole outfit screamed adorable.  We laughed the whole time, making fun of the teacher and telling jokes. We got barely any work done. That was a day I'll never forget. To this day, I'm still good friends with all three of them, and often we talk about that day and how glad we are that we met. So, as you can see, laughing is a big part of my relationships. It's a great way to make friends, and everyone loves to laugh. Even when you barely

Laughter is a natural reaction every human being has when they are either happy or have heard or seen something that is funny to them. It is healthy to be happy other than sad or mad. Laughter is pretty much a sign of happiness, as crying is of sadness. It is just another natural emotion any person is born with. I agree to the quote someone once said about laughter being the closest distance between two people because, if two people get along, they will have many moments in life together where they are happy. It is easy to get along with people who have a good sense of humor as for they won't take everything personally and can understand a joke. Its always good to have a sense of humor because its something everyone appreciates, also, that way people can see that you like to have fun when you know you don't have to be serious. When your with a group of friends that you get along with very well, one of the main things you will hear is laughter. It shows that you get along and that your having a good time.  Of course there are times when its better not to laugh, or when people laugh for no reason, which often gets annoying. Yes laughing means your happy, but when its not needed and is used just to cause noise, it is better to be quiet than annoy everyone around you. In my group of friends we are always laughing and joking around with each other, i like when people have a good sense of humor, i feel more relaxed and its easier to talk to them. Unless, that is, they take everything as a joke and never take anything seriously. Even though it is natural, you have to know when you can and cant laugh. Its a way to show happiness, but in certain situations, it can be disrespectful or rude.  Sometimes when I'm with my friends, they @MONTH1 joke around about a certain person, and once it happened like this;at my friends birthday party, we all went to a bowling alley and as always, were all standing around talking and having a good time. While we were talking, @PERSON3 and @PERSON4 were joking around about something so we all started listening to their conversation. They were joking around about something and then @PERSON3 said something as to turn him down in some way, ask a joke, and @PERSON4 said that hes going to get his heart broken. Right after that was said, @ORGANIZATION1 pitched in, adding again. So it turned out to sound like @PERSON4 was going to have his heart broken again. As everyone laughed at it, @PERSON4 looked at @ORGANIZATION1 with a hurt expression and was the only one not laughing. You see, @PERSON4 had a girlfriend that broke up with him about two months ago, @ORGANIZATION1 forgot about that and didn't mean anything when she added "again". She meant it as a joke but it turned out to sound very mean. In this case, the laughter caused by @ORGANIZATION1 was meant for @PERSON4, who was hurt by @ORGANIZATION1's comment. Good thing @ORGANIZATION1 noticed and remembered about @PERSON4's ex later that day. She ended up apologizing for saying something she should have thought through more carefully before saying.  How a person takes it when people laugh at them, has a lot to do with friendship. One time, my friends were driving to a party, or home from a party and were listening to music in the car, one of the guys in the car was singing his heard out to a song by @PERSON1. At one point, while he was singing, his best friend suddenly turned down the volume so everyone in the car heard @PERSON2 sing really loud, with no music. Everyone started laughing because @PERSON2 didn't know that @CAPS1 would turn off the music in the middle of something. Even though it was kind of embarrassing, @PERSON2 laughed along because it was pretty funny. If @PERSON2 and @CAPS1 weren't such good friends, i think for sure @PERSON2 would have gotten mad at @CAPS1 for doing such a thing to him while there where other people in the car aside from just them two. Friends understand each others sense of humor, and know when doing something is going to far, or when the other person will think it's funny too and will laugh along. So as you see, laughter can be happy, thankful, annoying, and or mean, you just have to know when it's okay to do, and when it is better not to laugh. Even though it's a natural reaction, it is one that can be controlled and thought about before doing. Next time someone says something that's funny, first think about if it can be insulting to someone before laughing at it and hurting someone. Otherwise, enjoy life and be happy.

I think that laughter is very important. However, the way we use laughter matters a lot. For instance, let's say that a student falls and you laugh at him just because you think it's funny. It's going to hurt that student deeply. I think that instead of laughing at someone, you could be a good kid and ask him if he is okay and help him up. That simple act shows that student that he really has a friend who cares about him a lot and doesn't laugh at his misfortune. You also can get rewarded for doing something good, but to me, it's really not about what I get. It's the things I do to help out my peers. I think that we should not laugh inappropriately and have a positive attitude. We should be mature about what we do, what we say, and how we react to things like laughing at someone else. I also think that if I would have fallen and I got really hurt and kids would start laughing at me, that's when I learn to respect the students the way that I want to be respected. So I wouldn't like people to make fun of me, so why would I like to make fun of someone else if I wouldn't want them to make fun of me? That's why you should treat your peers with respect. By showing respect, we create a more friendly and caring environment where everyone feels valued and supported.

Laughter is such a great joy in my life. If people never laughed, life would be dull and boring. Most of my favorite experiences involve laughter while having a good time. One of my best experiences with laughter was going camping with my friends last summer. I will never forget that experience last summer. During the middle of summer on a beautiful sunny Saturday afternoon, my close friend calls me and tells me he's getting a bunch of guys to go camping and I should come. Immediately I ask my parents to let me go with the only exception of turning in my job application to the local store before I left for camping. After turning in my application, I got in the car, picked up my buddy and the makings for peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, and left for the adventure. After I got to my destination after driving 30 miles up river, I didn't see anyone, just two huge tents where my friends were supposed to be. Looking around, the camp site had been attacked by bears with trash laying all around and the camp fire still going. I started searching for my friends. I found my friend passed out in one of the tents and tried to wake him but he was dead asleep. My buddy and I, not knowing what to do, so we sat in the shade of the large trees surrounding us. It was a good 80 degrees outside. After about five minutes, we heard a splash and went to investigate. We walked towards the river and found all of our friends jumping off a 15 ft rock into the river and we went to join the fun. After jumping off about 5 times each, we headed back to camp. My friend was awake and all of us, including some other friends, huddled around the camp fire when we returned to camp and told jokes all night. All of us really bonded that three - day camping trip, laughing and joking and just being boys. I wouldn't get rid of those memories for anything. After camping, I returned home and worked a lot of the rest of the summer but ever since then have had really good friendships with all of my camping buddies.

Once upon a time on a sunny Saturday, I had my birthday party and my friends came over. My friend Tree brought his projector over and hooked his gaming console to it. We played a really exciting game: Call of Duty on his projector and on my big - screen TV with my gaming console. Then we got bored and all of us went out into the living room with the girls and chilled and hung out for a while. Then we had cake, had an icing fight, and played games. We laughed so hard that our stomachs hurt. Then we went to the park that was by our apartment. We played frisbee and made jokes and laughed a lot more. Then we went back to my place and we watched a scary movie, Scream 3, and laughed at the people who screamed. Then we played spin the bottle/truth or dare and we laughed a lot. This birthday party was truly filled with so much fun and laughter that I'll always cherish these memories.

The only true story that I can remember that involves laughter was about 5 years ago at the beach. I was with my mom and my sister at the local beach. I was running from incoming waves when I decided to run into just one wave. That wave swept me off my feet and spun me around for what seemed like forever, but wasn't even 10 seconds. I laughed so hard that I tripped and started spinning again. My mom had to get me up because I could not stop laughing. I got so many cuts from the sand that it was hilarious. After I got changed, I got a big chest that my dad could fit inside it. That's the only time I remember laughter being my true friend. It was a moment of pure, unadulterated joy that I'll always hold dear in my heart.

My freshman year of high school started off less favorable than most. During the end of my eighth - grade year, I found that my friends were not as loyal as I believed they were at the beginning of our friendship, and in turn, started high school without any. It wasn't all bad because I was able to see things for myself for one of the first times in my life. Of course, I sulked but looking back on it now, I am appreciative of this time that helped me get to know myself better. However, one can't go through life without any friends, so I quickly tried to conform to what was considered 'normal'. I had some luck from the start, but I was still scorned from being deserted by all the people who I once considered friends and in turn took these new acquaintances as little more than just that - acquaintances. Like most acquaintances, we only spoke in class and kept the conversation casual about nothing more than trivial facts. I wanted to have 'real' friends, but I wasn't sure what a real friend was. I suppose that these so - called acquaintances considered me a friend though I can never be sure whether or not this is true. So I continued through my days with a person to talk to in each class but no one to sit with at lunch. This circumstance, however, was made a bit more bearable because my sister still attended the high school at this point. Her presence made my life slightly easier because I could confide in her and even eat lunch with her. People who have always had friends might not understand, but when you have nowhere to sit at lunch it can be kind of lonely. Fortunately, my sister was always there for me, though she did skip a lot of school. And whenever she wasn't there, I could rely on her friends to keep me company. I found that even if I couldn't find my own friends, I could always share my sister's. This nomad existence continued until the second trimester of my freshman year. I had all new classes and felt as if it was a new beginning and anything could happen, and truly anything I could imagine did. It started out the same as the trimester before had. I went to my first couple of classes and gained more acquaintances like usual and felt as if things might not change after all. However, after five minutes of sitting alone in my apparel construction class, two girls walked in and sat at my table. Their conversation caught my attention and held it. I knew that it was wrong to listen to others' conversations, but I figured that if they didn't want me to hear they would have spoken quietly. Though I can't recall the actual subject of the conversation now, I remember it was a hilarious topic. Even though I took no part in the discussion, I couldn't help but be overcome with laughter as the two spoke. They then began to laugh so hard which resulted in tears filling their eyes. In turn, my eyes also began to fill with tears from the extreme amounts of laughter. One of the two girls looked over at me and told her friend out loud to "look at her, she's laughing so hard at you she's crying!" I could hardly stop laughing long enough to introduce myself. Before I knew it, we became close friends and it was all due to the amazing powers of laughter that can bring two strangers together into best friends. This experience taught me that sometimes, laughter can be the key to finding true friendship.

I'm going to tell you a story of smiles, laughter, and love. The story of my summer and how I changed a girl's life and my own with only smiles and laughs. I have three major memories of my time with her, there was the first smile, the day at the beach, and the evening at the park. Starting with the beginning, these memories are about me and my neighbor's exchange student, Person1, and they are memories, they are not perfect. The evening I made Person1 smile. It was a cool Friday evening out on the back lawn of my grandmother's house which overlooks the national park gorge, perfect for watching the firework show. The lawn was even inclined so that you don't have to sit up straight. My friend and Person1 came over to sit with me as I waited for the show. Person1 sat to the left of me and my neighbor and life - long friend, to the right. I was very curious about Person1, what she was like, what part of Europe she lived in, how were her costumes different than ours. So I started to ask her some questions as we waited. I didn't get much. It was obvious that she was shy, very shy. Finally, I got a conversation going between the three of us about the fireworks that had started. Person1 was telling us how the fireworks back home in her country were much bigger than ours. Of course, me being sarcastic, I said "Really?" She just smiled. The rest of the evening, the conversations flowed much freer between me and Person1 and it was a wonderful evening. Next, we have the day at the beach. This happened about a month later for the second memory. Person1 and I were good friends and she had lost her shyness and I was starting to really like her. We arrived at the beach down on the local shore. It was starting to become a hot day, a perfect day for the beach. We unpacked the towels and other random beach stuff. Soon all of us were in the water, Person1, my friend (Person1's host sister), her boyfriend, and me. In a bit of a flirting mood, I started to splash Person1 who happened to be by my friend. This started a very large splash war with everyone splashing everyone else. Everyone was laughing and having a great time. It abruptly stopped because everyone didn't want water in their face any more. Soon thereafter, I dove under the water and tried to lift Person1 up and then drop her in the water. It ultimately failed though because I missed and only caught her right leg. Nothing happened, just more and more laughter. That was a good wet day at the beach. Finally, my third memory is the evening at the park. We had just finished eating dinner and it was Person1's last evening in the town. By now we were practically boyfriend - girlfriend. It was getting dark at the local park as we arrived at the park for Movies in the Park. A popular movie was playing that evening. I found a good spot and set out the blanket. We lay there talking as we waited for the movie to start. I had a flashback of all the laughs that had brought us close together. I knew at that moment that I was really going to miss her more than I had missed anyone before. It felt like the right moment as the sun was setting over the valley. I leaned in and kissed her and she kissed right back. I'll spare you the rest. Afterward, we laughed and cried. For she was leaving early the next morning and we were in love. Yes, I used the 'L' word but it was and is true. We absolutely did not want the movie to end and yet it still did. As I drove her back to her host family's house, we talked about the amazing summer we had together and all the smiles and laughs we shared. I smiled and laughed a lot that summer and it did bring me very close to someone. Person1 and I still talk nearly every day. It is hard but I've never felt as close to her as anyone else. I was about ten when this story happened to me. I was with my grandma at the local park when the story unfolded. We were at the park and I, being curious as a ten - year - old, put my head in the monkey bars. My grandma had went to the bathroom and I was stuck in the monkey bars. The kids at the park, seeing my predicament, thought it was funny and were laughing at me. I felt my face flush with embarrassment, my ears burning. When I finally managed to get my head out of the monkey bars, I told the kids that they should try putting their heads in the monkey bars. The other kids, not thinking twice, tried doing it and they all got their heads stuck in the monkey bars. The kids did not know that I had secretly practiced putting my head in the monkey bars so that it would not get stuck. I was laughing very hard at what I had just done and when my grandma came out I asked if we could go home. The next day we went back to the park and I pulled the same trick on some different kids. What I don't get is if my head was stuck why would they try the same thing. The kids this time told their mom and dad what I did and they told my grandma and I got in a lot of trouble. We went home and I was grounded for about two weeks. The next time I went to the park I did the same thing. That shows that kids will be kids, always up to some mischief and learning from their experiences in their own way.

Friendship and Laughter go hand in hand. @CAPS3 best friend and I would spend hours sitting on her soft, cozy bed laughing at nothing. So I said goodbye. @CAPS3 best friends name is @CAPS4, we have known each other since we were two and have been inseparable since then. We love to hang out and be together. That was until the fight where I was told that she had been telling lies about a boy and I. I remember the hurt and how disappointing it was to hear that she would do that to me. But I didn't care enough to ask her about it, so I ended the friendship. It hurt but I had talked myself into believing that it was all true. But something didn't feel right, something told me that it wasn't her. But I didn't want to hear it. I ignored the feeling and just went on with life. I missed talking to her, so one day I said hello, after that we talked non - stop, it was like nothing had ever happened between us. Except there was one thing missing, the laughter. Since then we have become closer, we hadn't talked about the fight, but it got to the point to where we could occasionally laugh or giggle at something one of us had said, but never the kind of the laughs that we used to share. I never thought that we would have been able to speak, nevertheless be friends again.  After a few weeks we both signed up for a youth camp. During that camp I found out the truth. We talked about the whole ordeal and came to the agreement that the whole fight had been both of our faults. Mine because I didn't want to know the truth, and hers because she didn't try hard enough to show me the truth. During that talk we shed a few tears and for the first time in about four months actually laughed together. The tension between us broke and fell off our shoulders like a very heavy pack that we both had been carrying. We both apologized for our parts in everything and then went to dinner, and laughed throughout the meal. I realize now that I can't take laughter for granted, it's a very important piece of life and you laugh the most when you are with people you love. Sam and I are still working things out between us but we are on our way to being closer than ever. We laugh all the time and never have a dull moment, we have both decided to work very hard at not having another fight between us. We have both realized that there are two very important things in life and they are friendship and laughter inside of the friendship. I love @CAPS3 best friend very much and I love the laughter that we share together just as much, and I will always cherish these precious moments in our friendship.

I personally do believe that laughter is an incredibly important element in any relationship. After all, who doesn't enjoy a good bout of laughter every once in a while? I know I certainly do. My true story revolves around the relationship between my @NUM1 - year - old toddler daughter and me. I'll share why I think laughter is important, how it plays a role, its significance in my relationships, and the benefits I believe it can bring to anyone's relationships. Everyone should take a moment to smile and just laugh, forgetting about the things that make them frown, so they can turn that frown upside down.  My relationship with @PERSON1 (my @NUM1 - year - old) is filled with mixed emotions at all times and is constantly evolving. The emotions range from pure happiness and admiration to anger, frustration, and a great deal of stress. Of course, despite these different feelings, I love her with every fiber of my being. But during those moments when I'm so stressed out that I feel like screaming, she'll say the funniest thing or make the most adorable face. And it's impossible not to smile and laugh, which, I must say, makes all the difficulties fade away for that brief moment.  The most cold, angry, and hurtful people in the world rarely laugh. They isolate themselves and struggle to form good relationships with others. We all need a bit of laughter to avoid falling into depression and sadness. If you're always frowning and stressed out, there won't be any room to focus on the good things and just have a good laugh. When @PERSON1 does her little thing and it makes me laugh, then she laughs too, and we're all in better moods. She knows that mommy still loves her, and she knows just the right ways to make me smile. I just want to pick her up and give her a big squeeze.  Because at the end of the day, when you reflect on all the events of your day, whether good or bad, there really isn't anything you can do but laugh. And that makes your whole day worthwhile. It doesn't necessarily have to be your children who make you laugh; it can be any relationship with anyone. Maybe it's your relationship with your boyfriend, and you've been together for a long time. You guys laugh, right? Because, honestly, how could you stand being with someone all the time, claiming to love them, yet never sharing a laugh with them? If they never make you laugh, it just doesn't seem right. No relationship can truly be a good one without some laughter, especially if it's someone you love and are with constantly. The good things in life should outweigh the bad, so the more laughter, the better.  I know that parenting is extremely stressful, especially as a teen mom. And when she puts that smile on my face, I forget about my stresses for that moment, and it makes everything better. I'd like to give an example of when laughter really made a difference in my day, even my whole week. You know those days when nothing goes right, you're arguing with your parents or boyfriend or whoever, and you've just been feeling miserable all day and all week. You haven't laughed, smiled, or had any fun because the past couple of days have just been dragging on with the same old routines. Then, the weekend arrives, and I find a babysitter and go hang out with a friend or two. We all get together and start reminiscing about old memories, both good and bad, the ones that make you embarrassed or the ones that make you want to cry. But then we get to that story that always makes us burst out laughing if told the right way. And we're all laughing for what seems like hours (but really, it's only been @NUM3 minutes). Finally, we're forced to stop laughing because we're laughing so hard that we start crying, and our stomachs hurt as if we've done fifty crunches. It hurts so much, yet we feel so good. Then we just lie there, catching our breath. The only noise we hear is an occasional sputter of a laugh coming out of someone's mouth every thirty seconds or so.  So, all - in - all, that's how I view laughter and why I think it's important in everyone's lives. When you're sad, it will lift your spirits. And when you're stressed out, it helps you forget about the bad things and focus on the good for a moment. When you've had the worst week of your life, and then you finally get to have a weekend with the girls and laugh your heart out, you feel like a new person. Laughter is good for the soul, and it even exercises some kind of muscle in your stomach, I think. It doesn't matter who you are or what the issue is; laughter will make you feel better and help you forget the bad things.

I believe laughter has the remarkable ability to bring many different people together. In my friendships, my friends and I are always laughing about the random, silly things that happen to us each day. Laughter is an essential part of any friendship or relationship.  One particular time when laughter made a huge difference was during fourth grade. Fourth grade brought a roller - coaster of ups and downs that none of us had anticipated. My friends and I had a huge fight over the smallest of reasons. This fight involved my best friend @PERSON2, my neighbor @PERSON1, @PERSON3, and @PERSON4. We were all very close until this fight, which was over my favorite sport, @CAPS1, and @CAPS2. Everyone took sides; @PERSON4 sided with @PERSON2, and I was left all alone. @PERSON1 and @PERSON3 didn't take sides; they just wanted us to get along. It was especially hard for @DATE2 and me because we were best friends and did everything together. All the students in our class were shocked to see us having such a big fight.  @PERSON3 and @PERSON1 tried their best to hang out with both of us, but @LOCATION1 and I didn't feel that way. We thought they were never spending time with us. Soon enough, our teacher and student teacher called our parents to inform them about the fight. I remember that almost every other day, someone would go home in tears. Our parents had a meeting with our teachers and the principal to figure out how they could help us. They decided that @PERSON2, @PERSON1, and I would go to see a counselor. @PERSON3, however, was excused from seeing the counselor. We found this out when our teacher announced it to the whole class. As @PERSON1 recalls, "That was the first time, in a long time, you and @PERSON2 actually talked!" I don't really remember talking, but I guess change was starting to happen.  When we went to the counselor, she was incredibly nice and spoke to us in a way that made us all feel at ease. She asked us what we missed most about our friendship, and all three of us answered with laughter. We said that we used to laugh every day, but now we went home crying. She asked if we liked to play games during our time together, and we said yes. She let us play games like monopoly, which was a lot of fun. At the end of the day, the three of us went back to class smiling and laughing. When we entered the classroom, everyone was surprised to see us getting along.  After school, I went home, and my mom asked me how the counseling session had gone. I smiled and said we'd all had a great time! The next day, the three of us went back to the counselor and played more games. During this session, we also had to write a paper about how the fight had changed us. When we were done writing, we read the papers to each other. All of them had the same message: I wish this had never happened, I miss the laughing, and I will laugh about this fight in the future. To a large extent, this message was very true. @DATE1, @PERSON1, @PERSON2, and I are still best friends. Yes, we tell this story to everyone and laugh every time. Most of our friends are either shocked that we had a fight or just laugh at how silly the fight was. When they ask what the moral of the story is, we simply say, "Don't let any little thing get in the way of your friendship and remember to laugh about the good times." In many ways, laughing about this silly fight has brought us closer and kept our friendship strong. Now, we have even more things to laugh about.  Every friendship has its ups and downs, and along with those come moments of laughter or tears. In the end, the only way to strengthen your bond with your friends is to laugh. Don't miss out on a single moment or second - guess a change in your friendship. Your friends will always be by your side on the journey of life, and laughter is the key to a lasting and happy friendship.

Quietly, I turned over my shoulder, trying to catch more of the story. As soon as her friend said this, the girl's face blushed and she started to giggle with laughter. @CAPS1, still, her eyes were red as she sniffled a little. @CAPS1, a slow smile gradually washed over her face. The woman had more of a giggle than a full - blown laugh. @CAPS1, you could tell the girl was going to be okay because she had someone to make her laugh and remember that life is more than just a guy.  I thought for a second how this kind of situation happens more often than you might think, especially with my best friend. I feel like even after seven years have passed, it never gets old when we burst out laughing. Most of the time, it's something silly, and we're just strangely thinking the same thing. @CAPS1, then there are other times where it will be like the situation of the ladies behind me. One of us is upset, and we know exactly the perfect thing to say to each other. Friendship is like that. And laughter is the medicine for any problem.  After watching the two women, I turned to face the front of me. Now I saw a teenage boy and girl. The girl looked slightly nervous as she kept smoothing out her skirt. The boy, on the other hand, kept shaking his knee up and down. You could tell he was trying to think of something to say while he kept taking quick sips from his water bottle. The girl finally pointed out the window and said something about when she was a girl, she would play soccer there. He looked where she was pointing and said he thought he maybe played baseball there one time. She nodded her head, and they fell silent again.  The train came to its next stop, jerking a little, which made the boy spill some of his water on his pants. The girl quickly pulled some tissues out of her purse and gave them to the boy. His cheeks flushed red as he started to chuckle and explained how nervous he was and that this wasn't going to help. The girl stared at him and quickly started to smile. Then they both began to look at each other and started to laugh. The boy's laugh was deep and echoed across the train, while the girl's was contagious and sweet. Now the ice had been broken because of one awkward moment, and they were both talking and laughing. This could potentially be the start of young love.  I smiled and rested my head on the window, watching the trees blur by. I knew how our world is often described as being so melancholy, but I think people forget moments like this. It's those brief seconds when you connect with another human, when they make you laugh and care enough to try to make you feel better that keeps our world from completely going insane. The train slams and starts to slow down as it comes to a stop. I slung my bag onto my shoulder and got off the train. As I stepped outside, I felt the cool air gently kiss my cheeks. I looked around and saw people hurrying by me, looking for their next bus or the person to pick them up. I sat down on the bench and watched the teenage couple holding hands as they walked by me. As they smiled and talked, everything suddenly went dark. I threw my hands up to my eyes and felt another big, cold hand. I quickly snapped around to see the person who had blinded me. It was my dad, smiling from ear to ear. I stood up on the bench and hugged him as I started to laugh. My laugh was high - pitched and muffled in my dad's coat. This was the best type of laugh to me. There was no particularly funny action or a friend saying something specific. It was just because I was so happy that I just had to let out a little bit of joy. You just laugh, not for any particular reason, just because you're happy. And then in that second, everything bad or what you were stressed about just fades away. Maybe just for a little while, but it's still something that can make your whole day better.

I love looking back at pictures from when I was little, having memories with best friends and their animals, as @CAPS2 as taking trips and just being with my boyfriend. Laughing has helped me a lot in life because it brings me up when I am feeling down.

Laughter is the @CAPS1 @CAPS2't @CAPS6 frustrating when you can't manage to get someone to laugh? Is @CAPS6 really possible to be so upset that you can't even crack a little smile?
