The cars passing by honked at us, and not in a friendly way. But honestly, we didn't care at all. We were having so much fun that we didn't even think about the other people.  In conclusion, laughter is an essential part of a relationship. Without it, our squad wouldn't have half the funny and unforgettable memories we do. That night, with all its crazy events like getting locked out of the bus, getting kicked out of @ORGANIZATION2, and the wild @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @CAPS3, will forever be etched in our minds.

From the moment of birth until young adulthood, kids are nurtured and guided by their guardians or parents. It is the solemn responsibility of parents to instill good morals, impart life skills, and teach their children how to cope and thrive in society. @CAPS24 parenting children involves being firm and strictly enforcing rules. The positive outcome of this approach is that the child grows up well - prepared to lead their adult lives outside the home.  Even though I'm still a teenager, I've learned a great deal about raising kids. My knowledge mainly comes from the stories passed down to me by my parents and grandparents about their life lessons. I find it incredibly enjoyable to be "in on" these small yet significant bits of family history. While many facts about the "good old days" are fascinating, it's the memories filled with laughter that my family shares that are the most precious to me.  My @CAPS1 grew up in the @DATE1's in a small but typical - sized house with her @CAPS1, @CAPS3, and four brothers and sisters. The stories my @CAPS1 loves to tell about her childhood mainly revolve around the memories made at the dinner table. It was her @CAPS5's (my @CAPS6's) noble goal for his children to learn proper manners and standard etiquette. The @PERSON3 children were expected to practice this by remaining calm, courteous, and mindful of their physical actions when gathered around the table for dinner. For an average, fun - loving, and not - so - formal @CAPS7 family, this was quite a challenge.  Throughout their childhood, my @CAPS1 and her siblings tried their utmost to behave and follow the rules at the dinner table. The one thing that particularly annoyed my @CAPS6 was when someone spilled their milk. This seemed to happen almost every single night. The milk spills were either the result of a child being playful or reaching too far to grab the butter dish. Whatever the cause, it was always hysterically funny when it occurred. The catch was that laughing at the table was frowned upon as it disrupted the formal atmosphere the family aimed for during the evening meal. Both laughing and spilling milk were actions that were not encouraged at the dinner table.  As the children grew older, milk spills didn't happen as frequently, but they didn't completely disappear from the dinner - table scene. One memorable night, it wasn't my @CAPS1 or any of her siblings who spilled their milk. Instead, it was my @CAPS6. When the incident first happened, the whole family was in a state of shock. Everyone quickly donated their napkins to clean up the mess, while their @CAPS3 maintained a composed but slightly annoyed expression. After the mess was cleaned up, the family resumed their meal, and on my @CAPS6's face, there was a subtle yet noticeable grin.  Years later, my @CAPS1 (@PERSON4), @PERSON1, @CAPS15 @CAPS16, @PERSON2, and @PERSON2 @CAPS17 grew up, got married, and some even started their own families. Most of my @CAPS1's family lives in @LOCATION2, so they love coming up to visit their @CAPS1 and @CAPS3 (my @CAPS21 and @CAPS6) during the holidays or whenever they can. When the entire family gets together in @LOCATION1, there are hardly any somber or serious moments at the dinner table. As my @CAPS3 would say, "@CAPS24 we laugh so hard that tears run down our legs." I believe that the fun we have together is due to the strong bond of love that connects us all, and this bond would not be as strong without the element of laughter. My @CAPS6, who is now in heaven with @CAPS21, successfully achieved his goal of preparing his children for life. Now that they are all grown up, they can relax, enjoy each other's company, and freely burst into laughter, even if there's a small risk of someone spilling their milk again.
Laughter is the gateway to happiness, and happiness is the key to a fulfilling life. When you laugh, it's like a warm, comforting embrace from within

When I think of laughter, I think back to the wonder years. Although the memories are foggy, I can still recall the times where I whole - heartedly believed friendship had no end and that laughter was the common cure to every battle. Thinking back to the summer when I was twelve, I remember those wild adventures pushing me upward towards the sky. Free - spirited and lacking a sense of reality, I was an unstoppable soul. I wasn't alone though. Through adventures and explorations, I found a trustworthy opponent. Her name was Lily and she was my best friend. Lily lived out in the country, where the grass grew tall and the land came in vast acres. Through thick forests and gurgling streams, you could find our hideaway from the world; We called it our wonderland. Now, the small stream with a rickety bridge is nothing but a forgotten place. On a typical sunny afternoon in July, I drove up the long dirt road to Lily's house. Walking in her front door, I automatically smelled fresh cinnamon scones drizzled with honey. The sweet smell sent shivers up my spine. Lily came down the stairs and greeted me with a warm hug. She wore her long, dark hair in braids and was wearing a white sundress that fluttered in the breeze. Her brown, shimmering skin glittered against the sunlight and her dark brown eyes sent me a happy glare. I envied her with my heart and soul. Next to her, I was just the simple, blond girl with a blotchy skin tone. In one moment, she fled to the window and looked out at the perfect, blue sky. "Wow, finally summer has come along," she whispered and then exploded, "Another day spent with grumpy, sleepless peers and no more stuffy classrooms or annoying teachers. It's the first day of many!" We burst into laughter as I made fun of her poetic outburst, but we both knew every word of it was true. Sighing, I looked at her breathtaking dress one last time and ran out to the field in her backyard. Lily grabbed a red cardigan and followed me, holding a basket in her hand as if she were little red riding hood. I frolicked through the meadow like I was a radiant fox chasing after its prey. When I stopped for breath, I encountered the wind blowing the tall, wispy grass in rhythmic motions around me. Racing towards our secret place, I looked back only once to find Lily. As I turned towards my destination again, a branch met my vision and knocked me down painfully. Blood trickled down my chin and left crimson droplets of blood in the green grass. I breathed in, choking on the salty fluid and then realized she was standing there. Like a worried hare, Lily sprang to my side and helped me to the house. We made our way into the upstairs bathroom. Standing at her bathroom sink, I wept small tears. In the mirror I could see a belligerent - looking girl with a bloody slash across her chin and red, misted eyes. The pain was sharp and made me cry; it was my appearance that had me down. People would ask for days "What's on your face" and "Oh no! How did that happen?" Lily came to my side and squeaked, "Hey, how are you?" My face turned to a bright shade of red in a way that I might explode. I turned to Lily and in one fluid breath I burst out, "Terrible! Wonderful! Ecstatic! Before this, I had a boring, simple look going. Now, I will look even worse with this terrible blemish! I hate how gorgeous you are Lily. You are exotic, distinguished and everything about you seems extremely, perfect!" My friend just stood there and took in every word. A confused look came across her face but slowly turned to a crooked grin. Suddenly, Lily burst out into laughter. Embarrassed, I walked to the door wanting to leave that very second, but she grew silent and took hold of my arm. Shaking her off, I continued down the stairs. "Wait," she called out to me, "I'm not agreeing with you in any way. Hey, you just have a small cut across your chin, but you have always been beautiful and I feel like a simple, field mouse next to you. The way your blond, thin hair becomes perfect ringlets and the way your freckles highlight your amazing, turquoise eyes. I have always been jealous of you! That's why I'm laughing!" I took this in for a second and then erupted into laughter. Racing up the stairs, I came to her with a big, bear hug and laughed some more. Everything I had ever thought about her beauty and mine wasn't at all relevant. Having thought this, the pain of my cut became apparent to me. Lee, her dad, fixed me up with his sewing skills and with each stitch, I laughed along with Lily to get through the pain. Seven stitches and a nasty scar, remind me every day that laughter gets you through the worst while friendship builds an everlasting bond.

The wind rose and fell, whipping against the side of the house with full force. My mom said she had never seen such a fierce storm before in her life. It shook the house making it creak in odd places, like the old floor boards that groaned under the pressure. My aunt, uncle, and cousins sat at the kitchen table contemplating, worrying. They had rental houses acres off that were surrounded by trees. The ground was so soft and so saturated by the heavy rain and flooding that had taken over the valley. There were already hundreds of trees that had come uprooted and there were bound to be more. The little homesteads that rested off of County Road 101 including my papa's were well - built, weathered farm houses. Most were surrounded by hundreds and hundreds of acres of land. You would be surprised to find someone out there with less than 50 acres of land. It's mostly wheat fields, but you can easily find fields of corn, alfalfa, and you'll find rows and rows of blueberries so big only 3 can fit on the palm of your hand. It is literally paradise on earth, a small piece of heaven that was thrown down to earth by either accident or purposely. The sun is so bright and the sky is the clearest, most crisp blue. When weather rolls in, giant fluffy clouds make the sky look like it's dappled with giant pieces of cotton. All this stretches over land so flat you wonder if it could possibly be real. I have spent so many wonderful, laughter - filled summers there. Running barefoot through the fields, playing in the large expansion of lush, green grass. Feeding the goats, chickens, and pigs with my siblings. On that fateful day, my mom said she had never seen a place so beautiful turn so ugly in such a short period of time. My mom says if she had known what was going to happen that day she never would have let them get in that car. My papa, aunt, and cousin pulled out of the driveway. Since it was a small car, my aunt volunteered to ride in the back. The storm had been showing its vicious temper for over two hours, and it showed no signs of letting up. They had set out to see what damage had been done on their acres of land, to see what needed fixing once this storm moved on over the mountains. There is no explanation, no one understood why my cousin walked away with not even a scratch on his body. No one knows how the tree fell or why it only landed on the back end of the car, but it did. God's hand had swept down and caused destruction. My aunt was killed instantly, my papa was seriously injured but alive. He spent weeks in the hospital, during those weeks the news of the accident spread like wildfire as news does in a small town. Everyone loved my aunt; she was a social butterfly that fluttered from person to person, laughing, talking, sharing tears, and joy. She knew everybody, and everybody knew her. The heavens cried and howled that day, rain drops fell so heavily it felt as if the whole world was crying, crying just to share your grief. It's painful, to lose someone so dear to your heart. My papa cried, he sobbed until he had no strength left to feel any emotion at all. He loved her so much, he needed her. Lightning struck the giant oak that stood tall and proud in my papa's backyard that day. It was the same tree that held my grandparents' initials. The lightning split the top of the giant oak clean in two. Everyone saw it as a symbol, a sign of how my papa and aunt had been struck apart quickly and forcefully. But, days before my papa returned home from the hospital, my dad climbed that giant oak and chained the severed part back together. With that, my dad had made a symbol of his own, saying you will always be together just not physically, but you will never be truly apart. The day my papa returned home he saw the giant oak, and for the first time in weeks a glimmer of understanding shone in his eyes. A small amount of hope had settled over everything once again. Her funeral was a nice affair, elegant, simple, beautiful, just like her. The whole town came, they reminisced for hours, telling stories about my aunt and her crazy yet lovable nature. Then from across the room it came. Small at first then growing ever louder. Laughter. A smile, yes there were tears with that laughter, but it was laughter all the same. I've never seen the saying "laughter is the best medicine" put to justice better. My aunt was one person who saw laughter, love, faith, and hope as necessities in life. She brought joy to so many people, and now they were returning the favor.

When we were little it was watching cartoons. In junior high, it was seeing a kid squirt milk out through his nose. But now as we approach our high school years, we stifle giggles, suppress outbursts, and laugh until we cry, for our own reasons; and we can't hold back the inevitable urge to laugh. Some say laughing is the best medicine, unfortunately for my sister and I, this was not the case; laughing just got us in more trouble. No matter how many times we were lectured, someone always found their way back into the other one's room purely because we were nosy. I remember back a few summers ago, I'd seen Sarah, my sister, putting a bag of chocolate under her mattress. There was a possibility it was gone, but I had no doubt in my mind that it was still there. But as the mattress was lifted up and as I was beginning to reach for it, the bed was shoved back down, very nearly smashing my fingers. There stood Sarah with a vindictive look in her eyes and two hands placed on her hips. What could I say? What could I do? A shrill scream escaped my lips and I bolted for the door before she could unleash her wrath upon me. Up the stairs, around the couch, through the kitchen I ran; but not fast enough. Before I could lock myself in the bathroom, she caught my ponytail and yanked, hard. I was in for a nine - year - old, hair - pulling, all - out beating. But lucky me, no more harm could be done because my mom had heard my scream and had come to investigate. Fighting was taboo in our house, but that never stopped us. Mom's punishments were minuscule, we could hug and make up, or stand in the corner. The anger in Sarah's eyes was already gone, and a certain, significant smile played across her lips. Mom was still trying to play the strict parent, but to us, the past four minutes were just a joke now. "Stop," she had said, one word, one meaning, that's all it took. We exploded in a roar of giggles and laughter. Although there was no way Mom could have known this, we meant no disrespect, but we couldn't keep silent. Boisterous laughs rang through the hallway, so loud, Mom's words were inaudible. Grabbing our hands and pulling us towards the living room we were half - dragged because we were shaking so hard. Ten feet apart we stood, eyes focused on the ninety - degree angle in front of our noses. But one look at each other and sent another tremor of giggles through our little bodies. We could have been inebriated if you didn't know any better, but really we were just two rambunctious kids playing around. We all have our reasons to laugh. Maybe your reason is as simple as reading an e - mail that made you laugh so hard you cried. Maybe it is because my amateur writing style is a joke to you, or maybe you too have just witnessed a child's nose spew chocolate milk. We all have things in our life that make us want to roll on the floor, or slap our knees; but from my experience it's excruciatingly hard to hold back, so let it out.

When my friend Lisa and I went to go hang out with our friends from the local park. We knew how we would get there but we didn't know how we were going to get back, but knowing us we didn't care; we just wanted to have fun. We had lots of fun hanging out but then it started getting dark and we needed a ride back home. Later on I decided to call my dad to see if he would come and get us. Knowing my dad, he thought it was really funny that my friend and I were stuck in the park, so he started laughing. After he was still laughing I asked, "So can you come get us cause it's getting ready to be dark?" and he said no, because it's not his fault that I was stuck there. So Lisa said, "Why don't I call my dad to see if he would?" and so she did but just like my dad he also started laughing and said no. Later on Lisa and I ran out of people to call. So we said to each other, "Why don't we worry about this later? It's really not that dark and we can all still hang out for a while longer

It was a normal sunny day in the country hill's of @ORGANIZATION1. The sun was out and shineing on the creek that me, my twin brother and my best friend were swimming in. The creek was fantastic. It was a deep swimming hole that all the neighborhood kids would swim in. Since all the other kids were either too old and busy to swim, or they were too young it was just us three that swam in the creek that @DATE1. We loved it. It helped cool us down during the heat of the day. We would play games like @PERSON1, and tag in the water. There was even a rope swing off the little brigde that one of the older kids made. The swimming hole was the place to be that @DATE1.  Eventually we got hungry and tired of swimming in the hole for a while. There was this trail we would use to walk back to my house. The trail was the fastest way to get home. From the trail you could see farm animals grazing in the sun filled fields. The day we walked this trail was a little different then normall. All the farm animals were making noise. One of the farm hands was walking the trail listening for a bell. He said one of his goats had gotten out. He warned us that the goat was alittle mean and if we saw it to keep our distance. So we took the warning and walked on. Once we reached the gravel road that lead to my house, @PERSON2 said she heard the bell. My brother and I didnt believe her at all. We thought she was playing another joke on us. We walked on for about @NUM1 seconds. All of the sudden @PERSON2 screamed run! My brother and i turned around and saw the white goat with big horns chasing us! We ran as fast as we could. I tripped over my feet and fell. I got up as fast i could and sprinted faster. I could tell my adrenaline was up because I was running really fast and i wasn't getting tired. We reached the hotwire fence that surround my house. We all stopped and questioned if we could jump over it or not. The goat was getting closer and closer, we didn't have much time to deside weather we could or not. My brother was the first to jump. Of course he made it and soo did @ORGANIZATION2. I was the last one. I started to panic in my head. I backed up alittle and ran and jumped over the fence. I thought i was gonna make it but then my foot caught the fence and i flung over the fence and face planted it. It was super embbarrasing. My friend and brother were both laughing histarically at me. I could tell my face was beat red and i was mad that i fell. Again. Although i still found myself laughing. The goat had stopped at the fence and started to charge it with his horns. That made me jump and run. I dived over a row boat were my brother and friend was and I said oh my lanta that was the funniest most scareiest thing i had experianced all @DATE1. We walked up to the house laughing and talking about eachothers faces as we where running and how funny it was that i face planted it. They made fun of the face i made when the goat started to charge the fence. Even though i was embarrased that i tripped over the fence, I still found my self laughing and making fun of myself for what had happened. I would have to say that was the best day all @DATE1. We got up to my house and went into the kitchen to find my mom laughing so hard that she was crieing. We all asked her what was soo funny and she said she saw the whole thing from the window. We all started laughing to point we all cried. We all told the story the story to our parents when they all came over for dinner and they laughed and laughed. All of our cheeks hurt by the end of @TIME1. Laughing is great. It mends the soul. Plus its a great ab work out!!!!

Laughter In A Relationship The most important thing in a relationship is laughter. Laughter is something we all deeply need, and it keeps us going in the world and with the daily duties we do. This is because we get frustrated a great deal of times. So, one thing that truly helps us is laughter. If someone is upset, the person might watch a comedy movie or read a comic about funny or humorous characters. But many people like talking to someone when they are upset and need an uplift from them.  When I was once upset regarding my school work and about not having a job, I went out for a walk after an argument with my mother. It was about my grades being dropped. My mom got quite angry, and my dad was also very upset with me because they knew I was much more capable than I showed in my grades. My parents knew I wanted to do a job to buy the things I wanted. They didn't think it appropriate to linger around about having a job so much and not care about my grades. When I was walking along the lakeside, I heard someone playing a guitar, and he played it so beautifully that I wanted to meet that person instantly. I tried to find him but couldn't, and at last, I just sat down and wondered who that person might be. So suddenly, a boy came to me with a guitar and asked me what time it was. I told him the time and asked him where he learned to play the guitar so beautifully. So he told me that he had been interested in playing the guitar for a long time and he wanted to join a band. We both shared our feelings, and we couldn't even understand that the things we never told anyone else, we were telling each other. After that meeting, we became close friends and we met every day. He knew I was quite tense, so he used to play the guitar for me and we sang songs together. He also told me jokes, and I knew he was doing all this just for me. I sometimes just kept quiet and didn't respond to his jokes. He got more tense that I was not laughing or smiling. But I didn't realize that by doing this, I was really hurting him. But he never lost hope in me and he kept on telling me funny stories and we talked over the phone all night just so that he could make my tensions a bit less and make me laugh. So one day, he took me out for lunch at McDonald's because he knew it was my favorite place and I loved going there. He took me to a comedy movie on superheroes, but neither of them were making me laugh. All the time I was just in his arms. But after the movies, he took me to the most beautiful place and it was near a beach. The whole place was decorated by colorful lights, and we were sitting down on a swing and talking. Now he knew how he could make me happy, and he told me jokes and we read comic books. Surprisingly, I started loving his jokes and the comics we read. Whenever I would meet him, he would do something special for me and make me laugh. He once got dressed up as a clown and tried to juggle balls but he couldn't do it so well, and I laughed at him so badly. I know it was being rude to laugh at him, but I loved spending time with him.  One day, he came to my home and we were talking, and he held my hands and proposed to me. I was really happy to hear that, and he brought me the most beautiful ring ever. He proposed to me and took me out for a drive and gave me some advice in a very respectful manner, not with the intention that he was putting me down. But I had never seen a person like him. He told me that laughing and smiling is good for life. No matter what happens tomorrow, why should we care about it today when we have such a beautiful life waiting for us. We must live the way we want and not force ourselves to change just to get serious in life. He held my hand and took me in his arms and said, "No matter how much we love each other, but laughter is important in a relationship." I looked at him and asked him why. So he replied, "We must be happy and to be healthy and to be with each other." After we had some time there, he dropped me home and told me to live life because who knows if we will be alive tomorrow. From that moment, I realized that he was right, and I looked at life from a different perspective from that day and decided to live life in a better way so that I laugh and enjoy.

I used to love hermit crabs. The cute little creatures who hid in their shells fascinated me deeply. When I was about six, my family decided to take a road trip along a coastal coastline. We were accompanied by another family with four kids. Put together, there were eight kids for me to play with, but the closest one to my age was Tom. He was only a couple of years older than me. I adored Tom. We explored the beaches, swam in the clear waters, giggled at silly things, and played tricks on our siblings together. Everything he did, I did.  We went to so many different beaches I can't remember half of them, but one in particular stood out. It was a short and slender beach. On one side there was a cave. The cave was loaded with hermit crabs. Never in my life have I seen so many of them. There were mini hermit crabs, great big hermit crabs, and even bigger hermit crabs! It was as if our dreams had come true. Tom and I created sand castles, prisons, and water channels to keep the hermit crabs contained. Our older siblings weren't interested in them at all. That was alright though, in our eyes it only meant more for us!  When it was time to leave, Tom and I were devastated. We both knew that we wouldn't just come across another beach like this in the future. It finally hit us that we wouldn't be able to keep our beloved crabs. We stayed down on the beach near the cave for hours just saying our "good byes". When my mom eventually yelled across the beach saying that it was time to go, we both had made a quick decision. I had watched girls stuff shells into their bathing suits before. I thought why not? Tom liked the idea, so we silently slid two hermit crabs into our swim trunks. His crab in the pocket of his shorts, mine in my one - piece swim suit. It sagged at the bottom, but I decided to ignore it and pretend like nothing was wrong. Guilt weighted down my scrawny little body, like I had stuck a ten - pound rock in my suit, not a tiny little crab. My mom had asked me directly if I had left all the hermit crabs on the beach. I nodded, but my voice was absent.  Back on the road, my sister and I played word games. Everything was fine, the music playing, my parents talking, and our wheels rolling down the narrow dirt road. Every once in a while I would have to move a little because I could feel my little hermit crab checking out his surroundings. We had been driving for about an hour when I let out a blood - curdling scream. As my dad slammed on the brakes, dust swirled around the car like a hurricane. I remember my mom swiveling in her seat to look at me and ask what was wrong. I didn't answer. As the pincers grabbed on again, I let out another urgent scream. I then decided it was time to quit hiding my little friend in the bottom of my swimsuit. Letting out the last prolonged scream, I pointed down to my crotch. My sister's urgent hands pulled my swimsuit off and quickly found the little devil. I was so embarrassed and guilty that my mom just laughed. She said that I had already gotten my punishment for lying, and that she thought I had learned my lesson. I sure wasn't going to disagree on that. A few minutes later, our friends pulled over too. When we asked if everything was okay, they said while laughing, that one of the girls had gotten pinched by Tom's hermit crab. That sent all of us laughing.  We never stopped laughing about that story. My family loves to humiliate me in front of friends, guys that I like, or adults that I don't even know. Every time my mother says that that crab grabbed right onto "where it counts", we all bust out laughing. And every time I turn tomato red in embarrassment, but I guess I deserve it.  Tom and I both learned our lessons, although I think I learned a few extra lessons. First of all, never put an animal near your "sensitive" parts. The second lesson was don't lie, because eventually you will most likely be caught and punished. The last lesson would have to be to learn how to enjoy something when you have it and when it is time to let it go, let whatever it is go, and be grateful for the time you got to enjoy it. If I would have been able to just say good - bye to my shelled friends, I would have never lied or felt so much pain. They were all great lessons to learn, and I am very grateful for them. Not only because I became a little wiser, but also because I have a great story to tell that always sends people up in laughter.

Laughter is a huge part of life. Or so that is what I believe and grew up with. "A day without laughing is a waste of a day." Charlie Chaplin's quote has greatly influenced my life. As well as the people in my life.  My mother is quite the entertainer. People have told her that she should become a comedian. Apparently, our family stories are very amusing. Mostly because they involve my brother in some way or another. He's adventurous, spontaneous, and is not afraid of anything. Sometimes his decisions are not the smartest. A majority of the stories my mom talks about are from when my brother was little. She loves to talk about one in particular.  Charlie Chaplin's story, however, does not include him getting hurt or someone else getting hurt. Which is surprising because it seemed like every day he would injure himself or his best friend Jake.  When I was about eight or nine, putting my brother at age eleven or twelve, we were at one of my soccer games. My brother had to use the bathroom and when he came back, my mom was not pleased. He went to use the port - o - potty and he had just gotten two new shirts; a white t - shirt to go under a new button - up. It was a hot afternoon, so he took off his new white t - shirt but kept on the button - up. Unfortunately, he dropped the white shirt. He dropped it into the rancid, disgusting excrement. If you ask him, it was all an accident and my mom was not happy about it.  My mom is the person in the family who thoroughly enjoys laughter. I think about her words of wisdom all the time, "When it seems like nothing can get better, think of the positives in your life and laugh. Because really, that's all you can do. If you embarrass yourself in front of a lot of people, you need to laugh it off. If you can laugh about it, it won't matter if anyone else does." You need to get through life somehow. Might as well make it the best, and laughter is truly the best. It makes my mood better, and makes me feel welcome and at home.  There are many stories about what my brother did, or how blond I am. But ultimately, all that matters is that we can laugh about something every day. It brings us closer. "A day without laughing is a waste of a day.

Laughter is what connects me and my friends. It's a very important aspect in any kind of relationship. I know that almost all the memories I have are of my friends making me laugh. We have been friends for a very long time. One of my favorite funny memories is the time me, Sarah, and two of my friends went to the park. Sarah stopped at Dairy Queen. We sort of had a hard time getting out. Me, Sarah, and my friends went to the park to do a cultural performance at the community center. When we were done, we started heading back home. Sarah kept complaining about needing to use a restroom. Her dad told her to wait until we got to the next town so we could stop somewhere. Sarah and I suggested Dairy Queen. By the time we got to Dairy Queen, Sarah was doing the potty dance. Sarah and I got in line to order ice - cream cones dipped in chocolate. While we were waiting, Sarah was searching for the restroom. After approximately four minutes of searching, Sarah finally asked the lady working behind the counter where the bathroom was. She handed Sarah a key with a large bulky wreath attached to it and told her it was outside behind the building. Sarah took the key and sprinted to what appeared to be double doors. Little did Sarah know that only the left door opens. She ran straight into the right door and fell over. We all started cracking up laughing... Especially Sarah. She laughed so hard that she didn't quite make it to the restroom. Instead, she had an "accident" on the floor in Dairy Queen. When you can laugh with your friends about things that might not seem funny to other people, such as, wetting yourself in public, it only makes your friendship stronger. Laughing is a huge important benefit in any kind of relationship. It strengthens the relationships you already have and it helps build new ones also.

My special evening was a warm, sunny evening in July, 2005 in Miami, Florida. The stars were out and there wasn't a cloud to be seen. As usual on the weekends, most of the family was over; as well as some friends. I was just a little girl who loved everyone and everything, especially laughing. Anyone could make me laugh, smile and have a good time. One person,

I have always tried to be a happy person, and over time I have learned that laughter is a key component to my happiness. I have succeeded in being a happy girl most of my life. Even as a tiny baby, I hardly ever shed a tear; I was constantly laughing and giggling in a most adorable way. As I have grown up, I have earnestly tried to keep up my happy - go - lucky spirits. Sometimes, life threw challenges my way, and I couldn't always maintain that cheerfulness, but that is simply the reality of life. There have been numerous times in my life where laughter was the only thing that surrounded me. I rely on laughter to keep me close with my friends, and so far, this trust has always come through, and it has worked wonders for me. I often find myself reflecting that laughter and happiness are truly what life is all about.  When I was first born, I didn't let out a single cry. As a baby, I rarely ever cried. My mom loves to remind me of this whenever I ask her about my baby years. As a young kid, I was incredibly eager to be a part of everything around me! I was constantly on the lookout for laughter and exciting events; I didn't want to miss a single moment! My mom would have to take long drives just so I could take a nap, and even then, I would hardly ever fall asleep. For if I did, heaven forbid, I might miss a moment of laughter! If someone else was laughing, I would immediately join in. Sometimes, I had no clue what was going on, or I wondered why what they had said was so funny, but I adored the feeling of laughing with other people.  I am always reminded of my happy toddler years whenever I look at my baby pictures. I don't have one of those pictures where I am bawling my eyes out, like you might find in most kids' baby pictures. In every single baby picture of me, I'm either laughing heartily or there is a wide, beaming smile spread from ear to ear! Laughter is what kept me a contented baby!  As a pre - teen, I was still the girl who you would always see laughing and smiling brightly. I sometimes wondered what it felt like to cry because I had never experienced that type of emotion before. I was so engrossed in laughter that I never had time to dwell on the negative. Now, unfortunately, I know the feeling of sadness and being upset, and I try incredibly hard to go back to when I didn't know these feelings. Whenever I'm feeling down, I attempt to find laughter in each thing I do. When I make this effort, I can always find a reason to laugh, and my spirits are quickly brought back up.  My friends are always a great source of comfort and a pick - me - up. Especially @PERSON1, who is my best friend. Every time I am with her, I find myself laughing for one reason or another. @PERSON1 and I have not had the steadiest friendship, but what always brings us close again is laughter. Our fights always end when we find common ground in something funny. Usually, she is the one who finds this, and she makes me burst into laughter. Laughter is what has kept @LOCATION1 and I so close for the past few years. If laughter didn't exist, I can assure you that we would be anything but friends right now!  Not long ago, I was in the car with three of my closest friends: @LOCATION1, @CAPS2, and @PERSON2. We were all laughing and singing as loudly as our lungs would allow to one of our favorite songs. I looked over to my friends and saw all of their smiling, happy faces, and I found myself smiling too. I realized then, that laughter is truly what life is all about. Laughter is what has kept me close to all of my peers throughout my life. When I was little, I was drawn to those who I had the most fun with and who made me laugh the most. As I've grown older, that same thinking still holds true; I want to be with the people that make me laugh. The older I have gotten, the more I've learned about what I need in a friend. My main criteria is someone who can make me laugh. If I'm with someone with a dry sense of humor and who doesn't talk at all, then I am going to go find someone who is laughable and hilarious! Laughter is something that I am extremely thankful for. It has been the key to making me happy for all fifteen years of my life! From when I was a baby, up until now, laughter is what always has been, and what always will be, what my life is all about!

A moment that laughter made everything better was when I was with my cousin @CAPS1, in @LOCATION1. He is going off to the @CAPS2 pretty soon, so spending quality time together was the main goal for both of us. @CAPS1 and I have a very close bond; we talk as often as we can over the phone, sharing our daily stories and dreams. This trip meant a great deal to both @CAPS1 and me, as we have no idea how long it's going to be until we see each other again. Every moment of laughter and every bright smile was something that we will always cherish in our memories.  My parents and I went to @LOCATION1 for @CAPS4. In @LOCATION1, I met up with my cousins, since my parents seemed to be busy all the time with their own activities. Of course, when there is a group of teenagers together, well, it's bound to be loud and full of energy. I remember - on our @DATE1 in @LOCATION1 - my cousins and I got lost in the small town we were staying in. Now, let me emphasize that in that town, there is absolutely no way someone can get lost; it's so minuscule. So when we got lost, we found it incredibly funny and unbelievable. Fortunately, it was during the @DATE1, so it wasn't too scary. My cousins and I firmly believe it wasn't our fault; we blame the taxi driver for not listening to our directions properly. Because it was such a hilarious mess, we didn't stop laughing until we finally reached our destination. In the car, all three of us were arguing about where to go and what turn to take, while the taxi driver just sat there, listening and laughing at our chaos. It was so embarrassing that none of us wanted to see that taxi driver ever again.  @CAPS1 is older and significantly taller than me; he was the tallest person in the entire town. Now, @CAPS1 is always boasting about how he is not afraid of anything and that he is extremely brave. Until one night, all of that bravado was forgotten while @CAPS1 spent the @TIME1 in a state of panic. I shared a room with my two other cousins, and @CAPS1 stayed in the room next to ours with my brother. It was about @TIME1 when we all went to bed. Out of nowhere, we heard a strange noise outside our room. The next thing I heard was @CAPS1 yelling in the other room, desperately wanting to come sleep with us. I was also scared, so my cousins and I decided to let him in. I quickly turned on the light while @CAPS1 and my brother were rushing inside the room. My brother @PERSON3 came in carrying all the blankets and pillows, while @CAPS1 dragged in the airbed. It was such a comical sight that we all burst out laughing. @CAPS1 said, "I may be big and tall but I get scared easily," which made us laugh even harder. The noise turned out to be two cats fighting in the street.  I remember this moment so clearly in my head since it concluded our entire vacation with each other as a family. While my parents and grandparents were out on the front lawn chatting with all the guests, my cousins, @PERSON3, and I were in my room - like always, the funny moments happened in my room. We were just bored and had no idea what to do. Slowly, I was starting to doze off on top of a suitcase. All of a sudden, my cousin @PERSON1 came up with this crazy idea of how I could fit inside a suitcase. I thought she was joking at first, but when I looked up and saw everyone's serious faces, I knew they were dead - set on it. So, I started opening the suitcase and taking everything out, while @CAPS1 went to get his camera. The next thing I knew, I was squeezing myself inside the suitcase. I'm no acrobat, nor am I very flexible, so when I realized that I was having no trouble getting inside, I started to freak out. My brother was practically wetting his pants from laughing so hard, and my cousins were just stunned at what they were seeing. When it came to zipping up the suitcase, I told them it was going too far, but they managed to convince me to zip it up so they could roll me around. @CAPS1, @PERSON1, my brother, and my third cousin @PERSON2 all took turns rolling me around. They kept saying that we should go out on the front lawn and surprise my parents. I finally came out of the suitcase - feeling incredibly dizzy - after my brother dropped the suitcase on the cement floor. We laughed and made jokes about how tiny I am and how much fun it had been after I felt a little better. Since then, @CAPS1 calls me "@CAPS13".  Saying goodbye to everyone was difficult, but saying goodbye to my cousin @CAPS1 was even more heart - wrenching. Knowing that I won't see him for a long time is almost unbearable. @CAPS1 and I have a strong bond, and I see him like a brother. During our entire trip, neither of us could bring ourselves to talk about him going away; instead, we chose to just have fun and ignore the pain. Laughing made that pain fade away. It made our trip truly worth going.

My best friend @PERSON2 turned thirteen on a beautiful @DATE1 day. Her family had a lovely boat, and since the weather was just right - not quite uncomfortably hot but not so cold that it was chilly outside - @PERSON2 decided to have a sleepover birthday party on the deck with some of her closest friends. I was quite nervous about meeting her school - going friends since I'd always been a homeschooler and wasn't going to know any of the other people there.  When I arrived at the boat, @PERSON2 warmly introduced me to her friends @PERSON1, @PERSON3, and @PERSON4. I politely greeted them all, and @PERSON2 then suggested we go @CAPS2. I was all set to walk down to the beach, but @PERSON4 said she wanted to go @CAPS2 right on the docks. @CAPS2 by the boats wasn't allowed, and I was certain @PERSON2 would say no immediately. But instead, she walked over to the '@CAPS1 @CAPS2' sign, defiantly tore it down, and casually tossed it in the harbor. Her friends burst into laughter, and I laughed too. I'd never witnessed people act in such a rebellious way before. But their disregard for rules and customs was so contagious that I found myself caught up in the moment.  As the day passed, I closely watched the way they talked and behaved. The girls used bad language and spoke in a very harsh manner. Everything they said was loud and shocking, and everything they did was meant to be wild and challenge authority. They appeared to be so free, but there was something about their interactions with each other that seemed forced. I wondered if they were truly like this or if they were just putting on an act. But I understood that to be part of their group, I had to act like them. It was my very first experience with peer pressure, and I didn't know exactly what to do. But the girls' attitudes were straightforward, so I adapted and started to behave like them.  But it soon became clear to me that in order for there to be a group, there has to be someone who isn't in the group. That someone was @PERSON3. @PERSON2's parents had made her invite @PERSON3, and @PERSON4 and @PERSON1 were well - aware of it. They would sit close together so she didn't have much room, and they would look at her with disinterest and not laugh when she tried to make a joke. I became aware that if I hadn't adapted so quickly to the attitude of the girls, I might have been the one they left out. I also knew that they could still turn on me if I did something wrong.  We were sitting on the deck of the boat, chatting about movies, and @PERSON3 was trying to tell the group about a movie that she'd just seen and had now become her favorite. @PERSON1 stared blankly at her, refusing to even crack a smile. @PERSON4 looked off into the distance, lost in her own thoughts. @PERSON2 rolled her eyes at me. Suddenly, @PERSON1 cut @PERSON3 off and started talking about a scary movie she'd just seen. @PERSON3's eyes widened in surprise, then she looked down at the ground, clearly disappointed. Without thinking, I laughed and gently reached out to her arm, telling her I wanted to hear more about the movie. I'll never forget the way her face lit up at that simple act of kindness. She smiled brightly and began to gush about how amazing the movie was with renewed enthusiasm. @PERSON1 continued her story while secretly watching @PERSON3 and me.  Later that day, when we went to the movie theater and the girls chose to sit in a row that only had room for four, I made the decision to move and sit with @PERSON3 in the next row down. We talked about the absurdity of straws for drinks and how we would never, ever

Without thinking, I laughed and reached out to her arm, telling her I wanted to hear more about the movie. I'll never forget the way she lit up at that simple kindness. She smiled and began to gush about how amazing it was with renewed enthusuasm. @PERSON1 condinuted her story while watching @PERSON3 and me. @TIME1, when we went to the movie theater and the girls chose to sit in a row that only had room for four, I moved to sit with @PERSON3 in the next row down. We talked about the absurdity of straws for drinks and how we would never, ever wear skinny jeans. It was easy to talk to her. I'd never had to focus on being myself before but I knew if I could do it, @PERSON3 would have someone to talk to. To my surprise, everyone became more natural. Soon we were all joking about what ridiculous things @PERSON2 should wish for with her birthday wish. I suggested a lifetime supply of marshmellows. @PERSON4 suggested the original @CAPS3 of @CAPS4. @PERSON3 suggested to wish that everyone in america would speak with a @CAPS5 accent on @PERSON2' birthday from now on. Everyone laughed. I saw that day that kindness if more powerful than crulty. Making someone an enemy or an outsider doesn't make a friendship stronger. Neither does having to worry about saying or doing something that might make your friends reject you. But integrity and kindness can bring people closer.

Closer @CAPS1 @CAPS2  In life, I think that laughter is a very important element. Without it, everything just wouldn't seem as fun. Laughter can be a great thing, or it can be a little hurtful at times. Luckily my story is of great laughter. So, i will be telling a story of one of my adventures of laughter.  It all started one day when me and my cousin @ORGANIZATION1 were at home. It was pretty much a normal day. Laughter...What exactly is laughter? Laughter is that magical force that makes the world go round. It's the very essence that makes friendships and relationships truly click. Laughter can even pave the way from romance straight to marriage. Without laughter, people would be constantly sad and deeply depressed. They'd be clumsily stubbing their feet as they walked. People would be under stress all the time, and there would be a lot more wars. Simply put, the world would not be able to survive without laughter. That is the profound truth I know about laughter.

Laughter, an incredibly important part of life, offers a comforting feeling just by the act of laughing because, in that moment, everything seems okay. Laughing has this amazing ability to bring people together, making them share in the joy of laughter. It's like a unique form of communication. Once you start laughing about something, others around you start to laugh too, and it connects everyone in a shared state of happiness. It's as if you're silently telling everyone to be happy without uttering a single word. That's the power of laughing with others, but when they laugh at you, well, that's a completely different story. I remember one particular day when I was at home doing the dishes. Everyone in my family was feeling frustrated, and I was no exception. I really hate being angry, and I also hate it when others get angry. So, I said something (I can't quite remember what it was), and suddenly, everyone started laughing. It instantly put everyone in a great mood. I like to think of laughing as a fire. One single candle can light many other candles. When you hear people laughing, the first thought that pops into your mind is, "Something must be really funny." And you naturally want to go and find out what it is so you can join in the laughter. This is a very common reaction for most people who love laughing. Personally, I absolutely adore laughing because it gives me this wonderful, slightly strange feeling. It's a feeling that makes life more enjoyable and worth living.

Laughter between two people serves as one of the clearest indicators that you're truly good friends. When you're having a really bad day, the shared laughter between each other can instantly cheer you up. It's the very reason you know you've established a great bond in your relationship. Laughter is the strong bond that ties my two best friends and me together. It's the secret behind our long - standing friendship. One of my best friends is named @PERSON1, and the other is @PERSON3. I've been friends with them for @NUM1 years now. We're all extremely close, and we do absolutely everything together. We hang out regularly, we play soccer as a team, we live in close proximity to each other, and, most importantly, we laugh together all the time. @PERSON1 loves going camping with her family during the @DATE1. For the past @NUM2 years, she's kindly invited @PERSON3 and me to join her. On our last trip, I was texting quite a bit because I was the only one who had service at the campsite. @PERSON1's mom got annoyed and yelled at me for texting so much, which made me a bit angry. @PERSON1 and @PERSON3 sided with @PERSON1's mom and also yelled at me. I shouted back because I didn't like the way they were all ganging up on me. I said, "I know, I'm getting off the phone. Just shut up!" They were both really taken aback by my outburst and became a bit intimidated. We all fell silent, and the atmosphere was really awkward for a little while. Then, our friend @PERSON2, who was also on the trip, attempted a cartwheel and ended up falling flat on his face. @PERSON3, @PERSON1, and I tried hard not to laugh because we were still mad at each other, but it was just too hilarious. So, we couldn't hold it in any longer and burst out laughing. In that moment, we realized that we shouldn't be mad at each other. We knew that a small fight like that couldn't possibly break our friendship. We all hugged each other and apologized. This is precisely why laughter is such an amazing thing. There's nothing better than having friends who are always there for you and can make you laugh even when you're mad at them. Laughter can strengthen the bond between friends and repair any damage that has occurred in a relationship. In my case, laughter has fixed many such problems and will continue to do so in the future.

Laughter is the key to every friendship I have. If a person is really nice, but I can't seem to make them laugh, or vice versa, it becomes difficult to find common ground between us. When I reflect on my friendships, it brings back all the wonderful memories filled with joyous laughter over the years and months. The simple things in life that make me happy often trigger laughter. Whenever differences surface in friendships, all it takes is a memory that made us laugh to reignite that friendship. Whenever I'm with my best friend, @PERSON1, things that usually aren't funny at all become hilarious. Another factor is that @PERSON1 and I don't hang out as often as we did when we went to the same school @DATE1 @DATE1. So, the time apart makes us cherish our moments together even more. Three nights ago, I went to dinner with @PERSON1 and her mom at @CAPS1 @CAPS2. Throughout the dinner, we had numerous laughing sessions. People around us either think we're really annoying because we can't stop laughing, or they understand what it's like to have a best friend who can brighten your @DATE2 and think we're funny. There has never been a real fight between @PERSON1 and me because we've become so close over the @DATE1 and realized how much alike we are, like twins. So, conflicts rarely arise. However, one of my other close friends, @PERSON2, who goes to my previous school with @PERSON1, has been having issues with @PERSON1. The most important thing to me is that they get along because they're two of the most important people in my life. I'd do anything to make them become friends again, even though I might not have the power to do so. I can get close to both of their hearts and maintain a level of laughter, shared secrets, and wonderful memories. But when they're not on good terms, it's not easy to bring them together. I was with @PERSON2 @TIME1, so I understood how she felt, just as I understood @PERSON1, who I was with at the moment. I tried to briefly bring up the subject, and at first, she refused to talk about it. I knew that @PERSON2 meant a lot to her, and that they'd only had a small, silly argument. The problem is that both of them can be very stubborn. In any argument, neither of them will be the first to say they're sorry because they both think they haven't done anything wrong. In this case, it was just a minor miscommunication. I ended up explaining to @PERSON1 in more detail how @PERSON2 was feeling because I could really relate. Once I got her laughing, she started to see things from @PERSON2's perspective. The key to my friendships is definitely laughter, especially while we're young. I wouldn't have been able to get @PERSON1 to listen to my view on @PERSON2's feelings if I hadn't used things that made her laugh. I told her things that made her giggle and brought back memories of the good times the three of us had. She thought about it, and even though she wasn't ready to immediately run up to @PERSON2 and hug her and make peace, she was willing to consider communicating with @PERSON2 again. That was enough to make me feel good. For the rest of the @TIME2, we put aside the drama, relaxed, and had a great time. We played our favorite songs and laughed about the smallest things or the mistakes we made when talking to each other. I know that as I grow older, I'll look back on my two best friends, @PERSON2 and @PERSON1, and realize how they made my high school years truly amazing. They helped me become a better person, someone who can fully enjoy life by being in the right company and having innocent fun. They taught me that you can be great friends with multiple people, and even if they don't get along, you can find a balance and not leave anyone out. In the end, the most important thing is to be a good friend to everyone and not be selfish. Laughter has led me to understand this important lesson.

Close people to you cherish the moments you've shared with them, and recalling those moments brings laughter for what transpired in that time. Laughter has the power to bring together people you've known for a long time because it evokes the feelings associated with that person and the moment. Laughing at the memories spent with someone and truly enjoying them can strengthen your bond with that person and is crucial for the relationship. In fact, this has happened to me. Laughter filled my heart when I watched a special video from my past. It was from a family party when one of my favorite cousins was two years old and I was three. My cousin was very chubby with straight hair, but that day, she was terribly sick with a fever. I was quite different, with curly hair and a short stature. We both had dresses on, but they were of different styles. Everyone at the party was having a great time, and so were we. The video reached the part where my cousin and I were bouncing up and down, grabbing our dresses, and putting on a little show for everyone. At that time, we were supposed to be dancing. It seemed we were having an absolute blast that day. Then, my youngest brother came over to watch us dance. He was holding a cup of soda. Just then, one of the grown - ups got up from their chair and accidentally bumped into him. He dropped his cup of soda, and it splashed all over my cousin and me. Our dresses were instantly wet, dirty, and sticky from the soda. We stopped dancing, sat down on the ground, and started to cry. My aunt and my mom quickly changed our clothes. Later, when we saw my brother, we were so angry that we ignored him when he tried to talk to us. But as time passed, we started having fun again and eventually forgave him. Finally, the video ended. It's truly important that laughter can bring people closer together because it creates a wonderful shared moment. My cousin and I watched the video and laughed at our past selves. We shared the same feelings and the innocence of that age. We noticed how much we've changed since then, looking back at all the funny times we had. We also realized that it wasn't really my brother's fault that we got splashed. Laughing at those shared moments helped my cousin and me become even more united. Obviously, as we grow older, our reactions change, but laughter, whether in the moment or later, has the power to bring people together. Sometimes, our feelings may vary over time, but laughter remains important because it allows us to share moments of happiness with others. I often remember events from my past with my family, and these memories bring us closer and fill us with laughter for the happy times we've had. Laughter is truly a precious gift that enriches our relationships and makes life more beautiful.

I would say laughter is something that comes from the heart. It's that genuine, warm feeling that bubbles up from deep within. But really it is what is on the inside and how you really feel about the person and, how they feel about you. When that person makes you laugh, you know that they really love you and care about you. When you make someone laugh and they make you laugh then you are with the one and only true person. Laughter is from the heart and soul, a pure expression of connection. When that person tells you something that makes you laugh then it is true between you two. Feelings, those unspoken emotions, are a lot between two people. Joy, that feeling of happiness, is from the soul and down deep within your body. As my mom would say, joy helps clear the mind and body, but what I really think is that when someone makes you laugh they see the real side of who you really are and what you can become. You laugh about all kinds of things like jokes, funny videos, funny stories, and more. But the real thing is that at least someone makes you laugh. When it says it is the important part of any relationship what it is trying to say or make a point of is that you need to laugh in your relationships and, have fun. But my thought about joy is that you clear your mind and you have to listen about things and, then if it is funny then you start laughing about it. Here is what my mom used to say to everyone is that "if you have not laughed at all today then you do not have a clear head or body". There are times in peoples' lives where they just laugh and laugh and have a hard time stopping that, I think laughter is just a feeling that people have. You might tell funny jokes that make people laugh but sometimes they do not even make any sense at all. There are sometimes you can play a game that is really funny and you have to make funny things or even do crazy stuff, but it all comes down to one thing and one thing only you need a laugh once and, a while. I mean don't everyone need a laugh, I tell myself almost everyday that if I don't laugh then I did not clear my mind or soul. But is it really about me no it is not. When you say you need a laugh people look at you like you are crazy but you really aren't. What you are really trying to say is can you can tell something funny then people will understand what you mean. I have been told funny things over the past few years but I'm a teenager what do you think I will remember them all. I am just like everyone else I will forget them over the years real easy. I'm not all that smart but after I think about it for a few min I finally understand the joke. I know I am a bit slow, but I have those days where I am saying what to people what are you talking about, then they look at me and, they just say wow! you really are slow and I also have slow jokes about me and I really do not mind when people tell slow jokes to me. Cause I am not affected at all I got used to it. When I heard my first slow joke I had to stop and, think about it for a few mins then after about an hour I realized that they were trying to tell me that it was me. Then I walk up to them and I was like "Hey, I finally got that joke and, then I was like what a really good joke. When you have a laugh for the first time is because that someone special either made you laugh or they tickled you. They might even tell you a very funny story about themselves, or someone that is related to them. When you laugh is like your showing your feelings and, trust to that person, because if you do laugh then it is just like wow you are really lost on what they were trying to tell you. I will always tell myself if I need a laugh or something to either call my friends up or just look in the mirror every morning. Because for some odd reason I think I am just really funny looking. Most people think that if you look at yourself and make funny faces in the mirror you will laugh non - stop. The reason I laugh is because I see or hear something really funny or just wanna laugh so much. If I have a good day or a good weekend I laugh a lot. Laughter truly enriches our lives and relationships, making every moment more memorable and meaningful.

Laughter is one of the many ways to share a memory. It's a powerful tool that can create bonds and leave lasting impressions. It is also a key component to story - telling, it shows that the listeners are enjoying what you have to say. When you share a laugh or a smile with someone its almost as if you're sharing a deep secret that no one else knows. Laughter is having something in common, it doesn't matter how much money you have or how old you are, a person always has the ability to burst out in laughter. Inside jokes are laughter's best friend, from the second they are made to the slightest mention of them, they always bring smiles and giggles to everyone's face. As a person, I feel that it is my duty to make people laugh. One example of this would be when I was seven years old and spending the night at my friend @PERSON1's house. We had just gotten done watching an exciting @CAPS1 @CAPS2 movie and were super hungry for lunch. As it turns out @PERSON1's big sister @PERSON2 was the only one home, and she wasn't going to have anything to do with her "baby sister", so we were to fend for ourselves. Being young, we didn't want a boring old @CAPS3 @CAPS4 and @CAPS5 sandwich, we wanted to make @NUM1 delicious cupcakes! This might sound like a ridiculous objective for two seven - year - old girls, but we were surprisingly ambitious and tackled this with no problems, or so we thought. In reality it was a disaster, we had no idea what a mixer was so we mixed everything with our hands, which worked up until I brought the flour out. From now on I will never think of flour in the same manner, every time I open the jar of flour all I can think about is the mess @PERSON1 and I had made that day. Let's just say it was a disaster, enough flour to successfully make @NUM1 cupcakes is approximately the whole bag. As I was getting ready to pour this tremendous quantity of flour into the bowl, I slipped on some of the vegetable oil that had spilled out of the measuring cup, and the flour went everywhere! @PERSON1 started laughing as soon as the white powdery cloud filled the room. As for me, I was still in shock, not to mention covered in what felt like enough batter to feed the entire world. Now that I am quite a bit older, I don't think I could have taken such a tremendous mess so lightly, considering I would most definitely be the one cleaning it all up. But as a little girl, laughing was the only thing that mattered. @PERSON1 couldn't stop giggling as she was looking at my whole body covered in white. We started to play in the flour, picking it up and throwing it in the air as if it was confetti. When all of the sudden @PERSON2 came down the stairs, took one look at the kitchen and started to yell, "Clean this up right now! I was upstairs for an hour and you manage to make this big of a mess? Mom will be home in twenty minutes and you had better have this kitchen cleaned" @PERSON1 and I looked up at each other and back at the kitchen. Then was when it hit me just how much work we had to do. All of the sudden I started laughing uncontrollably, it felt as if I had no care in the world. It turns out that @PERSON1 and I completely ignored @PERSON2 and continued to play in the flour for those short twenty minutes. We were in the middle of building a fort in the kitchen surrounded by what we called "snow". I heard the slam of the front door as @PERSON1's mom walked into the house. It sounded like paper towels being ripped right from the dispenser. Because we didn't clean up anything, we in fact made the kitchen much worse, we made a split - second decision to run down into the basement to pretend we had done nothing wrong at all. That day had been our biggest mistake, as soon as @PERSON1's mom saw the kitchen we heard a scream, "@PERSON1! What is this??". Slowly we climbed the stairs to the kitchen and @PERSON1 starts explaining herself. I choose to stay quiet because I had never gotten in trouble by someone that wasn't my own mom before. When @PERSON1 is done telling her story, her mom tells us to go downstairs. Both of us are on the verge of crying, when all of the sudden @PERSON1 starts laughing once again. I could think of nothing that would possibly be funny at this moment when she says, " you still have flour in your hair". From this experience I have learned that sometimes, laughing is the only thing that will make you feel better. Even though I have moved away since this cupcake fiasco, I know that if I ever talk to @PERSON1 again we will begin laughing at just the mention of this story. Laughter truly has the power to turn a messy situation into a cherished memory.

Laughter is a huge part of life, in fact it is all I wanted to see my grandfather @PERSON1 do before his final days. He's the most obedient dog I've ever seen, he would go to the mail man and get the mail to bring back, he opened and closed doors if it had a rope, he would even get my grandma's slippers in the bedroom. When I lived in @LOCATION4, @ORGANIZATION2, everyday after school I would be picked up by my grandparents and go to their house and wait to be picked up by my mom until I was old enough to be alone. Grandma would always help me with math homework, patiently explaining the difficult concepts, and cook dinner and then afterwards grandpa would help me with drawing or turn my favorite @CAPS2 show on. When I was young I would go over to their house in the morning and grandpa would have recorded my favorite show "@CAPS3 the @CAPS4". Every morning that was the routine, and then breakfast. Later on in my life when I became more independent I didn't go over to their house as often as I used to and it is something I can't take back. A few home videos I've looked at recently reminded me of a good time with them, my grandpa was recording me chase the dog around the kitchen table and I stubbed my toe. Apparently it was humorous to my family, all who were laughing in hysterics. Another time when I was younger my grandpa was a barber shop owner and cut hair for years in @LOCATION2, @ORGANIZATION2, and at his house one time I didn't know what a "mullet" was but I knew it was a hair style. I pleaded and pleaded until he finally gave in and gave me a mullet hair cut, I was astonished to what it looked like and immediately hated it. The last @CAPS5 I spent with my grandpa I bought lot's of presents for him and my family. Thanks to the @DATE1 job I had on the eastern part of the state, I was able to get a heating blanket that covered his whole bed, a couple movies, and his favorite " @CAPS6" chocolates. I can honestly say it was the happiest I had seen him in a long time, which made me happy too. When the day is over and you reflect on how everything had gone, you will notice the best of times are only a laugh away. Laughter with my grandparents was a precious part of my life, and those memories will always be cherished.
Laughter. Laughter is a key

Laughter is important in all relationships of any kind. If you have a friendship where you never laugh and nothing is ever funny, what is the point? I have four friends that mean the world to me. @PERSON2, @PERSON3, @ORGANIZATION2, and @CAPS1. @CAPS1's real name is @PERSON1 but we all call her @CAPS1 because how she acts. @PERSON2 and I use to do almost everything together. I asked her what was wrong and told her to tell me all about it even though we were fighting I wanted to be there for her no matter what because she was always there for me. Little did we know that the past two weeks @PERSON2's @CAPS3 had been "house sitting" he hadn't planned on returning home to his family. As i listen to @PERSON2 tell me the news and how hurt she was, my heart sank. While she cried I cried. Her @CAPS3, broke the news to her @DATE1 @TIME1 after we left for @ORGANIZATION1. He will not be returning home because he hasn't been happy there for awhile and he wanted a divorce. I knew exactly how @PERSON2 felt, my parents got divorced when I was very young. Although it didn't tear me apart like it did her it still effected me. Not having a real family with one home and two parents who were married and inlove was never easy on anyone. @PERSON2 had not the slightest idea that her @CAPS3 would later get married and start a family with a woman he had been seeing for over a year while coming home to his family. She just kept telling me that she had to bring him home, that she couldn't do this. @PERSON2 and her @CAPS3 were really close, she was daddy's girl one hundred percent. I remember her telling me that she just wanted to disappear it was all her fault. All I could do as her friend was listen and tell her it would be okay. @PERSON2 began to calm down and grasp the fact that things happen and she couldn't change her @CAPS3's mind. So @PERSON2 came over, we played guitar hero and everytime I messed up she would laugh. Hearing @PERSON2 laugh again made me feel better about things because I knew that she had figured out it was not her fault for her @CAPS3 leaving. Without the laughter in that room I'm not sure me and @PERSON2 would have been able to ever be good friends again. Afterall laughing at me messing up on guitar hero brought me and her back to being good friends again. So it's very important to have laughter in a relationship because once the laughter is gone then the friendship or whatever you know is going dowhill. Now @PERSON2 and I talk for endless hours or text about anythign and everything and when we aren't laughing we know to ask one another what is wrong.

A few years ago, me, my mom, and my sister @PERSON1 were at a cozy sub shop for a delicious dinner.
