Laughter can create this type of strong bond that's extremely hard to sever. I can vividly tell you how I've made some fast and true friends just by laughing at the same silly things. It's an amazing phenomenon when people laugh. It doesn't always make perfect sense or seem that incredibly funny at the moment, but I think it will make anyone feel better no matter what the difficult circumstance is. I can tell you how I've made some fast and true friends just by sharing laughter at the same things. Or how laughter can mend a fight that you and a loved one have had. Well, here it goes, my story of a very true and very close - to - home incident that helped me open my mind and gain one of the best and most genuine friends I'll ever have in my life. To tell this story, I have to go back in time to when I was around nine or so. When I was a young girl, my sister, @CAPS1, or as I always affectionately called her @PERSON2, and I despised each other. We never got along well. Maybe that's because of sharing a room with an older sister. I can clearly remember her never wanting to play with me or hang out with me. My oldest sister @PERSON1 had just gone to college, so my sister @PERSON2 and I got the chance to get to know each other a whole lot more. Sure, we still had heated fights and still didn't get along with each other very harmoniously, but we were well on our way to becoming the best friends we are today. Well, one day when my parents went out shopping, my sister @PERSON2 and I stayed home to clean the house. In my family, when cleaning, loud music is blasting, no matter what kind it is. As always, my big sister had to "order" me around, or at least that's what it felt like then. And like always, I was a stubborn little sister who never liked taking orders from the big sister. Well, @PERSON2 told me I had to clean the bathrooms, and I really hate to clean bathrooms. I mean, who likes it, right? So I told her that I wouldn't clean them... well, that didn't go over so well with the big sister who was in charge while mom and dad were away. So we started to fight, and oh what a furious fight that was. I mean, it was as loud as it could be. The music couldn't even be heard over the intense yelling and screaming. Like most fighting in my house goes, my sister and I got so fed up with each other that we stormed out of that room and into our own bedrooms. While the music was still loudly playing and could even be heard from all the way upstairs. So as I, and I can only guess my sister was doing the same, was plotting my revenge on my oh - so "wise" sister, then the music changed to an upbeat classic song that is one of the most popular songs in my household. This song was "@CAPS2 @CAPS3". Because I loved this song so much, I opened my door to my bedroom. I guess my sister is like me because she did the same. Well, I had started singing and dancing in my room to the music, and guess my sister had heard me because she had come out of her room and into mine. I of course didn't notice her so I kept on singing and dancing. Well, as soon as she started to laugh at me, I stopped and glared at her. @CAPS1 just stood there laughing. I had said something along the lines of well, you couldn't do better than that. So she tried, and it was my turn to laugh. We ended up making fun of each other's dances and laughed all the way downstairs where we hugged and said how sorry and stupid we were for fighting. Then after all that had just happened, we looked around us at the work still left to be done. We then looked at each other and laughed and ran to do our work before mom and dad got home. We finished just in time. As soon as my mom and dad came home, we were just doing the last bit of cleaning. That night after my mom and my dad had gone to bed, my sister and I had a great time watching movies and laughing our heads off. That's it, my story of how sisters, or more like best friends, can fix a rift and start anew with just laughter and having fun together. Now my sister lives in @LOCATION1, so I don't see her a lot, but whenever I can, I web - chat with her or call her. We spend hours laughing. It doesn't even matter what we are laughing about. That's what laughter does. It creates this deep bond, a strong connection. My sister and I have had our fights in the past... and will likely have them in the future, but we have laughter that always helps us stay close no matter what happens in life.

Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." I firmly think that laughter is truly important in any aspect, in any kind of relationship. When people laugh, they get to understand each other better. Usually, people think that you are a cool person when you say something funny and laugh with them when they say funny stuff. It's much more fun to be with people who are laughing with you or make you laugh. There were many times throughout my life when numerous problems were solved by just telling a witty joke, saying something humorous, or even recalling fun memories from the past. I have many friends that I love dearly, but of course, like in any other friendship, we've had minor disagreements between us. I remember one time when my friends and I went to hang out at the bustling mall. Two of my friends got into a huge conflict because of something really strange, which later escalated into a heated argument. Of course, we always had small conflicts, but this time I guess the two girls were really serious and mad at each other! My other friend @PERSON1 and I were looking at them and didn't know what to do. And my friend @PERSON1 was kind of scared that they might hurt each other. I told them, "Hey, you guys! Don't be like that!" They looked at me and stopped. So we started to walk. Then I remembered something funny and crazy that those two girls and us did at a camp the week before this incident happened. After that camp, I remember how they were saying how we are going to be "@CAPS3 @CAPS4 For @CAPS5" for our whole lives and that they wouldn't forget how much fun we had. I started to laugh, recalling what we did at that camp, and they looked at me like I was weird or something. So I reminded them about all that fun stuff we did, and they looked at each other and started to laugh really hard! Because their conflict had something little to do with that camp, which they had forgotten! After that, they started to talk to each other and forgot about that conflict that they had. Sometimes I remind them about the conflict, but they just laugh and say "We were so dumb to make that conflict!" And we all laugh at them. "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." This is why I think that laughter is really important in any friendship. And I think that this problem was solved by just sharing some funny memories so they could laugh! And by reminding someone of a thing that they had forgotten.

Laughter is of key importance in life, within the family, and in relationships. It gets people through tough times and those moments when you just need a friend by your side. Laughing is a significant part in my life. I love joking around and having a great time. When something unpleasant happens, I try to cover it up with laughter. Some people sometimes say that I laugh too much in certain situations, but it gets a lot of people through tough spells. If there was no laughter in the world, it would be dull, and I feel that people would miss out on really experiencing the joy of laughing and making jokes. Making other people laugh gives me a wonderful feeling, even if it is a rather lame joke. I think that's because it gives me a good sense of self - worth, as it's one good thing I know how to do. My family has always been the joking type. We love messing around and just laughing about everything. There have been a lot of wonderful memories with my family and me, filled with jokes and such. We cherish every little laughing moment because it's something we all treasure, and it's a bond that we don't want to break. One moment in my life where laughter was really beneficial was in awkward situations with people. On my sports team, we tend to get down on ourselves very quickly during games, and we start to blame other people, which is the most common thing that people do when they start to stress in such situations. This causes so many errors, and my teammates and I are just not paying attention to one another and not acting like a team. After losing so many games, you really start to lose hope for yourself and your team. Our coach always tries to comfort us by saying we did well or we could have tried harder. Some people take this seriously, while others don't care and act as if nothing ever happened. Those people start to shut others out and only care for their close friends on the team. One morning before we even started, the atmosphere was tense between people. The captain noticed that two of the team members were talking about her, and she confronted them, saying "If you're going to talk about me behind my back, just say it to my face." They were in complete shock, and no one knew what to say. So I stated, "Well, this is just awkward." The whole team just started to laugh because it relaxed the situation. Even though it didn't totally solve things, it just made the situation a little more bearable. Another moment in my life where laughter was a key part was during road trips. Being stuck in the car with my family while going somewhere and on the way back is a great bonding time. You start to talk in a crazy way, not making any sense, and not being your usual self. Then it brings out the fun of messing around, and when you say or do something, it becomes really funny, and it's a moment that you don't want to lose. An example that happened to me on this experience was when we were going to @LOCATION1 and we made up a lot of inside jokes about the things we saw or heard. Moments like these I always want to cherish because these people in your life right now won't always be there. To create memories, just do the simple thing and laugh with your family and friends.

Laughter is how me and my friends connect most of the time, and that's how I became friends with a lot of them. You know when you're in a new class and you don't know anybody there, so it's kinda awkward because you feel like you're a loner. I try to make the best of the situation and try to make new friends, but I'm not always the best at it. So, when I get a chance, I make them laugh. First, we take baby steps, and the more we laugh together, it seems like the closer we are to each other. By the end of the semester, you don't really like the class, but you don't want it to be over because you made such a good friend. The next semester, you find out you have a class with that person, but they don't like the class, so they move out. Then you realize you guys kinda grow apart because you never see each other, and if you never talk, then it gets kinda awkward. The way we started off our friendship was really by accident. I didn't know many people in the class, and the people that I did know weren't really my friends. We sat by each other, and after so long of awkward silence between us two, she made a joke, and I started to laugh. The next thing we know, within a week, we would talk to each other, and soon enough, we hung out some. About half - way through the semester, we would get in trouble in class for talking too much, and we started to realize we were starting to be best friends. The semester went on, and we were hanging out more and more, and she was the only one I would hang out with sometimes. By the time the semester was almost over, we didn't know what our classes were, so we thought we would be split up. The day we got our schedules, we talked to each other and saw what our classes were. We saw we had one class together, and we were excited. The first day of the second semester, we went into the art class that we had together, and we were laughing the whole time. At the end of the period, she told me she didn't want to be in that class because she's not an artsy type of person. I went to my sixth period and was wondering if she was actually going to switch out like she said or not. At the end of sixth period, I saw her, and she told me that she got switched out and went to a class that she wanted. I know people in that class still, but it's not the same because I knew we were going to lose our friendship because we would never see each other. It's a couple of weeks into the last semester, and we hardly ever talk. Sometimes it gets awkward just to be around her because it's not like how it used to be. Laughter is how me and her became friends, and classes are what tore us apart. It's a bit sad, but it shows how circumstances can change relationships, even when they start with so much laughter.

And all I can hear in the background is my family laughing as this little 7 or 8 - year - old is running full - speed up and down the hallways and opening and closing doors to rooms that he's never been in before. And also shouting at the top of his lungs, "Brother, where you be at? I can't find you." And with one more door to open, that's at the beginning of the hallway where everyone is sitting or standing. This little boy comes running down the hall in a panic, who can't find his brother. And opens up the door, and out pops my brother, his brother, who is wearing the scary monster mask and says, "I will get you tonight if you don't eat all your dinner." So, now what I did was just as he told me to do. I ate my dinner so fast I ended up throwing up because I was so scared that he was going to come after me that night! And the funny thing is that this happened for the first time of my life, so that's the funny thing. It's a childhood memory that still makes me smile thinking about how easily I was scared back then.

Is laughter important? In my opinion, laughter is very important! How could laughter affect someone's life? If there was any, or not? Also, is laughter important to me? Laughter is important for so many reasons. In a relationship, in everyday life, and with the ones you have in your life. How would the world be if there wasn't any laughter in this world? It would be very dry and dull. It helps connect people together if they have the same sense of humor. Having a good sense of humor is very important these days. A lot of people use sarcasm, which isn't "laughter" but to some people it could be, or some could feel hurt by it. However, most people that feel hurt by it don't have a sense of humor in any way, shape, or form. Most people have heard the saying, "it takes more muscles to frown than smile," and that is a very true and factual fact! Having a glorious relationship is the best thing with my significant other. The affection that he can be by sharing our laughter together brings us closer to a point where we couldn't be at all if there wasn't for laughter and communication. Having a sense of humor is an important thing in a relationship, to most people. Would you want to be with someone who bores you? Who can't make you laugh when you're sad? I sure wouldn't want that. Laughter brings out great communication skills. By laughing with someone, it shows your type of opinion on the subject you are talking about. In a relationship, could you imagine if there wasn't any laughter in it? Would you feel the same about the person you're with if there isn't any laughter? How would you feel knowing the person you love isn't very "humorous" and doesn't like to laugh often? I couldn't handle that. I would want to love someone who is very funny with a great sense of humor. Laughter is important to me for so many reasons. I would rather be around very ecstatic people than someone who brings me down! I consider laughter to be one of the most important things in my life and in my relationship with my significant other. It brings us closer. People ask, "Doesn't it ever get old being happy all the time?" "Of course not!" I would say in defense. Why would someone think that way? Being in a phenomenal mood all the time would be the most amazing place I would want to be in my life and with my partner. In my opinion, I would think that almost everyone would feel close to what I'm saying. However, people have their own opinions about laughter and how and if it's important, and they're entitled to their opinion. I know a few people who don't like to be in a very cheery mood, who would prefer to be sad all the time and not care. Laughter could raise you up from that. In conclusion, laughter enriches our lives and relationships, and we should embrace it.

When I think of a day where laughter was the element, I think of June 15th. That was one of the worst days of my life. I had plans to break up with my girlfriend. That morning, my decision was final, and I was going to do it. For some reason, when I woke up, I felt sick. That day, everything was falling apart. Around 3 PM, I went to my girlfriend's house and broke up with her. The next day, I couldn't smile to save my life. The whole day, my friends were making me smile and showing me they cared. They told me funny stories and did silly things. The next day, I felt so much better. I was smiling and laughing like nothing ever happened. All day, my friends were telling me jokes and being really stupid in a fun way. They made me laugh so much. Throughout those upcoming weeks, I met another girl. I couldn't be any more positive about my life. All I do now is just smile and laugh. I don't need to live my life with sadness. All I can do is just be positive and smile. Laughter is very important. No one should go a day without it. Just let's live our lives to the fullest and put the past behind us. Just think on the bright side and smile. Laughter has truly turned my life around, and I'll always cherish its power.

My high school varsity basketball team isn't the best team, but the one thing that we do have is the ability to make each other laugh. At the start of the school year, the school held try - outs, and the teams were decided. After graduating seniors and some players not coming out, our team was brand new. Full with all different ages of players. We all were civil with each other at practices, but we weren't all best friends that wanted to hang out outside of practice. The varsity team decided to take a retreat to the beach and stay there for a weekend. When we went to leave for the beach, our phones were taken, and we had assigned seats in the cars. This trip seemed like it was going to be a long one without my phone. We arrived at the house at 7 PM. As we all found somewhere to relax, shower, or sleep, myself and most of the team ended up in the living room conversing with the coaches. We all sat on the floor, recalling stories about the game from that evening or funny stories from our past. By the time we finished telling stories, it had reached 10 PM, and everyone in the house was either tired or hungry. As we sat on the floor complaining about tiredness or hunger, we all started to turn our attention to the kitchen. Sarah was starting to go on a tirade about how hungry she was. In her opinion, she thought the house we were staying in should have already been stocked with food for us for when we got there, but there was no food. As she continued on her rant, she became more and more mad, which made us laugh harder and harder. Finally, she reached her point. "There's no steak or chicken up in these mother - freaking cabinets." Sarah proclaimed. At that point, the coaches and players started laughing uncontrollably. Sarah didn't understand why it was so funny, but we kept laughing and laughing at the fact that she just said that there should be steak and chicken in the cabinets. The outburst of laughter continued on for the next five to ten minutes. When we finally started to calm down, Lisa came downstairs. She had missed everything that had happened, and as we went to fill her in, Sarah stopped us. "Lisa, get up on the counter and look in the cabinet," Sarah said. Lisa hesitantly got up on the counter and slowly started to open the cabinet. When she opened the cabinet, she looked inside, and all she could see was chips. She turned around and looked at us. "What?" asked Lisa. As she turned to us, Sarah just sat there smiling. Then she finally answered the question. "Get me some of those chips right there!" Sarah said. Everyone in the room started laughing as Lisa was so confused as to why she was asked to get up on a counter just so she could get Sarah chips, who had been sitting next to the counter the whole evening. The whole basketball team started laughing again. Lisa got down from the counter but with no chips in hand. We all continued laughing and kept talking about what had just happened for the next 15 minutes. As everyone finally started to settle into their beds for the night, there were still those moments of "Remember when this was said", and "Remember when she did this". That first night that we spent at the beach did more for us than we realized. By going to the beach and making memories together, we were brought together by two common things. The love for basketball and most of all, the ability to be able to come together as a team all because of the memories we shared that night in the kitchen. Today, we still get on each other's nerves, and sometimes we lose our tempers with one another, but we will always laugh about the crazy things that happened on the trip, and the thing we laugh about the most is what happened that night in the kitchen. These shared moments of laughter have truly strengthened our team bond.

Allot of people say that laughter is a big part of any relationship, and I whole - heartedly agree. Although not everyone always laughs, in every relationship, laughter is a crucial component that can turn someone's day into the greatest day they've ever had. There are always people having a tough time, whether it's at school, at home, or anywhere else. When you see someone in such a state, you should always try to cheer them up. You could say something nice, like "Hope you have a good day @DATE3," and give them a warm smile. This simple act can make them put aside whatever is preventing them from laughing, and you'll have made their day just by sharing your smile and laughter.  Many people need someone to turn to when going through a very hard situation or problem. They can't handle it alone, whether at home or school. They need someone to talk to, share their feelings with, and have a shoulder to cry on. It always makes someone feel better to let out all that pain and their inner self. We all should make those going through a hard time smile and laugh, and this is always something very healthy in a relationship. It's a way to offer healing to the person in pain or sadness.  This reminds me of a true story because I was there. One time, there was a girl in my elementary school. She was an extremely happy girl who shared her laughter and happiness with others. She was someone anyone could approach when they had a problem or just needed someone to talk to. She was one of the nicest girls in school, and everyone liked her. She always showed love and respect to others. It always seemed as if her life was perfect, with no worries. She was an only child, so of course, her parents would always give her what she wanted, or at least that's what we all thought.  It had been a @DATE1, and it came to be @DATE2. We were all in school, except this girl. She never missed a day of school, so it was very strange for her not to be there. Naturally, we thought she must have been sick. But she missed another day, then another, and another. I started to think she had moved away and would probably never come back. However, the next week after that, she showed up. I was very happy to see her as I had missed that girl. But there was something very different about her. She wasn't the same. She wasn't laughing or smiling anymore. She had lost that sparkle that made her so special.  I thought to myself, "What is wrong with her?" I finally found out that she had been gone because her mom had passed away. I was so sad and didn't know what to say. She was so happy one day, and then suddenly, she didn't have her mom anymore. I thought, "I have both of my parents, and she doesn't. I should share the happiness she had shared with me and others right back to her and be there for her now that she's going through the hardest time of her life." That's why being happy and sharing your happiness with others is always the greatest thing you can do for someone. You never know what kind of things they're going through, and they need someone to make them smile and laugh. In the end, spreading joy can bring light to the darkest of times.

Coming down and making remarks at him about not being able to stay on his board was one of the most heart - warming things I have ever felt. The Power and Benefits of Laughter is truly an important thing in life. Laughter has the magical ability to lighten one's mood and make you feel more happy. Making adults laugh is not very easy because they tend to be more serious. There are numerous stories that highlight laughter as the important element. Laughter can connect with many other wonderful elements, such as being glad or happy. I once read a story about a little girl named @CAPS3 who had a knack for making people glad. And through that gladness, people were encouraged to laugh more often. And through laughter, the sick people started to become healthier and got rid of their illnesses. Laughter consists of many different factors. For example, being glad leads to more laughter, being happy, and of course, more smiling. When you're feeling down and a stranger, for instance, smiles at you, you'll likely feel happier and your mood might lighten. The morning dawned to be gray and rainy. The people in the household woke up irritable and grumpy. Everything seemed to be going wrong. No one was smiling. The breakfast was a very dull one because no one felt like talking. She was mad at her maid because she had forgotten to fill her pitcher with warm water, as she always did. She was mad at her little sister for taking her blue hair ribbons. To tell the truth, she was mad at everyone, and she hadn't even considered that if she had been happier that day, then everything would seem okay. Well, anyway, she still had to go to school, whether she wanted to or not.  At school, the little teacher was as merry as usual. She wasn't a bit grumpy, even though it was a rainy and gloomy day. Some of the students had the same positive mood as the teacher, but there were very few of them. The schoolwork seemed never - ending to @CAPS4, especially her mathematics. But everything changed after the teacher told everyone that it was story time. The story was about a little orphan girl who had to go live with her mean relatives. But she wasn't affected by their moods at all. She was very simple - minded and always happy. Over a period of time, the people she was staying with (especially the sick and old) began to be happy, just like her. And when she had to leave that village, everyone was sad to see her go. With a light heart and a happy spirit, the girl left the most precious gift, the gift of being always happy which led to more laughter. Even when she was gone, a passing stranger might always hear happiness and laughter in that place. And it was even enjoyable to stay there for a little while before continuing your journey. Because the passers - by always felt themselves feeling much better in health, because of the laughter. After the teacher finished the story, @CAPS4 thought, why wouldn't she try to cheer her family up? Even though it was raining, it didn't mean that everyone should be gloomy. So after school was over, @CAPS4 quickly ran home to cheer everyone up. In the evening, when everyone was done with their day's tasks and relaxing, there was laughter heard through the windows. It seems like @CAPS4 has found a way to bring laughter into her household too. The story she heard earlier in the day has helped her today, and it will likely help her throughout her long life. We can see that this small factor, which might not seem very significant to us, has made @CAPS4's life more happy. One day I woke up, gazing out my window and listening to the melodious chirping of the birds outside. My knees were weak and my hands were slightly shaking as my rapid heartbeat was causing my breathing to increase in speed and rhythm. So, I closed my eyes tightly, took several deep breaths, and decided to put this in the hands of fate. When my mother, sister and I arrived at the airport, (I'm not going to lie) I felt a strong urge to go home. My sister would crack a few jokes here and there and my mother would let her wittiness shine on me. But once I looked back at all I had done: two weeks in @LOCATION1, rafting, etc., I realized that I did miss him and did want him back. We could see his eyes frantically scouring the airport for us, and when he found us, he gave the warmest, friendliest smile I had ever seen upon his face. Tears welled up in his eyes as my sister raced towards him and my mom quickly walked behind. My legs carried me toward him and I soon found that my sister and I were competing to be the first to hug him! One hundred feet never felt so close yet so far away. Panting, we reached him with heavy legs and full hearts, now that we were with him. The good thing is, an awkward moment never occurred. It knocked, but we didn't let it come through the door; instead, laughter came in its place. All of my troubles and worries were gone when he opened his mouth, and those soothing waves of laughter came out and were welcomed into our ears. My heart was lifted and my smile brightened. I knew that my father could not have been gone any longer. I love him! Laughter soothes the soul and brings joy to any situation. It is kind and has no regrets. The only mistake is not taking the chance to laugh in the first place. Laughter is one of the many things that holds me so close to my father today. Our sense of humor when we're together is never dull and is unforgettable. I trust him with my life and ever since I was born, he has found a way to make the best out of every situation by laughter. You can count on his laugh to make anyone smile and it is without a doubt, the most contagious thing you'll ever hear.

The first day I met her, I knew she was the right dog for me. Her black and white fur was as soft as the finest cotton, and her eyes as brown as the rich bark on an old tree. She had a genuine personality that no other dog could possess. Which was something I could tell right away she was the dog for me. Over the next couple of months, our friendship grew steadily, as I patiently taught her to talk, smile, and stand on two legs and dance with me. A black lab named @PERSON1 instantly became her best friend. The two would run over the property, barking merrily and playing with boundless energy. Every night the two would cuddle up next to each other and sleep soundly. The times when she, my new dog, would lay on her side and relax, I would call her an oreo. Her middle belly was white and her sides were black, making her look like a large - breathing oreo cookie. That's where her name had come from. The seventh month had come along fast, but it was enjoyable every single day with my dog at my side. She gave me the best comfort when I needed it most, always giving me a warm smile when the day was rainy, or sleeping next to me when I didn't feel the best. It was kind of like she was my own special dose of medicine, her presence made me feel well again. Her love had grown deep into all of our hearts at that house and she was one of a kind. But something began to change about her as the days went on. Her food bowl would be nearly full every time we fed her. She wouldn't run with @PERSON1 anymore. She wouldn't talk, and she wouldn't smile. I knew something was wrong. We didn't know she was sick until it was too late. The first day she had thrown up blood. That was when the worrying began between my boyfriend, his mother, and I. We wanted to find a vet to help her, but none of us had the money to do it. The second day in the morning, I couldn't find her anywhere on the property. I thought that maybe she had just gone for a walk around the outskirts of the house, until it reached @NUM1 pm and there was still no sign of her. Panic spread throughout my body and I gave up looking for her and turned towards @PERSON1. "@PERSON1," I looked at her straight into her eyes, "I know you can hear me." She looked at me with big brown eyes and wagged her tail. "Where is she, @PERSON1?" I knew she understood me as she began to sniff around the areas of the property. Suddenly, as if she had picked up a trace, she followed a line of scent to an old opal car. @PERSON1 wagged her tail, looked at me and then looked back under the car. There she was, looking sick. So I pulled her back up onto the property for my boyfriend's mother to look at her. We weren't sure if it was poisoning or something else. So we called an animal expert and asked. The expert said it sounded most likely like parvo, since we hadn't gotten her her parvo shot yet. So over the night to help her feel better, I and my boyfriend stayed up, carefully shooting water into her dehydrated body, and giving her spinach juice, hoping it would help. But all she wanted to do was sleep. So we left her alone in peace and decided we would check up on her in the morning. In the morning, my boyfriend had to go to work and I was left alone with her to take care of her. I sang soft songs to her as she lay on the porch, looking sad and in despair. I stroked her on her head, telling her how much she was my best friend and my favorite dog that meant so much to me, and I told her I loved her. I tried getting her to eat but she would only puke it back up. Finally, after a day of crying next to her, I noticed she kept walking to the pond behind the house and sitting in it. It gave me the incentive to check her butt. As I pulled up her tail, I noticed a large bloody hole from which flies were flying out. She was rotting from the inside out. I cried. It was time to decide whether to put her down or not. I, my boyfriend, and his father just looked at her, watching her be in pain. It was time. As soon as we got to the vet office, they took her inside and laid her on a table. I was told to hold onto her as they shot an overdose of anesthesia into her. It was only seconds before she was gone and everyone in the room was silent. I cried over her limp, no - longer - smiling body. We dug a hole and buried her under the tree where she used to play. "Goodbye, my mama bear. I hope you're happy in heaven.

Ever since I was born, laughter has been a significant and constant part of my life. Without it, I would be a very boring and perpetually grumpy person. Even though I have experienced numerous moments filled with laughter, one specific moment always comes to mind. About a year ago, my mom and I went on a trip down to @LOCATION1 to visit her family. It was the first time we had been there in over twelve years because my mom and I could not go visit them due to immigration problems. After all those years had passed by, my mom and I managed to obtain our legal residency in the United States. As soon as we got the residency, we were free and could go visit her family without having to return illegally. When my mom and I arrived at the airport in @LOCATION1, my mom started crying because she was overwhelmed with emotions. For the first time in twelve years, she was going to see her mom, dad, brothers, and sisters. As soon as we had gone through all the airport security and baggage claim, we made our way out to the exit where my grandpa had agreed to pick us up. When we got outside the airport, a small little red @ORGANIZATION1 started getting closer and closer, driving steadily towards my mom and me. The car was no further than forty feet away when my mom suddenly dropped her luggage and started running eagerly toward the small red car. I had no idea who the elderly person driving the car was. When the car parked, an aged man stepped out of the vehicle and gave my mom one of the longest and most emotional hugs I had ever witnessed in my entire life. They must have been hugging for at least fifteen minutes, just crying on each other's shoulders. When they had finished hugging, my mom called out my name and I started walking toward her. When I was face to face with my mom and the older man, my mom told me that the man was my grandfather. Then she looked at her dad and told him to meet his grandson. For the first time in a very long time, I had a grandfather. I stood in shock for a while, and so did he. He was amazed at how big I had grown and how much I had changed in those long twelve years that he had gone without seeing me or having contact with me. When I reached out to hug him, he gripped me tightly and didn't let go. He told me that this day had been the happiest day of his life. Me and my grandpa started loading the luggage into his car so we could head home to meet the rest of my family. When we got done loading everything into the car, we headed home. The long ride home was a bit strange and uncomfortable because there wasn't much conversation in the car. It was about a fifty - minute ride home when we reached our destination in a small little town outside of @LOCATION1 called texcoco. It was a nice little clean town with a lot of small stores and lots of two - story middle - class houses. The streets were full of cars and people walking or on bicycles, very different from what I was used to back in the United States. When we got to our house, there was a group of about twenty people that were family and friends outside the gate waiting for us. When we were done settling in and got done meeting all our relatives, we got together and had a family dinner. One of my uncles really stood out because he was really funny and always acted like a clown. He was the one that set the mood in the house or wherever he went. As days passed by, I was getting more and more comfortable with the people around me and started having fun. About two weeks passed and my uncle @CAPS1 invited me to one of his stand - up comedy shows. That day, I experienced more laughter than ever before. His jokes were original and true. In conclusion, laughter is one of the essential elements of life. Without it, I could not be happy.

The Benefits of Laughter Laughter has always been a major and integral part of my life. Most of the relationships that I have with my friends are excellent because I can make them laugh and cheer them up when they feel down. When a person laughs, it makes them completely forget about anything that brought them down, and now they just focus on what made them laugh and feel that pure joy and happiness. When you laugh, the only thing on your mind is the thing that made you laugh; nothing else can intrude. Laughter, in many cases, has the remarkable ability to bring people from an absolute low self - esteem to a high self - esteem in a very short amount of time. An example of where laughter was very beneficial to a person happened with one of my friends. One of my good friends seemed to be really down and didn't want to talk about what was going on with anyone. With him not telling anyone what was wrong, it kind of left us guessing. What could have happened? After about a week of pretty much isolating himself from others, he was ready to talk and hang out with some of his close friends, which included me. Me, and two other people who were friends with me and him, decided to go golfing, which was a new hobby of ours. It was that day that he told us how his mom was cheating on his dad for over a year, and how she was also hiding alcohol in all different kinds of places and was over - drinking. By him just being around his friends, laughing and having a good time, he found himself focusing on other things rather than what was going wrong in his life. Even laughing at yourself can be a great way of coping with your problems. Even when it seems that nothing will go right in your life, something always will; you just have to be patient and give it time. The moral of the story that I have just told is that no matter how sad you feel, laughter can always help ease the pain. Even laughing about a bad situation could help you to feel better. Laughter truly is a powerful and positive force in our lives.

Laughter is a huge and vital part of everyone's life. It's used to express several different emotions, from pure joy to light - hearted amusement. It's also used to bridge the gap between people and break the awkward barrier that sometimes exists in social situations. People laugh at their own mistakes, which shows others that they too are fallible. Some people can communicate through laughter and understand what the other is feeling without saying a word. For instance, one time while I was on a long car ride and very bored and about to fall asleep, out of nowhere, I began laughing with my friend. We laughed in different ways and carried on a whole conversation just with laughter. Laughing can bring others together by sharing common interests; after all, everyone laughs. I laugh more than others, I'm sure of it. Laughter is a huge part of my life. Honestly, without it, my life would be dull and depressing. I laugh so much sometimes that my side and stomach hurt really badly. I also make a lot of mistakes and am very clumsy, so I get laughed at a lot. My family is a very close - knit and hilarious family. We make a lot of mistakes constantly every day. For my great grandma's @DATE1, we were planning a surprise party. While we were planning it, my grandma kept getting suspicious and asking what we were doing. So we kept telling her that we were going to get her a stripper for her @DATE1. So we managed to persuade my uncle Bobby into being a stripper and climbing out of a box, and he did it. It ended up scaring my grandma. Until this day, we still talk about that day and laugh about it all the time. Every day, my aunt acts in a ridiculous and funny way, so most of the time, I laugh at her. She is always dancing to the music on commercials or singing opera in a comical way. My great grandma always eats foods that make her pass gas, and it's hilarious because sometimes she doesn't even realize that she is doing it. My great grandma also likes to dance, and it's also really funny because the dance moves that she knows are far different from the ones today. I believe that without laughter, my family would not be as close as we are. Without laughter, I would not be as close to my friends. You can bond over laughter; it sometimes forces you to ask questions and get to know people in other ways you wouldn't have. It makes you comfortable around people and able to share things, act silly, and not worry about your appearance. Laughter can also change your emotion from mad to happy in an instant. For example, I was riding dirt bikes with my younger cousin, and he decided that he wanted to go through this swamp with his bike. I told him it wasn't very wise because I knew it was not possible for him to go through there without getting stuck, yet he tried it anyway. So, as I assumed, he got the bike stuck. Since I was the only one with him, I had to help him get the bike unstuck. It took a long time for us to get the bike out. As soon as we did, he tried to drive through again and got it stuck yet another time. However, my greatest strength is humor. I've discovered that I can captivate an audience, no matter the size, with humor. With this in mind, I designed a presentation to engage my class and show them the real me. I wrote a speech where I explained my talents and the things I enjoy. I could make someone forget their troubles for a while or brighten their day with just a few words. I wasn't a star athlete, and I wasn't even a top student. Laughter has numerous benefits, including inducing feelings of happiness and joy, facilitating bonding with others, triggering an adrenaline rush, and helping to release tension. The daily joking around us also adds to its charm. Laughter is a shareable emotion, especially among those feeling down. It can brighten any day and bring enjoyment. Laughter has been a significant part of my life. Whether it's with family, friends, boyfriends, or even strangers, laughter always holds great importance to me. I love seeing someone who smiles often, as it likely means they laugh a lot and are a happy person. How can I tell? Well, for starters, they may have dimples in their cheeks and crows feet in the corners of their eyes. These crows feet can appear regardless of age, resulting from frequent laughing, smiling, or squinting in the sun. The most significant aspect of laughter in my life is its role in relationships. Usually, when there's laughter in a relationship, it tends to last longer. The reason is that you can be yourself and let the other person see that you're comfortable laughing and being part of their life. I believe that laughter is the best part of a relationship. For instance, if your partner is in a bad mood, will you let them be moody all day or try to make them laugh and cheer them up? When I'm in a relationship and my partner is being moody, I try my best to cheer them up. I love making people laugh. And when I'm in a bad mood, my boyfriend is helpful, either trying to make me feel better or comforting me to find out what's wrong. So, if there's no laughter in your relationship, there will obviously be no happiness, and it probably won't work out. Therefore, spread the joy of life and make people happy. Another important part of laughter in my life is with friends. If you don't know me well, let me tell you that I'm shy at first, but once I get comfortable with you, you'll see that I'm a very outgoing person. Most of my friends say I'm weird, but I enjoy laughing a lot and making others laugh too. When I'm with my friends and feeling down, someone will always manage to make me laugh in the end. No matter how upset I am, they can always make me laugh at almost anything because I'm easily entertained. Being around these friends is like watching a comedy show. They're always finding ways to be funny and a bit annoying, like being obnoxious and doing stupid things that others wouldn't do because it's embarrassing. But just because it's embarrassing doesn't mean you shouldn't try it. If you don't, it gives us more to do and all the attention. How can you know if something is funny if you don't try something new? How can you laugh at yourself and have others laugh with and at you, no matter how silly it is? So, don't judge until you've tried. The person who said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people," is it true or false? Is it really the shortest or the longest? I honestly think it could be a short distance. You don't want to be snooty or crabby all the time, or you'll never make friends or have relationships. And if you don't have friends or relationships, who will make you laugh and help you enjoy life? If you're not a happy person, how can you experience the joys of life and the world around you? You won't, so put a smile on your face and be a spontaneous person without fear. Laughter is beneficial to all of humanity. In my life, laughter has shown me so much and brought enjoyment to me and others. The joys I've experienced include having boyfriends, friends, and family around me. This emotion can brighten any day and bring happy expressions to everyone's faces. So, share the laughter.

Laughter is undoubtedly the best way to bring people closer together. It forges a bond that makes you feel a bit more at ease and secure. Imagine how sad and depressing life would be if there were no laughter. Everyone has a distinct type of laugh; some are loud, some are quiet, some are weird, and some are funny. Our laughter is what truly makes us who we are. There are numerous effects that occur during the process of laughing. Your laugh can have such a powerful impact on your body that it can cause your eyes to become slightly teary. Sometimes, when you laugh, it becomes harder to breathe, and your stomach might start to ache. When something is really funny, I usually struggle to take another breath because I can't stop laughing. That's one of the effects that happen to me while I'm laughing. Everyone knows that when someone finds something amusing, they laugh. We can laugh at a movie, a joke, or even a simple mistake. My family always manages to make me laugh. When we have parties, we're always laughing and cracking jokes. One of the jokes my cousins said was that my aunt's baby was so white that it looked like it came out of La Lechera. "Lechera" is a Spanish word. Another incident that made me laugh was when I went to my cousin's house. We were watching a movie, and I had to go to the restroom. When I came out, she jumped out from around the corner and scared me. I screamed so loudly that my other cousin yelled from upstairs to be quiet. I couldn't stop laughing. I was scared, but it was funny because she scared me out of nowhere, and I never expected her to do that. I consider laughing to be a precious gift. It's something that can always brighten our day. I love to laugh, and there are so many unforgettable moments when I almost laughed until I peed my pants. I believe that the people with the best personalities are those who can make others laugh. Laughter truly has the power to make life more enjoyable and bring people together.

When you hear a child laugh, what comes to your mind? Do you think of peace and happiness, or something else? When I hear a child laugh, I immediately think of my little sister. Whether we're outside playing Peter Pan or inside playing with dolls, she lights up like a bright light, and I can clearly see her happiness. It's not just my sister's laugh that brings me joy; it's everyone's! However, I do think a child's laugh is the most unique. When you hear your child, niece, nephew, or grandchild laugh, you should be able to sense their happiness. As you grow older, a laugh changes. I remember when my sisters and brothers were younger, they would laugh at the simplest things. But now, they laugh at sick and disgusting jokes and laugh when someone gets teased. That's not the case for me. I'm the one who laughs when someone does something silly, like in America's Funniest Home Videos. A child laughs when you make a funny face or when an animal does something funny. They laugh at the littlest things. To me, a smile is just a silent laugh. I remember hearing the saying "A smile is worth a thousand words," and I think it applies to laughter too! Even though there's no sound in a smile, there's a potential for laughter waiting to burst out. I know for a fact that when I was younger, I was abused. So, whenever something good happened, which was very rare, I would have a huge smile on my face. Then, if someone did something funny, I would try not to laugh, but I could only hold out for about 5 seconds. Then, I would start laughing so hard that I would start to cry. There's one specific time that stands out as the highlight of my life. One day, I was hanging out with my sister Linda, and we were playing with dolls. My dad walked in and accidentally stepped on one of the dolls. Linda started to cry because the arm had been broken off. But as soon as she started to cry, my dad started hopping on one foot, holding the other, and then he fell on his butt. I laughed so hard that afternoon! Later that day, he took me and Linda to the store to each buy a new doll. Once again, I must say that a child's laughter is the most beautiful thing on earth! For some reason, it heals the soul. If you start your day badly, you can come home at the end of the day and hear your child laughing, and suddenly, your day gets better. I wish I could be a child again to relive those simple and happy moments. Every laugh is unique, and as we grow older, our reasons for laughing may change, but the power of laughter remains the same. It can always bring light to our lives.

Boy says to [someone]: "What's the weight?" [Someone] replies: "What?" Boy says: "I just wanted to say something to break the ice!" Laughter is truly the greatest thing to have in any kind of relationship, whether it's with family, friends, or in a romantic relationship. It creates a strong bond and makes the relationship full of playfulness. It was [date], and I was on my way to pick up a long - time - no - see friend to go to a Warped Tour concert. We hadn't been on the best terms due to an issue that had occurred a few months ago. I decided to take my friend [name] to the concert she'd been wanting to go to all year. When we finally picked her up, there was a lot of tension from the unsaid words between us, but I wasn't going to wait any longer to see what would happen. Before we headed to the concert, my parents decided to get a car wash. Then, I immediately thought of a few funny things I could do to make her laugh. The car moved as slowly as a turtle into the car - wash machine. I left the window cracked just enough for some water to seep in. We were chatting about the concert, and I pretended to be completely unaware that my window was open. In fact, I really didn't expect so much water to come in. She looked at me and started laughing so hard that she could hardly speak. I looked at her and asked, "What?" She said, "Your window's open!" I turned and saw that water was rushing in, which startled me. I jumped up and quickly closed the window. She was laughing uncontrollably, and so was I. From that moment on, it was a great ice - breaker for all the tension that had been there. The awkwardness was gone, and we had a wonderful rest of the day. As the saying goes, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." When laughter is present, no one is truly sad, mad, or in a bad mood. Laughter can make a good first impression between two people who just meet, bring couples closer together, and bring joy and happiness to friends and family. Laughter is indeed the key to happiness. It has the power to transform a tense situation into a pleasant one and make life more enjoyable.

Laughter is one of the most important things in life. It can range from a simple joke to an unbelievable event that becomes a great memory to share among family members. It helps you through tough times, makes someone's day better, puts a smile on their face, and can start a chain of laughter among people. Sometimes, it can be the most embarrassing thing people remember about you, but in the end, the person laughing at you might have done something similar in the past and just doesn't realize it. I remember on my fifteenth birthday, my grandma took the whole family out to a Chinese restaurant. It was quiet except for the adults discussing what to order from the family meals. I was sitting beside my sister, looking at the menu to see what they had to drink. Her mind was on other things, and out of nowhere, she blurted out, "They have no fricken chicken!" Everyone burst into laughter, including the waitress's son who was standing behind our booth and his mother. It really brightened everyone's day because it wasn't the best of days at that time. But you could tell she was embarrassed, yet she also laughed at herself. Her comment to the table was, "I thought I said it in my head." I looked at her and said, "No, you didn't." So, she just shrugged it off. To this day, whenever we go to a Chinese restaurant, my mom looks at her and says, "They got your fricken chicken." She replies, "Will that ever die?" We all look at her and say, "No, it's going to be passed down to your children. They'll hear about their mother's fricken chicken day." It was such a memorable incident that she gets upset that it won't go away, but it still makes everyone else laugh. Even though it happened so long ago, our parents joke that it'll be her wedding toast. It went something like this: "As long as you give her, her fricken chicken, you [partner's name] will last forever." It wasn't the nicest comment about that day, but it was still funny to the rest of us. This is something that will stay in the family for years to come and hopefully be passed down through the generations. Even if she doesn't want it to be talked about, in time, instead of us telling everyone about the incident, she'll probably tell them herself and just laugh about it because it was such an unexpected thing to happen. We still tease her about it and many other things she says out loud without realizing. But those are stories for another time. You never know what could happen. Just remember to laugh. It's true what they say - it's healthy for you. So, make the most of some of the worst days. If you're having a bad day, you never know what might happen to make you smile and laugh, even if you're the one causing everyone to laugh. Think of something that makes you laugh and share it with the people who are special in your life to brighten their day. Even if it's one of the most embarrassing events in your life, laughter can turn it into a happy memory. When we were little, laughter was often the cure for our sadness. Just because we grow

I think that laughter is a key element to any lasting relationship, because if you didn't have laughter then that would be one extremely boring relationship. Then, a few months ago, he added me on Facebook and we started talking again. It was tough for him to break up with her but he did it and I am really proud of him, because she treated him very badly. In the beginning of our relationship, we were both really shy and didn't talk much but the more and more that we hung out, the more we started talking. We want to be the type of couple that can talk to each other about anything in person the way that we do in texts. Every time I see him, I get really nervous and it almost seems as if my heart skips a beat. Whenever we are walking down a street, I cannot help but to smile. And when we lay on the couch and watch movies, I can't help but to laugh when he tickles me. We laugh at each other all the time, whether it's when one of us makes a silly mistake or what not. I believe that laughter and the way we get along is what keeps us going strong. Every time he leaves, I cannot wait to see him again. Laughter is what keeps most relationships going because without it, I feel like it would be a really dull relationship. And if it is boring, then you wouldn't want to spend time with one another. I personally think that every moment with your significant other should be fully taken advantage of, as these moments filled with laughter are what make the relationship truly special.

Everyone in life has siblings that they grew up with and that they love unconditionally, but for some of us, we didn't know our siblings until later in life. As it had turned out, my biological father had rights to my last name and unless he signed these over to my dad, my mom would take him to court and force him to pay the thousands he owed her for child support. During this little story that she was unveiling, I had learned that I have other siblings out there in the world. Over the next eight years of my life, I would spend countless hours running through old phone numbers and email addresses trying to find my other siblings. It wasn't until my freshman year that I met a guy who went to my school and was in the same grade as me, named @PERSON3. He quickly became one of my good friends and we hung out every other day. On one occasion that he was at my house playing video games with me, he chanced upon a question of what my last name was. I thought to myself that this was a peculiar question but in the end, I told him. All of the sudden, a smile crept across his face and he asked if I had a biological father named @CAPS1. My mind started to reel over this sudden question. @PERSON3 started to explain to me that he was half - brother to my sister @CAPS2 who was one of the siblings that I had been searching for. Almost before I could think to ask the question of how, he had called my sister and explained to her he had found her brother. As it had turned out, she had been looking for me just as hard as I was looking for her. @PERSON3 asked her if she would like to meet me and I heard a high - pitched squeal of joy from my sister saying yes on the phone. I too was overjoyed at the thought but I had no idea of how awkward it would be to finally meet her the next day. On the day that I met my sister, @CAPS4's mom had come to pick me up to take me to her house. As we were driving, so many thoughts were racing through my head that I thought I would puke in the car. When we finally arrived at her house, @PERSON4 who is @CAPS4's mom, urged me out of the car and into the house where my sister, who I realized looked almost the same as me, was sitting on the couch looking just as nervous as I was. During the next four long nerve - racking hours, my sister and I played 20 questions with each other to get to know one another. After doing this, we were more comfortable with each other and she looked a lot more accepting that I was truly her older brother. By the end of the day, we were telling jokes and laughing hysterically. We realized that we even had the same obnoxious laugh (that everyone hated) and that too made us hit the floor laughing. At one point in time, her mom had to tell us to quiet down because we were going to wake the baby if we didn't. And by the end of the day, we had connected with each other so much that she even gave me a hug before I left. @CAPS2 and I connected most through our laughter the first time we met and from that day to even now, every time we see each other we giggle and smirk. Since we found each other or in my case, her brother found me, I have gone to her house every other weekend. My sister is one of the most precious people I have in my life and that will never change because nothing we say or do will ever stop the laughing and joy we hold towards one another, and these shared moments of laughter will continue to strengthen our bond.

We couldn't control ourselves. Our eyes were watering, and our stomachs were hurting so much we couldn't move. I was choking on my words as I talked to my best friend @PERSON1. Every time we talked to each other, someone would say something that we thought was funny and we would start laughing and laughing. When I look back on the things that we talked about, most of what we said didn't make any sense at all and I don't know why we laughed so hard. One day at our bus stop, @PERSON1 said something very funny and we laughed until the bus came. Then I said something funny and we laughed the whole bus ride to school. This happened almost every day for us. On this particular day, we couldn't stop laughing not even when we got to our classroom. Our 3rd grade teacher had lots of pets in her classroom and one of her pets was a tree frog named @CAPS1. That week was @PERSON1's and my week to take care of him. When we went to feed him, @PERSON1 grabbed him and made him dance all over his cage. We both thought this was the most hilarious thing ever. Our eyes started watering and we were choking on our words as we took our seats for class. We laughed through the teacher giving instructions and while we were doing our class work. Eventually, our teacher had to come up to us and tell us to be quiet. This didn't stop us from laughing. We tried and tried to stay calm and do our work but we just couldn't stop. On this day, lots of people in our class were chatty but no one was laughing as hard as @LOCATION1 and I were. We were so loud I thought the people in the class below us would definitely hear us. I tend to always get myself into awkward situations with the people I love, but that's just life right? When you're a kid, you tend to be overly dramatic about every little thing. Middle school was a challenging environment. Not only are kids subjected to a rapid advancement in the academic environment, but a maturing social environment as well. The rapidly growing need for social dominance and in turn inflating egos makes for a bully breeding ground. Without the skill to be able to laugh it off, I would fear for anyone's mental well - being in that environment. Throughout my first @NUM1 years in middle school, I struggled with the building social discomfort of classmates higher in the social chain. Their constant teasing and taunting took a severe toll @CAPS1 not only on my self - esteem, but my academics as well. The stress of my own social stature plummeted my grades, continuing a vicious cycle resulting in even more stress. The whole situation seemed hopeless and depressing. I could not believe that in only a little over a decade of life, my outlook had become so grim. I wondered how I would make it through the rest of my school years. Every day I had the "pleasure" of hearing any number of new insults made up by those higher in the social ladder, attempting to supplement their growing self - esteem and inflating egos; @CAPS1 some days even those who I previously believed to be my friends joined in with them. Except for a few trusted companions, it seemed the whole world was out to further themselves by bashing me with any number of new insults. Being made fun of daily had continued until I realized something; That laughter is key in social survival. Without laughter there was no way I could have survived those school years. After this revelation, I was able to laugh at things said to me and laugh at myself as well. I was able to take the cacophony of insults and learn with it, taking it as critique to better myself. Through laughter and their jarring remarks, I was able to secure my position in the social scheme as well as improve my intelligence. I also made new, better friends and came to peace with others, while maintaining the hurt I experienced earlier to be "popular" without having to make fun out of those who were like who I used to be; @CAPS2 a win - win scenario. Laughter is key in any situation, whether it be a conversation with a friend, or experiencing the pent - up frustrations of immature adolescents. From laughter, I learned a great lesson, one that I hope everyone has or should learn. Without the lesson of laughter, I don't know how anyone could lead a successful and pleasurable life. Laughter truly has the power to turn a negative situation into a positive learning experience.

Most people think that laughter helps you live longer, love longer, and show who you really are. I believe all of that is true. Laughter is one of the most important things a person can do. In my life, laughter has helped me through the hardest situations and made them a lot better. You can laugh a lot with friends, family, or people you barely even know. Laughing can mend relationships and help you get through anything. I've found that out many times in my life. My mother and I haven't always had the best relationship. We don't always get along, and since I have a severe separation anxiety from her, we spend a lot of time together, which can cause friction. There was a certain time when we had a fight. I wanted to go somewhere, and she didn't let me. I was expecting her to be mad at me for a while because of how rude I was being. We didn't talk for a couple of hours and tried to stay away from each other. We would only talk if it was really important. After a couple of days of this, I went into her room to talk to her about it. When we talked, I understood why she was so mad at me, and I apologized and left her room. But I could still feel that there was some tension between us. I wanted to make things better more than anything. I wasn't really sure if she was ready to get over this fight, so I thought it would be better to give her some space and let her come to me when she was ready to talk. We both tried to stay away from each other for the rest of the day, trying to cool off and really think about what we were truly mad about. The next day, we went to do some things around town, like grocery shopping and visiting some family. In the beginning, we didn't really talk much. Within an hour of us leaving the house and having our alone time together, we started joking around and laughing at everything each other said. After our errands, we went out to lunch. It was the most fun I've ever had with my mom. We talked about everything, laughed, and had an amazing time. The days after that were wonderful too. We spent a lot of time together and felt like we didn't want to leave each other. I know that laughing together and talking really helped. We opened up to each other like we never had before. I love my mother and care for her more than anyone in the world. When we got into that fight, I was scared our relationship would never be the same again. But we were able to work it out by laughing. I honestly think that laughter can cure anything, from a broken heart to a broken family.

Laughter is important in many ways. It can help you solve an argument with a friend, improve your health, and help in awkward situations. All relationships need a little laughter to lighten the mood once in a while. If we didn't have it, everything would be taken seriously all the time, and there would be many more feuds. One instance where laughter helped was when my best friend, @PERSON1, and I were in a big fight about someone spilling paint on a pair of shorts she owned. We were both accusing one another, and the situation was getting worse. I remember right in the middle of the fight, @PERSON1 made a funny face that made me laugh. Once I laughed, I could tell she wasn't amused. She began questioning why I was laughing. So I explained to her, and she ran to the bathroom and, looking into the mirror, made the same face. To my surprise, she started laughing too. After a ten - minute laughing fit, I made a joke about the paint on her shorts, and we decided to splatter them with paint for a rather "unique" look. Needless to say, laughing saved us from getting into an even bigger argument. When people are angry or upset, they probably don't feel good physically. They might feel angry for days, which can give them physical pain. I know for me, if I'm angry long enough, I'll get a headache. Ironically, I get more angry at people around me because my head hurts and they're making it worse. Laughing is a way to change things. Not necessarily being carefree, but learning to let go and live. Physical health is greatly affected by laughter, as well as mental health. Everyone needs to laugh to stay sane. Learning to not worry about the small stuff is really important. My favorite thing to hear is "let go laughing." Letting go of a problem while laughing is the best way to get rid of problems. I've also noticed that when you laugh more, you feel better overall. You have more energy, usually because of the endorphins that kick in when you have a crazy fit of laughter. It also lightens the mood a lot when you're with other people. All people need to laugh, whether they're married couples, students, teachers, or best friends. Laughing can bring people together. In the end, laughing can benefit you in many ways. It can help resolve feuds, lighten moods, and have good effects on your mental and physical health. And the best thing to always remember is to let go laughing.

My best friend and I have been friends since third grade. We've shared many laughs, memories, and tears, yet to this day we're still closer than ever. One of the key reasons we've been able to stay friends for so long is because we make each other laugh. We joke around and we make any boring time into a good one. This is the story of how our relationship came to be and some of the reasons why we are still best friends. It started in third grade. I was walking alone on the playground when she asked me to play with her, having nothing else to do, I agreed. We played for the whole recess, and it eventually became a regular thing for us to spend recess together. The first time she invited me to her house, I was kind of nervous. I was afraid it was going to be awkward, or that we wouldn't have a good time. When we got to her house after school, we went to her room, played video games for a little bit, and then we had a snack. We brought our crackers to her room, sat on the ground, and started to eat. Out of no where we just looked at each other, and we started laughing like crazy. They weren't little giggles either, we laughed so hard it brought tears to our eyes. From that day forward we hung out as often as we could. A couple of years went by, we hung out more often, and declared ourselves best friends. When fifth grade came around, we were glued to the hip. Her dad was our teacher, so he already knew how close we both were. We never really got to sit next to each other, but we still managed to talk a lot. One day at recess we were joking around and she said your butt is so big, you're going to break a chair. These days it doesn't seem that funny, but in fifth grade it was hilarious. When we got inside we played this math game, I got the question wrong so I plopped down in my chair, sure enough, it broke. Other kids that heard what she said laughed, but no one really quite laughed as much as we both did.  Fifth grade was also when boys started coming into the picture. During @DATE1 break she really liked this one guy, and when he said he didn't like her, she was completely broken. That night she came over to talk with me about it, but we never ended up talking about it at all. Instead, we watched funny movies and I would do things on purpose to make her laugh. Even though we were already really close, that night made us grow even closer. At the end of fifth grade we had a little graduation ceremony. Towards the end they put on a slide show of everyone in the fifth grade class. One of the pictures was of @PERSON1 and I with mud masks on, we were both embarrassed, but we also laughed because we had a lot of fun that night, and we wondered how the picture got on the slide show. After the ceremony @PERSON1 and I threw a party. We shared many laughs and still that made us grow even closer, even though we had made new friends that night, our bond was unbreakable. Middle school was a whole new experience. New friends, different classes, and more drama. I hate to say it, but we grew apart those three years. We had none of the same classes and we both met new people, but every time I went over to her house, or every time we hung out, we laughed till we were crying, and gasping for air. A lot of things happened, our different friends fought, some of them moved, but our ability to make each other laugh kept us together through thick and thin. Towards the end of our middle school lives, we grew closer again, and things were pretty much back to normal.  Today @PERSON1 and I are as close as we were in fifth grade if not closer. When we are together not only do we make ourselves laugh, but we make other people laugh as well. We are together almost every weekend, and we @MONTH1 not do much, but we always end up laughing like crazy. Doing cheer, we also spend even more time together. Other things in our relationship are important too, like trust, loyalty, and kindness, but laughter is what has kept us together through everything we have been through. Laughter is also the reason we have become friends in the first place and I am happy to call her my best friend. Without her, my life would be very boring, and I hope we stay friends for the rest of our lives. Laughing keeps people together and makes relationships grow stronger. This was an example of how it helped me and my best friend become friends and stay friends through everything life has thrown at us.

Don't speak, just laugh. I truly love @CAPS11 little brother. We're @NUM1 years apart in age, yet from the way we act, anyone'd think we were twins. "Haha!" He was laughing at me! I landed at the bottom of the staircase and started to laugh too. We were both laughing! That's all we needed to start up conversation again. Just a little laugh and our bond was mended once more.

Why do people have so much trouble trying to laugh? Is laughter a healthy thing that you should have in your health chart? These are some questions you might seriously ask yourself. It doesn't matter at all what you laugh about, it can be one of your family members telling a hilarious joke or even a side - splitting funny show or a comical commercial. Somehow, I can't really fathom a person never laughing in their life. Some examples of people that don't really laugh anymore are probably those who lost someone close to them or those who just don't have anybody to tell jokes with. In my opinion, you have to have someone to share things with or someone who will tell you jokes when you're in a really bad mood. I always used to remember my mom telling my little brother and I to quiet down when we would talk animatedly at the family table during dinner one day. It really does give you a boost of energy sometimes, but at the same time, if you laugh way too much, your stomach will eventually start aching. Like I told you in the first paragraph, there are many different ways you can laugh. For example, if you watch a comedy show, a very good idea would be to watch @PERSON1. That show always makes me crack up. Sometimes my mom thinks I'm crazy. Or even the family @CAPS1, that's such a great show to watch when you're really in a bad mood. Another way to make someone laugh is by telling jokes. There are the knock - knock jokes and then there are the "guess what I am" jokes. But one way you're really going to make somebody laugh out loud is tickling. That always works. There's no way you can't ever make someone laugh. Either have someone always do it for you because I know that you can't do it to yourself (that would be really odd) or have a @CAPS2 see - who - laughs - first contest. It won't always solve all your problems, but it will make you feel good for a little while. It will really make you forget about the bad things for a short period.

So to relieve our boredom, we started playing the race car game driving with our feet instead of our hands. It was an incredibly fun time.  I couldn't possibly tell all of these hilarious stories. That would take hours, days, maybe even weeks. But I can tell you that laughter is definitely a huge and integral part of our day - to - day lives. So the next time you see someone who looks like they need a friend or like they could just use a good laugh, talk to them, attempt to be their friend, make them laugh.
