Laughter, one of the most joyous things there is to experience in this world. Everyone can relate to it, whether it's a hearty belly - laugh at a hilarious comedy show or a soft chuckle at a witty remark. There's no one out there who would say that they don't enjoy laughing. It's human nature to want and to need to be connected to other people; we are social beings, and laughter is the best way to connect to other people. There is no negativity in laughing, unless that is if you are laughing at a rude comment. In general, if people are laughing, they would say they're having a good time. People build relationships around experiences that they have with other people, for example dating. On a first date, it's to be expected, and an important factor, for the two people to be having fun and laughing. Otherwise, when they separate from each other and are only left with their thoughts, their impression could make or break the relationship. That's why a first impression is so important. When the two people are reminiscing about the date that they just had, if they remember smiling and laughing, then they will most likely have a positive memory of their experience and want to hang out again. Think about any experience you have ever had with another person. If you remember the first time you met them, and how you felt afterward, the way you felt then, could tell you a lot about how the relationship went. Meeting new people is difficult, but you ask anyone about how to start a conversation with someone new, and they will usually tell you, "make them laugh". It's a universal term, anyone can do it. This past month, basketball season has started and I am playing on a whole different team than I did last year. Only half the girls on my team last year are still here, and I have had to make a connection with girls who are younger than me, and who I haven't yet gotten to know. I start to think about all the new girls, and who I have already made connections with and how I'm now good friends with most of them because of laughter. Everyday we get closer and closer because we find ways to laugh with each other out on the court. No matter how difficult the practice this month gets, you can never become too exhausted when someone is making you laugh. Laughter is needed in life to make it more livable. Think about it. If you could never laugh again, what would be fun about life? Imagine life if it were like detention all the time, never being able to just let loose, relax and have a good time. No one would want that. People would go insane. Laughter calms people down and mellows them out. It helps create people's personalities and can affect others as well. Laughter is like a ripple in the water, it starts as just one single person, then expands out touching anyone near it. Laughing is contagious, like a wildfire in mid - summer, and brings joy to you and the people you can touch. Laughter, it's the foundation of happiness.

@LOCATION3 has always been my place of choice to travel to whenever my parents question me of where I would like to go during the summer vacation. The rolling green hills, which seem to stretch as far as the eye can see, stunning sunsets that paint the sky in vivid oranges and purples, and thrilling thunderstorms that shake the ground with their might are certainly a large part for my reason to go, but the idea of seeing my mother's side of the family again overpowers all of my other reasons. The core of my @LOCATION3 family has always been my Aunt Betty; with her friendly smile that can light up a room, caring personality that makes everyone around her feel loved, and a sharp sense of humor that can turn any dull moment into a fun one, she makes friends and acquaintances wherever she goes. Yet, due to the fact that we live hundreds of miles apart, I'm only able to see Aunt Betty three times each year: my family drives up to her house twice every summer vacation, and she drives down to my grandparent's house for a few weeks in the winter break. I cherish every moment I spend with her, especially when she accidentally makes a fool of herself and causes hysterics. A few summers ago, Aunt Betty, my mother, and I traveled up to @LOCATION2 to check out some of the town's antique and flower shops before dinner. We had spent a few hours driving around town, scoping out all of these shops to raid them of any gems that either my mother or Aunt Betty must have for their already old - fashioned homes. I had lost interest after the first few hours; antique shopping was never a passion of mine, and I was ready to take the one - hour trip back to @LOCATION1 to go swimming with my cousins. Once my mother and Aunt Betty had spent most of their money on a couple of "treasures" a few hours later, we were exhausted and prepared to head home when we happened upon a pizza shop down the main street. Our mouths watered at the thought of eating a slice, but rather than going inside to eat, we ordered a pizza to take home and bake instead. In her white Ford pick - up, my Aunt Betty pulled into the shop's parking lot, leaving my mother and I inside while she grabbed the pizza. Upon her return a few minutes later, the aroma of the pizza wafted through the cab, making our mouths water and our desire to get home to grow exponentially. Aunt Betty placed the pizza in the back seat, grabbed her coffee, and revved up the engine. We were all lost in our own thoughts about sneaking a slice of pizza when suddenly the front tires of the pick - up dipped down and thumped onto the road. Aunt Betty nearly dropped her hot coffee all over her lap, while my mother panicked and grabbed the handle on the door in reflex. We were all flabbergasted, stunned as little kids trying to grasp that the tooth fairy didn't exist. Moments after the initial panic, we realized that Aunt Betty had accidentally driven over the curb. We burst into laughter while poor Aunt Betty had a red - rose face and an apologetic smile wider than the Grand Canyon. She cautiously drove with the traffic, laughing hysterically with tears in her sea - blue eyes along with my mother and I. Our hysteria episode lasted for a few minutes, in which time Aunt Betty had pulled into a vacant parking lot; none of us wanted another unplanned adventure on the road. I wiped the tears from my eyes, trying to stifle the laughter and recompose myself. My mother was still giggling and wiping the mascara off her face. Aunt Betty was doing the same, and then turned around to look at me. She locked her bright eyes with mine and smiled as sweetly as only she could, and we burst into more hysterics. After the next small hysterical episode was over, we were finally able to pull back onto the street with the rest of civilization. As Aunt Betty pulled out cautiously, I burst out, "Try not to run over anymore curbs!" This drew up another round of laughter. Aunt Betty has always been there for me, through the laughter and the tears. Because we are family, we have a natural bond between each other. Yet without laughter, this bond would not be nearly as close and glued together as it currently is. Hundreds of miles of farmland and open road separates us. The occasional phone calls and e - mails are all we have to communicate between each other. My Aunt Betty is the most caring, humorous, and loving person I have ever encountered, and I unfortunately don't get to spend as much time with her as I would like. But every time I see her, I smile and think of the comical stories we have between each other. Without the humor and laughter we share, our bond would not be as close as it is, and we would both be clueless to our current world of joy.

Sunny days are diamonds and cloudy days are stone," are the famous, melodic words of Paul Simon. He was absolutely right and the day of June 15th, was a very stony day. It began when I woke up late, having stayed up until eleven o'clock the night before in order to finish my homework. As I hurriedly pulled a sweater over my head, I ran downstairs and out the door, rushing to school. Running under the dreary gray clouds, I suddenly remembered the geometry test that was scheduled for today. By my seventh - period geometry class, the sleep deprivation was kicking in and my head was pounding painfully. Of course, this had to be the day that Jake decided to cheat off my test. As his eyes swept over my paper for the third time, I sighed and stared pointedly at his own paper. I should have simply shifted in my seat so he could not see my test, but I wanted him to get the point. Mrs. Thompson, however, seemed to think I was cheating off of Jake. I took the reprimands silently and went to my locker. After collecting my belongings, I turned to go home. A loud ripping noise caught my attention and I realized, with a groan, that I had just torn my sweater on the corner of my locker. Without acknowledging the stares of my peers, I turned and ran out into the pouring rain. Once I had reached my quiet road, I could not contain myself. With my face turned towards the stony sky, I shouted until my throat felt like sandpaper. I had never had any sort of emotional breakdown before and the feeling was strange and alien to me. I hoped that no one would ever see me like that, as I had transformed into a stranger, hurt and lost. Following my explosion, I trudged slowly home and entered the house to find my 8 - year - old sister, Lily, begging me for macaroni and cheese. I sighed and put a pot of water on the stove. Maybe it was cruel fate or possibly just stupidity, but either way I ended up with half a pot of steaming water spilled down the front of my body. Granted, it was not very hot, as I had just put it on the stove, but all I could do was sit down on the cold kitchen floor, put my head in my hands, and cry. My sobs sounded like a frog croaking. I looked up suddenly, however, when I felt a small hand tapping my shoulder. "What?" Lily asked tentatively. "What did the dog say to the cat?" I just stared at her with leaking eyes. "You're a cat - astrophe," she answered herself. A small smile was set on her pink lips as she started giggling. Then I started giggling, too, which led to uncontrollable laughter. It was a ridiculously humorless joke, but the laughter felt like cold water running over the painful burns the day had forced upon me. There we sat, a giggling little girl and a messy, laughing teenager, sitting on their kitchen floor on a very grey day. One little joke, with just one fit of laughter, had transformed my entirely stony day into a perfect little diamond.

My dad and I went out to teach me how to drive after recently getting my permit. I was nervous in the beginning, of course, but quickly became comfortable behind the wheel as I navigated through the familiar streets of our town. I drove all over town completing some errands we had to do along the way, such as picking up groceries and dropping off a package. Now it was time to go through the car wash, my first time in a car wash with me in control. I didn't think a car wash would be difficult to achieve after driving all around town, but I was wrong. After having a hard time pulling up to the right spot so the wash could start, I had to roll up all the windows and fold the side view mirrors. Before I could do all that, the wash had started! As a hurricane of soap swirled around the car, I rushed to fold the side view mirror and was successful. Unfortunately, due to my slow reaction times, I could not also roll up my driver window as the soap came back around and enveloped me in white foam. My dad and I were all wet and the inside of the car got all cleaned even though that wasn't the plan at first. I finally rolled up my window and looked at my dad. He looked back at me not saying anything, the car was silent. After our minds finally processed what happened, we broke out in laughter. We had not stopped laughing through the whole car wash and after because of the rarity of that situation. All I could say after that was that people go their whole lives without having that type of car wash incident, so why did it have to happen to me! This unexpected event, though a bit of a hassle at first, ended up being a funny memory that my dad and I would surely laugh about for years to come.

You know when you're talking to a friend and they tell a hilarious story about that one time last year when they spilt soda all over the person next to them at the neighborhood barbecue, or they tripped in front of an entire classroom full of people on the first day of school? And then you think it's so funny that you laugh so hard you cry, your eyes watering and your stomach aching from the force of it. I remember days like those, you always tend to feel better when you laugh. When friends hang out, laughter is usually involved. To be able to joke around with someone and be able to laugh, you usually need to be comfortable to be able to find something funny. Laughter brings people together even on the worst days. Everyone has those awkward times when you're talking to someone who you aren't having the best of a relationship with but yet you have to make do and try to make it less awkward. There's also the random joke when someone's upset to try to lighten the mood. When you get someone to laugh, it's so much less awkward because then you know they are in a somewhat of a good mood and it's easier to talk with less tension. I've had plenty of days when I've gotten into a fight with a friend and I've had to talk to them for class or they insisted on talking. It's just like they just keep talking or just listening to you and you don't know what they are thinking

Have you ever had a truly memorable time, where you laughed so hard with friends or family that your sides ached and your eyes watered? Well, I know I have had several of those wonderful times with my friends and family. I absolutely love those moments when you laugh so hard that your stomach starts aching really badly. First, one of my most recent memorable laughing moments was spent with my mom, whom I don't see often. So, this moment meant a great deal to me, as you can well imagine. The last time she came to see my older brother and me, we decided to go bowling. She also brought her friend along with her. My brother and I hadn't bowled in a very long time, but we were confident that we would still beat them. However, it turns out my mom beat me. We had a lot of great laughs over that. Actually, I think that was the first time I wasn't a sore loser. Although, I'm still not quite sure how she beat me. She would throw the ball down the lane sideways, and somehow it would go right down the middle. When you have moments like these, that you can look back on to help you through the hard times, it's truly inspirational. All in all, we had some really great laughs that day that were shared with my mom. Another memorable laughing moment was spent with my dad and brother. Every once in a while, my dad, brother, and I sit in our living room and talk about several different things, some good and some bad. These talks can be about my mom, school, our animals, or all three of our passion for sports. These conversations always mean a lot to me because we never spend much time together. We don't get to spend much time together because my brother and I are always at school or involved in some kind of sport, and my dad is always at work. These conversations have several effects on me. Sometimes they are sad, and other times they make me feel better about things. There are so many laughable moments just in our living room. One thing we always like to laugh about is the way my dad always says album. For some reason, he thinks he has to add another "l" in front of the "b" so it spells alblum. My brother and I enjoy making fun of him for that, but we all have our moments when we like to laugh at each other. That was just one of the many things we love to laugh about. Sometimes, laughter is a very important part of someone's life. For someone who is on the edge, or upset, just saying something little to make them smile or laugh can make all the difference in the world. Laughter is a great way to make people feel loved and accepted. It's also a great way to put people back on track when they're down. I know smiles and laughing make me feel so much better inside. I hope you have had some great laughing moments spent with the people you love and care about.

In the summer of '19, I spent two relaxing weeks at my aunt's house. At the time, my cousins were living with her. My cousins and I are very close, so we always liked to spend quality time together. One evening, we decided to watch a movie. I clearly remember it was called My Best Friend's Girl. So, we started to watch the movie, and it was super funny. We laughed constantly throughout it. My cousin named Jake has an awesome, contagious laugh. Every time he started to laugh, I couldn't help but laugh too. After we watched the movie, we went to go get some delicious food. We were all in a very good mood, making hilarious jokes and doing crazy things to make each other laugh or be funny. My cousins would change their voices, making them higher or lower, repeating lines from the movie or just making up silly things. That night, we ate at McDonald's. When we got back to my aunt's house, none of us were tired, so we decided to watch a late - night program called Cartoon Network. It was a program composed of a bunch of short, wacky cartoons. They were all very funny. We would make fun of them, laugh out loud, and mimic what the characters did. We stopped watching it at about 2 in the morning. I was very tired, but my cousins were not. For awhile, we just sat on the couches and talked, continuing to make jokes and say stupid, funny things that would make us laugh. About an hour later, we all fell asleep. We continued to watch movies and just hang out for the two weeks while I was staying there. It was probably the best time of that summer. I was very happy and enjoyed my summer because of my two cousins and the wonderful time we spent together. I laughed so much that my stomach would hurt all the time, but I didn't care because I was happy. I still spend time with my cousins and laugh a lot. I believe that our time spent together and shared laughter has brought us closer and more involved in each other's lives. A person who can laugh, knows how to have a good time, and is fun to be around.

Live as long as you breathe, love as long as you live. His death was impossible; there was absolutely no way his death could be real. Breathing seemed virtually unachievable, as if I was choking on thin air. Everything around me blurred, spinning viciously as I clung desperately to the fresh - cut grass. Tears diluted the burn in my eyes, but not the sharp sting in my nose. Though neither caused my body to tremble as his death did. Attempted screams came out as muffled moans. Alone and helpless, I could feel her staring at me, unsure of what to do. My best friend stood and watched as I grew more violent, pounding the dew - soaked lawn with my fists. Whimpers transformed into ear - piercing shrieks. A door slammed behind me and I felt the strong arms of my father, trying to guide me towards the house. Once inside, my dad buried my face in his chest, more in an attempt to silence my obnoxious wailing rather than comfort me. He apologized repeatedly. I imagine he didn't know what else to do. His death was too early for the "In a better place" speech, but too late for everything to be okay. I continued to cry as I stumbled up the stairs to my bedroom, my sister trailing close behind. Sitting on my bed, it seemed like nothing was worse in the world. Suddenly, I was overwhelmed by the feeling that I was missing something, like he was closer than I knew. I sat up to see his plastic sunglasses sat staring at me from my dresser. A black frame with neon blue sides. The image of him and his "stunna - shades" danced through my head. Him standing out the car sunroof, flexing shirtless, to propping himself up pretending to be awake in class. Seeing the glasses was like looking into his eyes. In my mind, his face held grief and frustration. He didn't want me crying. The few times tears fell down my face he'd say, "Come on, suck it up and take it like a man!" I knew in my heart he wanted me to be with the people he loved and he wanted us to be smiling. With the morning sun beating on my back, I pedaled my bike as fast as my legs would allow. Reaching her front porch, I realized immediately the time I was about to spend in that house would be like none before. When I let myself in as I always did, she peered around the corner, eyes swollen and discolored. I took four steps forward and met her with a tearful embrace, in which I apprehended she wished I was him. She loved him in a way I'd never fathomed, but the desperate longing to be held by a loved one, I knew all too well. We cried and held each other because there was nothing more we could do. When there was a pause in the sobs and she actually looked at me for the first time, noticing I looked just as terrible as she did. I reached into my pocket and pulled out his sunglasses. His death made it hard not to be selfish at a time when all I wanted was to be comforted, but I knew what I had to do. Forcing a smile seemed infeasible, but I knew it was my next step. Her gaze drifted down to the palms of my hands. "Thank you." She started weeping once more. I held her and tried to be strong. More of my friends crept out of the kitchen, tear - stained and reddened as well. I smiled at them gently. They all took notice of the sunglasses in my hand, but didn't understand. They hadn't known him the way she and I did. We spent the day gathered around, at a loss for words and hungry. Our pizza sat untouched, the television on just to break the heavy silence. No one said much, about anything. "Do you remember the time he hid our biology project in the freezer?" I felt the question rise up like vomit, too large to swallow. They just looked at me, not sure what to think. I feared I spoke too soon. I began to assume all of the melancholy and crying was supposed to continue uninterrupted for longer than it had. She smiled and nodded to my relief. "And you got mad because he kept putting the nuts in your noodles." I laughed aloud; I couldn't help it. I was flooded by the memory of him trying to act confused as to why the boiling water had cashews floating on top. "Do you remember how he'd always braid your hair?" She smiled even greater. The rest of that month was filled to the brim with tears, but it overflowed with laughter. When he died, laughing was the last thing I wanted to do. He always generated the larger portion of my laughter, and with him gone I never imagined I would live fully again. But in reality, just because he left too soon doesn't mean the laughter did. My happiness in his memory will never die.

Laughter in my life is one of the most important things, because it is often the motivation I need. Whether it be an embarrassing situation that I laugh at when looking back on it, or when I'm feeling angry and my best friend does something really silly to make me crack up. Sometimes I just feel sad, and if I'm around the right people, the ones who have a knack for bringing the laughter out in me, I know my sadness won't last long. I know that to get my mind off of something, all I need are a few giggles here and there. Recently, I started going to the gym. I have always been overweight and out of shape, so the gym, like many other attempts at getting fit, seemed like it wouldn't last long. When taking the tour of my gym originally with my mom, who suggested we try it out, I was pretty excited. Of course, this was because it was something new, and I was pumped up enough that I wanted to start working out that very day. My mom, being the more logical one, and of course, the one who would be paying monthly for the membership, wanted to think and talk it over a bit more. In the end, my mom decided that it was right for us. At first, my mom kept me motivated. Because I was so out of shape, I got tired after just five minutes on the elliptical, at the easiest setting. Seeing my mom beside me on the treadmill, working hard at it and not even slowing down, kept me going. Just looking at her made me so happy that every now and then I'd just let out a short burst of laughter, followed by a questioning look from her, but then she would also laugh. Sometimes I thought it was just because I was tired and somewhat delirious from the exertion, but looking back on it now I know I was just happy that my mom and I finally had something fun to do together. The happy gym days were short - lived, because as usual, my mom was too tired and whatnot to go anymore. I promised myself to go once I was able to drive myself regularly. A few weeks after my birthday, I got my license, but another thing got in the way. My car was a 5 - speed, and I only knew how to drive automatic. So after begging my mom almost every day to take me to practice on my new car, she finally took me. In the dark church parking lot, the same one I started driving automatic in, more laughter between us started. She would have me close my eyes and "feel" where the clutch and accelerator were about halfway. At first, I thought this was so absurd that I would just start cracking up, and my mom would join in with her hearty laugh. Once I finally got the hang of taking off, which to me is the hardest part, but, like always, laughter was there to make things easier. I learned to drive stick quickly, and because I had made that promise to myself, my first trip for myself was to the gym. My motivation that time was being able to finally do something progressive just for me, and the satisfaction was doing it by myself. The whole way to the gym, I sang "Johnny Cash" in the twangiest voice I could muster, which led to more hysterical laughter. The first few times of going to the gym were based solely on the knowledge that I was doing something good for myself. After about the fourth time, though, my motivation started to dwindle. Instead of listening to my iPod while on the elliptical, I started to watch "Friends" because it would get laughs out of me while I was still working my butt off. Before I knew it, the episode was over and I had been going strong for almost an hour, burning 300 calories. I was so impressed with what I had accomplished that it felt like the motivation was fully replenished. I started going daily again. In a week and a half, I had lost 5 pounds just by going to the gym, working out, and most of all, laughing. Part of it was self - motivation, but another part was the laughter that so easily distracted me from the hard work. Because I had been

Laughter and @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @CAPS3 @CAPS4 Laughter is the key component in anything in life. @CAPS2 is able to turn any sad moment good and any great moment even greater. Here is an example in which laughter brought my boyfriend and I together. I had been crushing on the same guy, @PERSON1, for two months. I was way too nervous to speak to him. One day my friends and I were walking down the hall where he happened to be. When i saw him I tried to turn around and walk the other way, but my friends pulled me back. They then told me they heard from a "little bird" he liked me too, so we continued to walk in his direction. We stopped walking right in front of him and my friends pushed me into him then ran off. I told him sorry as I turned bright red. My best friends had set me up. We stood there for five minutes in an awkward silence. All I did was stare into his beautiful blue eyes. All i could think about was how hot he looked in his black wrestling shirt and his faded blue jeans. He probably thought i was a freak. He had been leaning against the wall standing mostly on his right leg. Then when he went to switch to his left leg he let out the biggest fart i have ever heard. We started laughing. After we had settled down from laughing hysterically, we started talking. We ended up talking for two hours. A couple weeks had gone by and we had been talking more and more each day. Another week had flew by and we went to our first movie. I called @CAPS2 our first date. That night he asked me to be his girlfriend. I of course said yes. Ever since the day he farted I have thanked @CAPS5 for @CAPS2. I wouldn't have him as my boyfriend if @CAPS2 weren't for him braking the ice with his embarrassing moment. Most of all I thank my friends for shoving me into him that day. There could not have been a better way to meet a guy. This is just one example of laughter and how much @CAPS2 @CAPS3 change or affect a situation. Laughter is the medicines of all medicines. @CAPS2 is one of the most important tools a person @CAPS3 have.

Laughter is what I'd like to call a "universal language of connection". Because no matter what language or tongue you speak, when something funny occurs, the natural reaction is to laugh. This reaction is present for all people, and when it takes place; it's contagious and helps to bring everyone together. Laughter also emits a sense of happiness and joy, which in return makes people feel more free and open to join in and laugh as well. In many instances, if there is an awkward situation at hand, laughter plays a big role in lightening the mood; and making the atmosphere a little more comfortable. In [specific date], laughter was a big key in the success of our annual family reunion. Our family reunion consists of around [number] people (including cousins, and some close friends); so as you can see it might not be easy to get to know and interact with everyone. However, at dinner time we like to switch it up, and sit next to relatives that you wouldn't normally sit next to. At first, it's usually very awkward, and sometimes even frightening for the younger kids, when they end up sitting next to our very loud and opinionated aunts and uncles. That is until my grandpa decides to crack one of his hilarious jokes. My grandpa is somewhat of a master of awkwardness. Not necessarily that he enjoys being in awkward situations, but rather that he enjoys watching them play out. Eventually about halfway through the meal, after eating in close to utter silence; he decides to stand up and give a little toast to the family reunion. Following the speech, he always concludes with a well - rehearsed joke; which, gets everyone laughing. Some of the younger cousins don't always understand the play on words. But what really gets them going, is listening to all of our aunts and uncles hoot and holler things like "Oh my goodness" and "Help me" mixed in with their obnoxious laughs. After all the fun dies down, the awkwardness always seems to drift away, leaving us with the feelings of happiness and joy that I described earlier. I believe that those feelings directly correlate to lightening the mood, and in helping to get everyone more comfortable with who they happen to be sitting by. Once all these things occur, conversation gets flowing and everyone ends up getting to know a family reunion member, that they otherwise might have not gotten the chance to truly meet. Laughter is one of the keys to happiness in life; because without it, life would be very dull and boring. Laughter also has the power to change situations, and to make them better for the most part. In [specific date], laughter changed a situation in my life for the better, just like it has done so many times since then. In my eyes, laughter is the best language of connection out there. If you really want to get to know a person, all you have to do is make them laugh!

I choose to have a positive outlook on life and I'm generally a happy person. Who wants to go through life mad all the time? Even at my lowest I know that I have a lot to be thankful for. Because of this, laughter is an every - day factor of my life. When I'm with friends and family I am always laughing. Laughter is my medicine and I wouldn't be the same girl without it. When I was in the fourth grade my family and I began going to a new church. I didn't know anyone there and I was really nervous about going to [specific date] [specific time]. Mom walked me down the stairs to the classroom and the teacher introduced herself to me. Her name was Ms. Johnson. She was pretty and very tall with a funny Australian accent. She was wearing alligator - skin boots with black jeans and a pink top. Ms. Johnson introduced me to the class stating my name and grade. After taking my seat we recited Bible verses and read short clips of religious stories. When church had ended mom came downstairs to get me. Reluctant as I was to see her I took hold of her hand, said bye to Ms. Johnson, and went back upstairs without one word from any of the other kids, but on our way upstairs a girl about my age, from which I recognized from the class said goodbye to me. I returned her nice gesture with a smile and a wave. One week later mom took me downstairs to church. This time I was relentless and determined to make a new friend. I went and sat down next to the girl who said goodbye to me last week. I introduced myself to her and she told me her name was Lily. We soon became very close. Every week I was so excited for church so I could spend time with Lily. We became best friends! We played on the same soccer team together and we pretty much live at one another's houses. In fact Lily has her own toothbrush at my house and I have one at her house as well. One time Lily and I were in church, and now that we are older we go to the main service, we laughed so hard we almost peed our pants! Lily and I have so many great memories together and though we are becoming older the memories will last forever. Laughter has truly been the glue that has held our friendship together, and I'm grateful for every moment of it.

Making jokes or just talking about funny stuff and laughing with people can make conversations comfortable and lets people see your true self. In my opinion, laughing is one of the most important things you should have in a relationship with someone because you need to keep having fun and laughing about funny things. Laughing also makes you feel close to people because once you and that person get to know each other you'll just laugh about anything even if it's not that funny. For example, when I first meet people I am very shy. I don't really say much but if the person that I am talking to makes me laugh, it makes me feel comfortable and makes me want to joke around with them, it makes the conversation fun. If there is no laughter in a relationship the relationship is practically dead. No one wants to be around a person with no sense of humor. In my opinion, everyone has a funny side, some people like to show it and some people like to keep it to themselves. Some people might be funnier but the thing is we can all be funny in our own way. I've had many experiences where laughing has benefited my relationship with people. Me and my friend met in middle school. I was good friends with his sister but I never really got to know him until I went to high school. I had a lot of classes with him so I started talking to him, but because I already knew him I wasn't very shy. The first day that I talked to him at school he was making fun of me but not in a mean way. He was joking around how I brought chocolates to his house and I didn't offer him any, it was more of like an inside joke. The thing is our relationship started off with us laughing and joking around. So I immediately felt like I could be myself around my new friend and not worry about what he would think. Now we are best of friends. We laugh about everything and we have our own little inside jokes. When I am talking to my friend I can say anything that I think is funny and I know he will laugh at it. Laughter has really made my friendship with my friend fun. One of the best relationships I have with a person is with my sister and it's because we just laugh all the time when we are together. When either of us is going through a rough time we still find a way to make each other laugh and forget about all our problems for a while. Even though we are sisters and we naturally have a bond, laughter just makes our sisterly bond ten times better. We have very similar personalities, and we are both pretty funny so the laughing never stops between us. There is always something we laugh about. Laughing in my opinion is very important to have in a relationship. Without laughter it would be a miserable, unhappy relationship. Laughing brings out the good side of people in most cases, it brings out truth in people. When you first meet people, laughing really makes conversation comfortable and not awkward. Starting a relationship with laughter can really make you good friends, for example, like my friendship with my friend. When you are sad or mad, it really makes you feel better when you have someone that makes you laugh. It just makes everything better. It really can change some people's mood and make them forget about the negative stuff in their life for a while. Laughter is just a great way to bond with people. Having someone to laugh with is just very important to have in life, as it enriches our relationships and makes life more enjoyable.

When I was about thirteen me and my older brother decided we were going to spend the day fishing. I got out of bed that morning, threw on a pair of old torn - up blue jeans and went downstairs to get some breakfast. On my way I could smell the sweet aroma of eggs and hash browns that made my mouth water. My brother was up and about and had just finished his plate. My mom handed me my plate and I reached for the bottle of ketchup. Ethan was sitting across from me as I ate and said, "We'll leave in an hour or so". I said okay and went on eating. After breakfast we gathered our poles and tackle boxes and put them in the car along with an old boat we kind of "borrowed" from the old neighbor lady. We put our stuff in the van and mom drove us into town. It was about eight in the morning so we wouldn't get back home till about three or four in the afternoon depending on how the fishing is. There was a little store in town and the creek went right behind it. It was a small creek. I grew up on it so I thought I knew what to expect. We put in behind the store and our mom left after telling us to be safe. It was a chilly [specific date] morning and a little cloudy. The water was cold and my brother said I should wear his waders. I thought it was silly seeing as we would be in a boat. But I put them on and we put the boat in the water. This was the first time we ever even used the boat so it was exciting. As we went down stream the water got fast and loud and the embankment was like a wall to the outside world. As we took the next corner there it was. A waterfall about as tall as a man. Not the kind you would see in the movies but it was good enough for our eyes. Right in the middle of it was a big rock and water went around both sides of it. We were pushed right up against the rock and were almost thrown from the boat and we grabbed the rock for dear life. We were stuck and I looked at my brother and he nodded as if to say down is the only way. So with that being said we both let go and let the water have us. As soon as we let go it was like being on the back of a two - thousand - pound animal in a rodeo that only lasts a second. When the boat sunk my waders filled up instantly and it took all I had just to hold on to that boat that was pulling us down stream now. We lost all of our gear except the tackle boxes, an oar and that stupid boat. It took all we had but we finally got the boat out of the water and poured the water out of it and the water out of me. I was scared for my life now. This was supposed to be a fun fishing trip but it was now a game of survival. We couldn't turn back now. The only way to get home was to go the rest of the way. I was cold and wet and didn't have any options. We had to continue so we tried it again just to sink. We spent most of that day carrying the boat around rapids and through brush all day until it mellowed down and we could put the boat back in. We got to a big pool, so big you could fit a house in it. There were some small rapids running right through the middle of it. It didn't look bad but with what we had been in we decided to be extra careful. We went around the rapids through the pool. As we went we barely grazed the end of the rapids with the boat and we went in. I tried to keep from sinking but my waders were too heavy. As I tried to swim to shore my shoe fell off and went down stream. Being stupid I chased after it on my belly to get it. The water was faster than I thought as I let it carry me. I was swallowing so much water and I couldn't breathe. I could feel it begin to get deeper and soon I couldn't touch bottom at all. My shoe was right in front of me and I finally got to it with barely anything left. I got to shore and just lay there choking up water. After ten minutes I got up and went back. I think it was freak luck we survived that day but somehow we did. Looking back, that terrifying fishing trip taught me the importance of resilience and the unpredictability of life.

It is true that laughter is important in any relationship, friendship, and in life. Sometimes laughter gets you out of trouble, sometimes it gets you into trouble. But the more we laugh the more we are going to be happy. A time that laughing came in handy was in elementary school. In the fifth grade, the school population was split into a group. The popular girls, band nerds, hippies, and the jocks. The lunch room was always how you knew who was who. The popular girls would sit with the jocks. Every one of the girls had a boy to flirt with. The band nerds on the floor making straw recorders and drums out of milk cartons. The hippies all in a circle eating salad out of one tray. None of these groups ever interacted with each other. I fell into the group of the hippies. We wore green everyday and peace signs on as many pieces of clothing as we were able to get on our tiny little bodies. We were the nicest group. We helped with every school - friendly activity there was to do. We did recycling

Laughter, one of the truly wonderful things that we humans can whole - heartedly enjoy. We can share laughter with friends, close - knit family members, and even with people we do not even know well. We all have the ability to enjoy and share laughter, and it is one of those amazing things that can bring us together regardless of our ethnicity, age, gender, or any disability. We all can relish it together, and no one can ever take it away from us. Laughter is simple on the surface, but yet complex in numerous ways. It is like falling into a pool of pure, unadulterated joy. Just the word "laughter" brings an immediate sense of joy to me! When our days turn sour, laughter is there to sweeten them up. Where would we be without the wonders of laughter? Laughter is like a precious tool. It is the thing that has helped me forge new friendships. Also, laughter has assisted me in getting out of conflicts with both friends and those who were once my enemies. It has also played a part in aiding me to achieve the things I desire. Laughter was a constant in my middle school years. My family and I moved frequently, and every time I moved, I had to step into the daunting task of making new friends. It became extremely difficult for me to make new friends each time I transferred to a new school. After I had settled down and gotten accustomed to the surroundings of the new school, I then began to make friends. I noticed that laughter was a key element in making people like you, and later on, they would consider you to be what is known as a friend. After I had made new friends and become very comfortable in my school, the time to move came knocking again. It is tough to make new friends, but it's even more heart - wrenching when you have to leave the new friends you just made behind. After moving so often, I just got used to the cycle of making new friends, and later on, laughter slowly transformed from something to enjoy into more of a tool. A tool solely for making friends. After I got into high school, I just stopped trying to make new friends because I felt that I knew the drill - make new friends, transfer to another school, and start all over again. I gave up trying and decided to get more involved in school and strive for good grades. Later in the year, I felt like a lost kid with no friends because I had stopped trying. I decided to go and make new friends, but somehow it became a lot more challenging to make friends in high school than in middle school. I tried to be the funny guy like I was in middle school, but I just didn't have that spark in me anymore. Also, as people grow older, the type of humor people enjoy undergoes a change. As time went by, I realized that you don't have to make everyone laugh to be their friend. It was about getting to know the person, being able to relate to them, and being there when they needed you the most. Making friends at a new school is not an insurmountable task, but it also isn't a walk in the park. All you have to do is be open to people and let them know who you truly are. This is what I learned about making friends. You can't make everyone laugh because everyone has a distinct taste in humor. Humor and laughter are different from each other. Everyone has a different preference for humor, but we can all come together and have a hearty laugh. Laughter is truly wonderful. It is what puts people in a sunny mood. We as people, despite our differences, can still all laugh together. It feels incredibly good when you get a good laugh, but it's even more rewarding when you know that the person who made you laugh did it to bring you happiness. We should not take laughter for granted for it is something that can put a genuine smile on our faces.

In the story I am going to tell you, it involves one of my close friends and myself. After school one day, my friend and I went to my house for the night. It was an absolute blast. We started off by playing video games, and we would laugh really hard whenever one of us would die in the game. The excitement and the shared laughter filled the room. Then, after a while of intense gaming, it was dinner time. My mom told us to get off the games and come eat. Dinner was really fun. We would secretly throw small pieces of food at each other when my parents weren't looking. It was a riot until dinner was over, and we didn't have anything left to throw at each other. But then it was time to start playing games again. By this time, it was about ten o'clock, and we were getting really tired. So we put in the movie Step Brothers and settled down to watch it. It was the best part of our day. We were laughing non - stop at every single joke and action in the movie. It was truly great. We both loved it and really wanted to watch it again the next morning. But before we could, my friend's dad was there to pick him up. So that was the end of the best time with my friend and the funniest time ever. It was amazing; we laughed non - stop the whole night. Now that just shows that laughter is the shortest distance between two people, bringing us closer and creating memories that will last a lifetime.

I had gotten better because laughter is indeed

Have u ever been hit by a basketball in the face? One sunny day I was playing basketball with my close friends. I had no school that day, so I think it was like around 3 pm. We were having an absolute blast playing my favorite sport and cracking jokes non - stop. The day was going swimmingly; I was making hoops effortlessly and I had some really hilarious jokes that made everyone burst out laughing. My friend Tom asked me a question about some girl, so I turned my face to him. Then, out of nowhere, the basketball hit me right in the face hard. At first, I didn't get angry; it was an accident, so it was all good. But then my friends started laughing uncontrollably. That made their day, and they just couldn't stop. So I lost it; I wanted to hit all of them. I started to think that if one of them had gotten hit in the face the same way I did, I would've been laughing too. But they didn't seem to care. So I just left home angry. When I got home, I was still seething. So I went to the garage where I have a punching bag. I started hitting it to get my anger out, just like my dad told me when I was a little kid. He said when I'm angry, don't take it out on the family; go run or hit something, but don't take it out on the family. I was in there for like half an hour. Then I went inside to the kitchen to get something to eat. My mom was there, and when she saw my face, which was still red from the hit, she started screaming at me, asking what happened and if I was fighting. I was still angry, and then her screaming at me made me even more furious. I just couldn't take it anymore, so I left to my room, put some music on. I was in there for like an hour, and then my phone was ringing. It was my friends; I had like five missed calls and three messages from them saying if I was crying and things like that, still making jokes. The time went by, and I was still angry; I just couldn't forget about what had happened. My younger brother Jake came into my room with food. I was still hungry because I didn't get anything from the kitchen since my mom was screaming at me, so I left with no food and an empty stomach. He was eating it in front of me, making faces and saying that was the best sandwich ever. I just couldn't take it. I took it from him. He wanted it back, and then I sat down and started eating it. He came up to me and asked me why I was angry, and I told him. He started to laugh, and I gave him a light punch. He asked me if I wanted to go play video games. So we went to play Call of Duty, which is an army game. He's really good at it, and I suck. Every time he kills me, he starts saying jokes like who's your daddy and stuff like that. After a while, I forgot about what happened and began to smile. So me and my brother went outside the house to play soccer. We were there for like ten minutes, and then my friends were walking by. Mike screams my name, I turn my face to him again, and I got hit again. My brother kicked the ball hard; it was going really fast. When I saw it, I had already got hit by it, but this time it was in my stomach. Everyone laughed at first, I didn't at first, but then hearing everyone laugh and thinking about it - to get hit twice the same day and in the same way because I turned my face - I thought it was funny, so I started laughing too. My friends came over and said they were sorry for laughing at me, but it was funny. And the one who hit me said that it was my fault because I wasn't looking. I was like whatever. I asked them if they wanted to play soccer with us. They said yes. We were playing for like five minutes when my brother kicked the ball and hit my friend right in the face, the one who hit me with the basketball. I started cracking up and told him why wasn't he looking and that what goes around comes around. That put a big smile on my face, and after a while, it was all good again. We were having fun with no anger towards each other. That's one time laughter changed how I felt.

The elements of laughter is to show emotion to others, to let them know that you had a great time or to show that they are special. Laughter is sometimes within me. I laugh heartily when I have a great time. The greatest laughter I always have is with friends when we're saying crazy things as we go to the bus after school. That's the joy shared between friends, a way to release the tension and stress from school. I always go home with a big smile on my face. There are always jokes to tell to bring about that joy. When the bell rings at the end of my last class, I'm tired from working hard throughout the day. When I go to my bus, which is located on the front of the school, I feel stressed out from the work I had to do. But I can't wait till my friends come to the bus. We always have a wonderful time chatting and joking around. I completely forget about school and just laugh along with the jokes and ridiculous stories we tell. When we get to the first stop, everyone gets out with joy, even me. This process has lasted for three years. But the next year is going to be our last ride on the bus, and 7, which is my favorite number, seems to mark this special transition. I hope we will still have the same great time even after this last bus - riding year.

The new trimester had started, and leadership was my second - period class. With no idea of what the responsibilities of a leadership student were, I was skeptical about taking the class. After a few days of taking the class, I began to enjoy it more and more. After a week or so, the teacher announced that we would be on stage, helping set up and organize the upcoming assembly. I had never done anything of the sort before, so I was somewhat excited. Days went by, and the entire class practiced setting up the assembly. We ran to our places quickly, moved props carefully, and stacked chairs neatly. The day of the assembly finally arrived; it was time for the show. The students poured into their seats as we scurried around behind the curtains, making final adjustments. Everything was set up perfectly. The curtains rose, and the assembly began. My peers and I stood behind the stage, watching the assembly unfold. The school band performed a long, boring set of songs. The curtains fell, and the entire leadership class ran out on stage, picked up and stacked the chairs that the band just used. After that, we all ran to get the bleachers and dragged them out to the front of the stage. The choir was now going to perform, and we then retreated back behind the curtains. The choir sang their songs, and we watched. But as they proceeded to set up for their last song, students moved around, leaving a large open spot in the top row. With the choir's last song, they performed a simple swaying dance to go along with their song. My leadership - class friends and I noticed this large open spot in the choir and thought it would be hilarious if one of us went up there and pretended to sing and dance. However, none of us had enough courage to do it. The choir finished their song and dance, and the first assembly was over. We then cleaned up and got ready for the second assembly. It was time for the second assembly, and everything was going to be performed again. The students came in, sat in their seats, the band played, we stacked chairs and moved bleachers. It was time for the choir to come out and sing once more. The thought of how funny it would be to go up on the bleachers and dance came upon us once again. Finally, we convinced one of our classmates to do it. She ran to the choir room, put on a choir robe, put her hair in a funny bun fixed on her forehead, and stepped up onto the bleachers. She took the open spot in the top row. The song began, as well as the dance. She broke into random dancing, not in any way matching up with the other dancing choir members. It was obvious she did not belong up there. The crowd soon began to realize what was going on. Laughter broke out in the seats, and soon after, laughter also erupted behind the stage. I was laughing like I had never laughed before. It was painful; tears were pouring down my face, and I was gasping for air. Running out of breath and bracing myself for a deep inhale, right at that moment, the song had a dead - silent pause. The auditorium went completely silent. I inhaled, and as I took in that air, my body managed to let out an extremely loud, embarrassing screeching noise. People behind the curtain stared at me. I knew that it was heard throughout the auditorium. Embarrassed, I laughed even harder, causing more pain, more tears, and a greater lack of oxygen. The song ended, followed by the end of the laughter, and then by the end of the assembly. We then cleaned up the stage. The girl stepped down from the bleachers, and we all scrambled out of the building, hiding the robe along the way. We laughed all the way to our next period, listening to the students in the hallway talking about it. Giggles filled the school for hours. Talk of who it was, what actually happened, and why it happened were on everyone's minds, except for ours. The second - period leadership students knew exactly what had happened. We had the pleasure of telling everyone in school about the dirty little details. The following days, however, the teachers also got word of it. Not thinking our actions all the way through, we would soon have to face the consequences. We were told it was irresponsible and child - like. We had a plethora of possible punishments, like in - school suspension, out - of - school suspension, a referral, an apology to the choir class, and loss of the privilege of being in leadership. After the school board talked to our parents and gave the event serious consideration, we got out of it with having one day of out - of - school suspension and apologizing to the entire choir class. The school board realized it was just a joke, letting us off easier than it could have been. In my eyes, the prank was well worth it. For weeks on end, every night I would go to bed laughing about that leadership assembly.

Have you ever laughed so hard that you cry? This is not the forced kind of laughter; this is uncontrollable. This is pure joy. I laugh like this at least twice a day, with tears and all. If it is even possible for your laugh reflexes to be connected to tear ducts, I swear I would have it. If I have a good laugh during the day, then I won't be so sad later on. It has made me a much happier person. And it has even been able to bring me together with other people. St. Mary's Elementary was not a time when laughter was abundant in my life. This was a time in my life where I worried and would dwell on the past. I was a rather moody fourth - grader. But my friends were much different. They did have their bad moods on occasion, and whenever we were feeling down, we would sit on the Blue Bench. Very creative, I know. This bench was navy blue and sat right at the corner of the playground, right where the baseball field started. We would sit there and watch the whole playground during recess while reflecting on our stressful lives. One day as we were dismissed to recess, four of my close friends and I went over to the bench. We watched as the boys ran as fast as they could to the field to get their daily game of football started. Almost every guy in the St. Mary's would go to the baseball field and play touch football. It was the cool thing for the St. Mary's studs. And sometimes the girls joined in too. While we were sitting there sulking on the bench, a few boys walked up to us. Hey, wanna play some football with us? We could use more people! they said. We weren't in the mood for playing football, but with their persistent nagging, we had to give in. The square field was soggy from the previous day's rain, and the grass turned into muddy mush wherever you stepped. Us girls would avoid any contact and we ran much slower than the boys. But we managed to score a few points for our team and duck for cover when needed. The football lightened our moods and was much better at making us happy than the bench. So a new tradition was formed. Every day we would go out with the boys and not have a care in the world as we chased each other around. We dove into the mushy mess of a field to save a ball and lunged to tag any person we could get to. The bench was out of all of our minds as we ran around having fun. But one day while we were playing, it was extra muddy from a storm the night before. It was hard to navigate as you were running around on the slick field. People were slipping and falling constantly. And then something amazing happened; it started raining all over again. But nobody had even thought of quitting. We just laughed and kept going. The rain blinded us, and the slick ground was no help. So a collision was inevitable. One of the girls picked up the football. The ball had been through a lot, and now it was covered in mud. She had a clear shot of the end zone and sprinted the best she could given the circumstance. When out of nowhere, a boy from the other team popped up in front of her. But instead of

Though my sister and I have very different personalities, and much of the time do not find humor in the same things, we have still shared some truly humorous moments. It's those times when you decide to just go with the flow and enjoy someone's company instead of letting little things bug you. One sunny day in @LOCATION1, I somehow managed to convince my sister to go rollerblading with me. My dad drove us to a large park that had a huge, serene pond right in the middle of it. The pond was nice in the sense that there was a smooth, well - maintained sidewalk that circulated all the way around the pond for my sister and I to skate on. However, the pond was not so nice as it was very littered with ducks and geese, and of course, their droppings as well. We always thought of the pond's water as one of the most disgusting things on earth. We got our roller - blades on and carefully, shakily stood up. Our dad was going to take a nap in the car while we made our laps around the lake. As we skated, we noticed a man and a woman sharing a date together in a very small, rickety boat. They were totally unaware that their boat was tipping strongly to one side. My sister and I thought it would be absolutely hilarious if all of a sudden the boat tipped over. We let that thought pass and continued on our route. On our next lap around, we heard a woman yelling. We looked up and saw that it was the woman who had been in the boat. The woman was now standing on the shore, angrily yelling at the man to get all her belongings that had fallen out of the boat and were now floating in the gross pond water. The man was waiting in the water up to his chest, clumsily collecting their items and trying to deal with his upside - down boat. "That date was definitely unsuccessful", I thought. We could hardly contain ourselves from bursting out with laughter. We roller - bladed back to the car as fast as we could. My sister was in front of me and when she tried to stop, she just couldn't. She basically body - slammed the car, fell back, and rolled right underneath it. My dad rapidly opened the door to find me crying with laughter. We pulled my sister out from under the car and drove home, still chuckling about the events of the day.

In @CAPS1 @CAPS2, there are so many elements in a person's life that hold great importance. Many people strive to make friends, achieve success, but most importantly, they aim to find happiness. Everyone desires happiness in their life, right? The purest form of happiness stems from your heart. It is widely believed that laughter originates from the heart and has the power to make you and those around you genuinely happy. One crucial aspect of laughter being significant in a relationship is the optimism it brings to your partner and friends. This shows people that you aren't just a consistently pessimistic, rude, and unhappy individual. You can truly enjoy life and have a wonderful time. After all, no one wants to spend time with someone who is constantly negative and only focuses on the bad things. Your partner will grow tired of you, and you will lose friends. Being able to laugh and joke around with others makes life a whole lot easier. It might not seem like much, but it takes some stress off your shoulders when you have a good time and share a few giggles. Another reason why laughter is so vital in a relationship is the sound of your laugh. What if you get a boyfriend or girlfriend, and they've never heard your laugh before, and once they do, they think it's the most annoying thing in the world? Studies indicate that they would be more likely to leave you. On that note, if you do have a terribly annoying laugh and that's why you're reluctant to laugh, I'd suggest sticking with smiling because us girls have pretty cute smiles that can get us out of a lot. Lastly, there is one more main part of laughter being important in a relationship, and that is happiness. You need to laugh to be happy. Without laughter, what is a smile? Without laughter, how will happiness shine through? Life can become quite boring when all you do is act like a mime, with no smiling, no laughing, and no fun! When you laugh, it encourages others to laugh and have a great time. Plus, it's incredibly fun! Like when you laugh so hard that you cry or when you really need to go to the bathroom, and it gets even worse when you start bursting into laughter. Laughing creates memories. And memories are a very important part of growing up. So now that you've learned these three elements as to why or how laughing is important in anyone's life, relationship, or friendship, go out and laugh. It will make you feel a whole lot better.

A couple years ago when I was in middle school, I met one of my best friends, with whom I've had great times. When I first met her was in math class, where she had an assigned seat right next to me. We started chatting, and even though we didn't know each other very well, I could say that laughter was the closest distance between us. We would just burst into laughter at really random things that happened because we didn't really know what else to talk about. Sometimes, it didn't make sense what we were laughing about. But we laughed anyway, even though we didn't always understand each other's jokes. Laughing was what kept our distance close.  Time went by, and we became good friends. Laughing was the one thing that kept us close together because, at that time, we had nothing better to do. We both are people who like to laugh a lot, and if not, we get bored easily. If either me or her had no sense of humor when we first met, I don't think we would have gotten along so well in the end. We didn't really have much to do because we didn't know each other very well. We would only hang out during lunch and in any other class we had together, but all we did was laugh at what we thought was funny, which was often really silly.  A couple of months later, we seemed to become really close friends, not just bonded by laughter. We got to know each other much better and finally had things to talk about. We also found out that we had something in common. Laughter still played a part in our friendship, but not as much as at the beginning when we first met. During math class, we were always talking and laughing at the things we said. That had never happened before. But now we were able to talk about other things too, not just things that made us laugh, and we knew that laughter isn't the only thing that keeps us close. Now we had other ways to get along as well.  I have friends with whom I get along in different ways. I have some friends with whom the relationship isn't extremely close, but we laugh a lot. With some of my other friends, I don't laugh that much, yet we have a very close friendship. My friends and I can get along in various ways, not just through laughter. We all have different ways to get along and have fun. Some of them are really calm, and some of them like to laugh a lot, just like me. Most of them are the type that like to be laughing all the time, and we are closer because of the way we are with each other.  I think that laughing can be the shortest distance between two people. There are other things that can keep two people close together. Laughing does help people have a good time together, but I don't think it's a huge, crucial part of a friendship. I believe it's about how they get along and if they have something in common. It also depends on how they treat each other. Everybody has a different way of what keeps them close to a friend, so I think it's different for everyone.

So I just said that school was good. She then told me that all people are not good, and I realized that not everyone will be kind in difficult situations.

To be part of something so special was an honor. @PERSON2 rode his bike all around @CAPS4 that day. He even rode it into his cabin and continued to ride in circles around his bunk.   I left the family to enjoy their night and went off to bed myself. The rest of the week was filled with a great deal of fun, but when the end came, the goodbyes were hard. We didn't want to leave each other. I had become part of @LOCATION1's family, and they trusted me. I felt at home with them. @PERSON2 and I were new best friends, and we couldn

Some say that laughter is the common language between people, bridging gaps from individual to individual, and nation to nation. If that is true, those hearty laughters can seemingly speak all the languages around the world. In our daily lives, we all genuinely need laughters to be around us. When people laugh, they don't just benefit themselves, but also all the people in their vicinity. There is a result from those who study psychology; they noticed that people don't cry because they are sad, rather they become sad because they cry. The same goes for laughing; people are happy because they laugh!  I remember once, when I was in middle school, every student in my class needed to go on the stage and do a presentation. Before the presentation began, the classroom was dead quiet. Everyone was silent, and there was not a single voice because we were all extremely nervous. You could even hear a pen drop. I sat at my desk, fidgeting, and had no idea what to do. I was so nervous that I thought I would pass out at any second. I believed that was what my friends were thinking, too. Suddenly, we all heard a kid laughing! I didn't know what he was laughing about, but soon the whole class started to laugh! You could feel that the tense and nervous situation was quickly gone! Everyone started to talk animatedly and walk around freely. That helped me calm myself down. I felt the big and heavy burden that was on my shoulder suddenly disappear! This story was so unforgettable because I realized how a simple laughter could change the situation from bad to good.  Laughter could change the whole world from a state of danger to peace. I am someone who loves laughter. I love to laugh because when I laugh, I feel that everything around me becomes better. It could be in both positive or negative situations, but laughter does make my life more bearable. People who are around me think that I am fun to be with because they can clearly feel the joy I bring to them.  Laughter is an important part of a relationship. My friend and I, when we get together, we always laugh about everything, from some random old house to the vast sky. We really have a great time together. There was one time that I wondered, what if nobody in my group laughed when we were together? That would surely be no fun anymore! Without laughters, the distance between my friends and me would become a huge gap, but with laughter, we would have no distance between us at all! Then I noticed another group of people. Maybe they just had a bad day, and there were no smiles on their faces. When they sat together during the lunch time, nobody talked or laughed. They seemed as if they were no longer friends. After a few days, they started to talk again and laughed just like they were good friends again! I realized that laughter could change everything. It could change not only the dynamics inside a relationship but also how people view that relationship.  Laughters do help us out a great deal. On mental, physical, and social aspects, they bring benefits to our lives. Laughter truly is a powerful force that enriches our existence and strengthens our bonds with others.

Laughter is an integral element in various situations. These situations can vary greatly, ranging from natural disasters to the simple desire to be cheered up or to be amused. Humor can make light of circumstances, no matter how grave, terrifying, or uneasing they may be. The recent earthquakes and subsequent tsunami in @LOCATION2 made me extremely worried for my friend @CAPS1. He lives in @LOCATION1, which at that time, I and many of my other friends thought was close to some of the more severely affected areas. Of course, we were all deeply scared for him, but we tried our best to make light of this disastrous situation. Our fears were further intensified when he never logged onto the ning or Facebook. However, we know now that was just because the electricity was down for him that night (our night).  When we finally learned that he was safe, at least for the time being, we were all incredibly relieved. Humor really helped to diffuse the tense situation, just as it has done many times before. As of now, this is still a story in the making because as this is being written, there are still great dangers looming over that region. Not the least of which is the ever - present threat of nuclear meltdown. The jokes have continued into the week.  I believe humor can be very helpful during worrying times because making light of a serious situation, in a way, makes it feel less overwhelming. Of course, many people look down upon doing this, which is completely understandable. They either don't see that we are genuinely fearful or don't understand and believe we're just joking about it to be "edgy" or "offensive". People who feel the need to joke about dangerous situations aren't intent upon being malicious or uncaring. Most often, they are people with a sense of humor and a deep - seated sense of distress. In times of crisis, humor can be a coping mechanism that helps us deal with the uncertainty and fear, allowing us to find a glimmer of hope in the midst of chaos.

To be honest, we never did find out what was wrong with @PERSON3. She was just insanely hyper and out of this world that day. LAUGHTER: Everyone knows that laughter is a healing medicine. It has the power to ease a lot of aches and pains, such as the deep - seated hole in someone's heart after a breakup or the long - lasting suffering of someone unable to provide for their family. However, the kind of aches laughter eased in my life was the intense pain from the loss of a dear friend and an amazing teacher.  Recently, one of the best teachers I've ever had the chance to know passed away. He was trying to get into the @ORGANIZATION1 to set up his detailed lesson plans for the @TIME1, when the fatal incident happened. <@NUM1</@CAPS2> had a doctor's appointment that day and had arranged for a substitute to take his place. It was six o'clock in the @TIME1, and it was still dark outside as @PERSON2 tried to open the doors of the @ORGANIZATION1. Before he knew it, he collapsed on the ground, waiting for someone to come to his aid. Eventually, @PERSON1, the janitor, came out, spotted him and quickly called @NUM2. The ambulance rushed to come pick him up and sped him to the hospital for emergency care. As soon as they got there, they found out he had had a heart attack. He'd had a couple of minor ones before this one. However, this heart attack was severe. It took his life, and they weren't able to revive him. @PERSON2 was pronounced dead on the day of @DATE1.  Our principal called for an emergency assembly when we all had arrived at @ORGANIZATION1 that @TIME1. We had known something was wrong, considering the strange and solemn looks on all of our teachers' faces. All the students gathered together in the small gym of our @ORGANIZATION1. The air was thick with anticipation as we waited for something to happen. After a short while, a man we all knew walked out in front of us with a microphone in his hand. With slumped shoulders and a grim, sorrowful face, @PERSON3, our principal, told us of the tragic news. My mouth fell open, and I gasped in disbelief. I could hear people shifting in their seats and whispering among themselves as they struggled to come to terms with the devastating news. Looking around, I saw the same shocked and heart - broken expressions on many of my classmates' faces. I didn't know what to do. I wanted to cry, but the shock held back my tears. @PERSON3 explained the situation further as we listened intently to the painful words coming out of his mouth. I was in a state of shock. I just couldn't believe that @PERSON2 was gone.  After our principal was finished speaking, we were led out of the gym by melancholy teachers and told to report to our first - period class. As I made my way to my locker, I heard soft sobbing, but it was mostly a silent kind of grief. I quickly grabbed the folder for my first class and closed the locker, eager to get out of the hallway and into a more private area. Walking into the classroom, I sat at my desk. People in my class filed in through the door and took their seats as well. Our teacher for that class didn't say a word to us, so we presumed we weren't going to do any work. Sitting there in silence and feeling utterly helpless, I put my head down on my desk and started to cry. It really happened, I thought to myself. The reality of the situation was starting to sink in.  By the end of first period, the sleeve of my sweatshirt was soaked in tears and mascara. Nobody had really said much, but that was okay. Seeing that I had been crying, some people stopped to give me a comforting hug as I slowly walked down the hallway to my second - period class. I expected my next class to be a lot like the first, but it wasn't. In place of the cold silence, there was the gentle sound of music. Instead of crying alone, people were being comforted by their friends. Students were making cards for @PERSON2's family. We were all reminiscing about the good times we had with @PERSON2. We retold the funny stories he told us of his life in the classes he taught. We laughed when we remembered how he couldn't hang up anything straight and that the evidence was still on his classroom walls. For the first time in that already long and tragic day, we felt a bit better. We felt as if we could celebrate his life, not just mourn his loss.  The rest of the day was bearable. Not because we lost a great teacher, but because we could remember and cherish a great teacher. Laughter eased the pain and sorrow of that dreadful day. We could remember and laugh about the good times we had in the classroom with him throughout our school years. We could remember the wonderful man @PERSON2 was through the warm feeling in our hearts. Laughter brought us together in a time of great need, helping us to heal and move forward.
